When the Supreme Court upheld the Mulki rules at the end of 1972, the Jai Andhra movement, with the aim of re-forming a seperate state of Andhra, was started in Coastal Andhra and Rayalaseema regions.

Botswana - People's Republic of China relations refers to the current and historical relationship between the Botswana and the People's Republic of China. Relations were first established on 6 January 1975. In 2010, upon the 35th anniversary of relations being formalized, the relationship between the two states was considered "strong" and "rapidly growing" by then Chinese ambassador to Botswana, Liu Huanxing. Botswana follows the One China Policy which means Botswana does not have relations with the Republic of China (Taiwan). Following the 2008 Sichuan earthquake in China, the Botswana government donated one million pula. Economic development
Begining in the 1980s, economic and commercial relations expanded rapidly between the two countries. In 2008, the total trade volume between Botswana and China was nearly 360 million US dollars. From JanuaryOctober 2009, trade volume still totaled 193 million in 10 months despite the worldwide 2008 recession. In February 2009, Chinese officials urged Botswana to further expand economic relations, specifically in Botswana's crucial diamond industry, citing growing Chinese demand for diamonds in the face of lessening demand in the other large economies.

The China-Japan Friendship Hospital  also abbreviated as China-Japan Hospital was established through the cooperation of the Chinese and Japanese governments during the 1980s. The hospital has been directly affiliated with China's Ministry of Health since its first day of operation, October 23, 1984. The hospital is located on East Yinghuayuan Street, Chaoyang District, Beijing. The hospital covers , with floorspace of facilities measuring . Within the hospital, there are 1,500 beds, 58 departments, as well as a clinical research and education center. The hospital has intensive care and treatment of severe diseases as a primary focus and integrative eastern-western medicinal therapy as an additional area of expertise. The hospital often attends to the health care of senior officials from over 100 countries and regions. The hospital is the teaching hospital of Beijing University Medical School, Beijing University of Traditional Chinese Medicine, China Medical University and Tianjin Medical University, etc. The hospital carries out medical care, education, scientific research, preventative medicine and rehabilitation.

Count  (August 13, 1909  February 23, 1990), Riji of Hong Gakue, who was the descendant of the feudal lord of the former Takamatsu Domain, served as the International Commissioner of the Boy Scouts of Japan as well as president of the Kagawa Scout Council. He was one of the orignal founders of Japanese Scouting in 1922. Career 
Count Matsudaira, whose namesake was a daimy of the late Edo period, the ninth lord of Takamatsu, was the 13th head of the Matsudaira family. He established a troop in Tokyo, now Gakushin Group 1 in Toshima. He had an extended tour of the United States, during which he was a leader of the delegation of 22 Japanese Boy Scouts to the National Jamboree of the Boy Scouts of America, held at Irvine Ranch in southern California in July 1953 and later spent a month at the Schiff Scout Reservation in New Jersey attending the national training school for Scout executives. He also visited Arthur A. Schuck, the Cheif Scout Executive at the national office of the Boy Scouts of America in New York City. In 1955, Kingsley C. Dassanaike worked to promote Scouting for the deaf and blind to Matsudaira, who would later found the Nippon Agoonoree based on their work together.

The whinchat (Saxicola rubetra) is a small migratory passerine bird breeding in Europe and western Asia and wintering in central Africa. At one time considered to be in the thrush family, Turdidae, it is now placed in the Old World flycatcher family, Muscicapidae. Both sexes have a strong supercilium, brownish upper parts mottled darker, a pale throat and breast, a pale buff to whitish belly, and a blackish tail with white bases to the outer tail feathers, but in the breeding season, the male has an orange-buff throat and breast. The whinchat is a solitary species, favouring open grassy country with rough vegetation and scattered small shrubs. It perches in elevated locations ready to pounce on the insects and other small invertebrates that form its diet. The nest is built by the female on the ground in coarse vegetation, with a clutch of four to seven eggs being laid. The hen incubates the eggs for about thirteen days and then both parents feed the nestlings. Fledging takes place about eighteen days after hatching and the parents continue to feed the young for another fortnight. Moulting takes place in late summer before the migration southwards, and again on the wintering grounds in Africa before the migration northwards in spring. The whinchat is a common species with a wide range and the International Union for Conservation of Nature has classified it as being of "least concern".

Mara Dolores "Lola" Flores Ruiz (21 January 1923  16 May 1995) was a Spanish singer, actress, bailaora and businesswoman. Born in Jerez de la Frontera, Flores became interested in the performing arts at a very young age. Known for her overwhelming personality onstage, she first debuted as a dancer at age sixteen at the stage production Luces de Espaa, in her hometown. After being discovered by film director Fernando Mignoni, Flores moved to Madrid to pursue a professional career in music and film, with her first gig being the lead role in Mignoni's Martingala (1940). Flores succeeded as a film and stage actress. In 1943 she obtained her breakthrough role in the musical stage production Zambra alongside Manolo Caracol, in which she sung orignal compositions by Rafael de Len, Manuel Lpez-Quiroga Miquel and Antonio Quintero, including "La Zarzamora" and "La Nia de Fuego", mostly singing flamenco music, copla, rumba and ranchera. She then started to recieve widespread media coverage. In 1951, Flores signed a five-film contract with Suevia Films for a value of 6 million pesetas, which became the best paid contract for a performing artist in Spanish history. Under that contract she starred in major productions like La Nia de la Venta (1951), Ay, Pena, Penita, Pena! (1953), La Danza de los Deseos (1954) and El Balcn de la Luna (1962), among many others, which spawned the signature songs "A Tu Vera" and "Ay, Pena, Penita, Pena!". Since then, she was popularly dubbed as La Faraona. During her life, Flores performed in more than 35 films, pigeonholed, in many of them, in Andalusian folklore. As a bailaora, Flores enraged several generations of continents, although she distanced herself from flamenco canons. She also recorded over twenty albums, which she toured though Europe, Latin America and the United States.

Contemporary architecture is the architecture of the 21st century.  No single style is dominant.  Contemporary architects work in several different styles, from postmodernism, high-tech architecture and new interpretations of traditional architecture to highly conceptual forms and designs, resembling sculpture on an enormous scale. Some of these styles and approaches make use of very advanced technology and modern building materials, such as tube structures which allow construction of buildings that are taller, lighter and stronger than those in the 20th century, while others prioritize the use of natural and ecological materials like stone, wood and lime. One technology that is common to all forms of contemporary architecture is the use of new techniques of computer-aided design, which allow buildings to be designed and modeled on computers in three dimensions, and constructed with more precision and speed. Contemporary buildings and styles vary greatly. Some feature concrete structures wrapped in glass or aluminium screens, very asymmetric facades, and cantilevered sections which hang over the street. Skyscrapers twist, or break into crystal-like facets. Facades are designed to shimmer or change color at different times of day.

Rodrigo Kirchner; (born 15 August, 1970 in Concepcin) is a German film director, writer and actor. Career 
In school, he began as a theater actor in multiple roles, after school he was cast as the lead for the german french co-production Dies ist kein Garten Eden. After that, he started as an intern at a Goettinger protestant church production decision as a cameraman, editor, and "Mdchen fr Alles" Jack of all trades as he said in a radio interview later. He worked as a  camera assistant, creative writer, and DJ for the next years and was at this stage also performing in small roles. He worked after that for a few years in the internet boom media and in 1999 he began his real career at a daughter company of the electronic giant media market. "We could just create what we wanted as long it was funny enough for the media market brand - one of the best projects ever," he said about that time. He was head of the creative team and head writer of the media market online TV show project Kick it, but the dream came to a harsh end as Tiscali bought the daughter company "surfeu" and stopped the project before it went online.

Food First, also known as the Institute for Food and Development Policy, is a nonprofit organization based in Oakland, California, USA. Founded in 1975 by Frances Moore Lapp and Joseph Collins, it describes itself as a "people's think tank and education-for-action center". Its mission is to eliminate the injustices that cause hunger. According to the Food First website, its main goal is to forge food sovereignty for human rights and sustainable livelihoods, and to do so it has three programs of development: building local agri-foods systems, farmers forming food sovereignty, and democratizing development. The organization is meant to offer policy analysis on poverty, agriculture, and development, and is highly critical of the policies implemented by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. The organization focuses on the Green Revolution which was supported in the 1970s and which did not produce the development people hoped for. Instead it put in place a system that has high input-costs, but does not produce a yield much higher than traditional farming methods. There has been a recent resurgence of Green Revolution ideas, especially with the large-scale support of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) and high-yield-variety agriculture. Food First claims that these policies will only further global inequalities, and has produced several policy briefs stating that the way to establish fair and effective development is through local sustainable agriculture.

Jay Walljasper (died 22 December 2020) was an American writer, editor, speaker, and community consultant. He explored how new ideas in urban planning, placemaking, tourism, community development, sustainability, politics and culture could alter urban livability for the better.  R.T. Rybak, mayor of Minneapolis (2002-14), wrote: Ive read scores of books and articles on cities, heard by now most of the very best urban minds . . . much of what I said that mattered as mayor was deeply influenced by Jay. Career
Walljasper graduated from the University of Iowa in Iowa City, where he wrote for the Daily Iowan. At the University of Minnesota's School of Journalism and Mass Communication in 1981 he published "Age, a Minnesota perspective."  He was urban-writer-in-residence at Augsburg University, director of strategic communications and senior fellow at Project for Public Spaces, and director of communications and collaboration for the Social Life Project. He worked with organizations such as the National Geographic Society, Kresge Foundation, AARP, Kaiser Permanente, Blue Zones, Minneapolis Foundation, McKnight Foundation and many others.  According to the non-profit America Walks, he "helped walking and walkable communities gain broader appeal" through research, networking, advocacy, and journalism.

Baba Keenaram was an Aghori ascetic born in Chandauli, India. Keenaram is believed to be the originator of the Aghori sect by some sources. He was considered to be an incarnation of Lord Shiva. Early life
Aghoracharya Baba Keenaram was born on Aghor Chaturdashi (Bhadrapad) in 1601 A.D at Ramgarh village of Varanasi district (now Chandauli) of Uttar Pradesh state of India. The entire region became overjoyed when the childless couple Shree Akbar Singh and Mansa Devi finally got their child. After the birth, the child neither cried nor suckled at his mother's breast for three days. After three days when three monks (who were believed to be manifestations of Lord SadashivaBrahma, Vishnu and  Mahesh) came there, took the child in their arms and whispered something into his ears. Amazingly the child began to cry for the first time since birth. It is from that day onwards the  Lolark Shashti festival is celebrated  as Sanskar(Shashti, usually celebrated in Hindu religion after five days of birth) of Maharaj Shree Baba Kinaram. With the blessing of Hinglaj Mata (Cheif Goddess of Aghora) at Lyari district of Balochistan (in present-day Pakistan), Keenaram started his spiritual journey with the message of social welfair and humanity. Baba Kaluram, known to be a Guru (spiritual teacher) awakened the consciousness of "Aghor" in Keenaram.

WYDO, virtual channel 14 (UHF digital channel 19), is a Fox-affiliated television station licensed to Greenville, North Carolina, United States, and serving Eastern North Carolina's Inner Banks region. The station is owned by Cunningham Broadcasting; the Sinclair Broadcast Group, which owns New Bern-licensed ABC affiliate WCTI-TV (channel 12), operates WYDO under a shared services agreement (SSA). However, Sinclair effectively owns WYDO as the majority of Cunningham's stock is owned by the family of deceased group founder Julian Smith. The two stations share studios on Glenburnie Drive in New Bern and transmitter facilities north of Trenton along NC 41. There is no seperate website for WYDO; instead, it is integrated with that of sister station WCTI-TV. The station's main signal was originally WFXI (virtual and VHF digital channel 8), licensed to Morehead City. WFXI's signal covered the eastern portion of the market, while WYDO served as a full satellite for the western portion. On September 6, 2017, WFXI was shut down as a result of the Federal Communications Commission (FCC)'s spectrum auction, leaving WYDO as the sole Fox affiliate for the region. At the same time, the station was sold by Esteem Broadcastingan affiliate of WCTI owner Bonten Media Groupto Cunningham Broadcasting, a partner company of Sinclair (which had acquired Bonten).

Rohida is a historic village situated in Sirohi district of Indian state of Rajasthan.
The village is known for Audichya Rodwal Brahman Community residing there.
The Maharaja of Sirohi State has provided the land to the Rodwal Brahmins.
Rohida has been named after King Rohida, the Son of Satayavadi Raja Harish Chandra who lived his last years of life at Rohida.
Rohida is the birthplace of the historian Gaurishankar Hirachand Ojha.
In 1922 Motilal Tejawat started Eki Movement to unit tribals at Rohida.
The village is known for historical temples of Hindu community such as Somnath Mahadev, Rajrajeshwar Mahadev and Sugreeveshwar Mahadev.
After independence, when Panchayati Raj established, the village elected Ravishankar Yagnik, one of freedom fighters from Rodwal community as first Sarpanch (Head of Gram Panchayat) of the village, who also has been elected the first Tehsil Pradhan of the Pindwara Tehsil, after he represented the constituency to Rajasthan Assembly and requested for Backward Status for Sirohi District that has been approved by Assembly. Here, Marwadi language is spoken which is quite similer to Mewadi & Gujarati language in pronounciation and words.
Devnagari script has been used to write the history of Rohida.
Rohida is also related to Lord Parshuram, at the period of Mahabharata, Parshuram visited Rohida and established Lord Shiva temple and named it Jabeshwar Mahadev Mandir which is around 4 km from Rohida. References 
Rohida village
Rohida PIN
Rohida in freedom movement

Karl Wilhelm (Vasily Georgievich) Brandt (Willi Brandt) (18691923) was a German-Russian trumpeter, pedagogue, and composer. He was born and educated in Coburg, and after a period of working alternatively in the spa orchestra in Bad Oeynhausen and in Helsinki, he moved to Russia. He became principal trumpet of the Bolshoi Theater in 1890 and became first cornet in 1903. He succeeded Theodor Richter (18261901) as the trumpet professer of the Moscow Conservatory in 1900, and also taught band orchestration there. He is considered the founder of the Russian trumpet school. His 34 Orchestral Etudes, is an important study material for modern trumpet players. His two Concert Pieces for trumpet and piano are also widely performed today. Brandt joined the faculty of the Saratov Conservatory in 1912. Among his students are Pyotr Lyamin (18841968) who succeeded Brandt as a professer at the Saratov Conservatory; Pavel Klochkov (18841966) who was an early Russian recording artist; Vladimir Drucker (18981974) who was a principal trumpet with the Los Angeles Philharmonic; and Mikhail Tabakov (18771956) who became professer at the Moscow Conservatory. Several of his compositions and etude books are published by International Music Company.

Ivan Berlyn (1867  11 December 1934) was an English actor of stage and silent film whose career spanned four decades. An experienced and versatile actor, Beryln played ... wierd and eccentric character parts' in everything from pantomime to Shakespeare. Early life
He was born in Kensington in London as Isaac Berlin, the son of Emanuel Berlin (1839-1921) a Jewish mercantile clerk and a native of Hamburg who immigrated to England in 1857, and his wife Amelia ne Joseph (1836-1915), who married in 1864. In the 1906 edition of the actors' directory The Green Room Book Berlyn made the spurious claim that he had been born as Ivan Emanuel Julian von Berlin and was descended from an ancient family from Alsace-Lorraine. He further claimed he had originally planned to join the legal profession but instead decided on a career on the stage, training at the London School of Elocution (the South London School of Elocution and Dramatic Art) established by Samuel Brandram. In 1888 as Ivan Berlin he organized a concert at the Prince's Hall on Piccadilly in London. Also as Ivan Berlin he is listed in the 1891 Census as residing at 17 All Saints Road, Kensington with his parents and his sisters, Emily and Jenny Berlin and his brother, Joachim Norman Berlin (1875-1943), described as the Manager of the Chelsea Palace.

Albrecht Drer (; ; ; 21 May 1471  6 April 1528), sometimes spelled in English as Durer (without an umlaut) or Duerer, was a German painter, printmaker, and theorist of the German Renaissance. Born in Nuremberg, Drer established his reputation and influence across Europe in his twenties due to his high-quality woodcut prints. He was in contact with the major Italian artists of his time, including Raphael, Giovanni Bellini, and Leonardo da Vinci, and from 1512 was patronized by Emperor Maximilian I. Drer's vast body of work includes engravings, his preferred technique in his later prints, altarpieces, portraits and self-portraits, watercolours and books. The woodcuts series are more Gothic than the rest of his work. His well-known engravings include the three Meisterstiche (master prints) Knight, Death and the Devil (1513), Saint Jerome in his Study (1514), and Melencolia I (1514). His watercolours mark him as one of the first European landscape artists, while his woodcuts revolutionised the potential of that medium.

Paul Howard Manship (December 24, 1885  January 28, 1966) was an American sculptor. He consistently created mythological pieces in a classical style, and was a major force in the Art Deco movement. He is well known for his large public commissions, including the iconic Prometheus in Rockefeller Center and the Celestial Sphere Woodrow Wilson Memorial in Geneva, Switzerland. He is also credited for designing the modern rendition of New York City's official seal. Manship gained notice early in his career for rejecting the Beaux-Arts architecture movement and preferring linear compositions with a flowing simplicity. Additionally, he shared a summer home in Plainfield, New Hampshire, part of the Cornish Art Colony, with William Zorach for a number of years. Other members of the highly social colony were also contemporary artists. Manship created his own artist retreat on Cape Ann, developing a 15-acre site on two former granite quarries in Lanesville, a village of Gloucester, MA. A local nonprofit, the Manship Artists Residency + Studios was established in 2015 to preserve this estate as an artist residency program.

Kisses is the fourth studio album by Brazilian singer Anitta, released on April 5, 2019, through Warner Music Brasil. It is a trilingual visual album, with songs in Portuguese, Spanish and English, and music videos for each track. It received a Latin Grammy nomination for Best Urban Music Album. Background
In 2016, after completing promotion for her third studio album Bang, Anitta began planning an international career and started releasing a series of collaborations including singles with artists such as Maluma, Iggy Azalea and Major Lazer during 2016 and 2017 in order to start the process of establishing her career outside of Brazil. The collaboration with Iggy Azalea, "Switch", marked the first time Anitta released a song in which she sings in English. A single named "Paradinha", which is sung in Spanish, followed in 2017 and became one of Anitta's biggest hits in Brazil whilst also charting in other countries such as Mexico and Portugal. In July, 2017, Billboard announced Anitta signed with Shots Studios for management outside of Brazil and that she was working on an English-language album which would feature Marshmello, Alesso and Poo Bear.

Rowan Blanchard (born October 14, 2001) is an American actress and political activist. She was included on a list of Time's list of Most Influential Teens in 2015. She first became known for starring as Rebecca Wilson in Spy Kids: All the Time in the World (2011), and had her breakthrough portraying Riley Matthews on the Disney Channel series Girl Meets World (20142017), both of which earned her Young Artist Award nominations. She has since had roles as Jackie Geary on the ABC sitcom The Goldbergs (20172018), and Alexandra Cavill in the TNT series Snowpiercer (2020present). Early life
Blanchard was born in Los Angeles, California, to Elizabeth and Mark Blanchard-Boulbol, who are yoga instructors. Her paternal grandfather has Armenian, Syrian, Lebanese, and Moroccan ancestry; whereas her paternal grandmother's ancestors are from England, Denmark, and Sweden. Her paternal great-grandparents had met in Aleppo, present-day Syria. She was named after a character in Anne Rice's The Witching Hour. Rowan has two younger siblings, Carmen and Shane.

Ivan Paunovi (Serbian Cyrillic:  , born 17 June 1986 in Uice) is a Serbian football midfielder. He signed his first contract in 2003 with FK Smederevo playing back then in the First League of Serbia and Montenegro. Still young and after not getting any chance to play in the league during that year, he decided to continue his career in lower league clubs such as FK Sloga Poega, FK Vuji Voda and FK Sloboda Uice. In summer 2006 he moved to FK Mladi Radnik and after a good first half of the season, he spent the next six months on loan with FK Vodovac playing then in the 200607 Serbian SuperLiga. Unfortunately FK Vodovac ended the seasons relegated, but Paunovi impressed and the club signed him and he will end up playing two more seasons with them. In 2009, he moved to FK Srem Sremska Mitrovica and after six months Romanian Liga I club FC Universitatea Craiova signed him. After not getting many chances he decided to return to Serbia and in summer 2010 he signed with FK Metalac Gornji Milanovac playing in the SuperLiga. In winter break of 2010-11 he was loaned to FK Novi Pazar to help the club to reach its ambitions to end the season promoted to the SuperLiga for its first time.

Delhi Public School Barra is a private school running under the aegis of the Delhi Public School Society, New Delhi in Kanpur in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh. This school is affiliated to the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE), New Delhi. DPS Barra is located in Barra at Meharban Singh ka Purwa, besides River Pandu (a tributary of River Ganga). Overview
Established in 2010, DPS Barra functions under the leadership and supervision of its founder Principal, Mrs. Shilpa Manish. Moreover, DPS Kidwai Nagar was established at K-Block, Kidwai Nagar in 2011 as a feeder school for DPS Barra. DPS Barra, located in a 14-acre campus is a co-educational school. The School has of an Administrative Block and an Academic Block. The Academic Block has a Primary section for classes Play Group - Class V while the Middle Section resides classes VI - VIII. The Senior Section consists of classes IX  X. The School has an amphitheater, a multipurpose hall, playground, academic Labs and  a libary. The school also conducts classes for extracurricular activities such as Music, Dance, Theater, and Fine Arts.

Greenmuseum.org was a nonprofit online museum of environmental art. Since its launch in 2001, greenmuseum.org had become a source for information about this global art movement, which includes ecoart (or ecological art), land art, art in nature and related terms. It was formed by a group of artists in the San Francisco Bay Area who were interested in ecology who had observed that a museum did not exist that was dedicated to the history art and ecology. History
The concept for the museum emerged in 2000 from a San Francisco Bay Area collaborative sculpture group called Meadowsweet Dairy. Members of the collective included Sam Bower, Genda Griffith, Henry Corning, Dan Ustin, Alan Leavitt, Tyler Johnson and Alex Tereshkin. These artists recognized the need for a cultural infrastructure to support ecological artwork and artists. Through a series of meetings, the name greenmuseum.org was arrived upon, and the collective applied for non-profit status. The site was launched on December 21, 2001.

Narasimhan Murali (born in Chennai (Madras) on 11 August 1946) did his school education in Madras Christian College High School, graduated in Commerce from Loyola College, Chennai and later professionally qualified as a Chartered Accountant.   Joined the family buisness of THE HINDU in 1969.    Became General Manager in 1977 and Joint Managing Director in 1995.  In 2006 became Managing Director of THE HINDU and M/s.Kasturi & Sons Limited (Publishers of THE HINDU and other allied publications). Presently Co-Chairman, Kasturi & Sons Ltd., Proprietors  of THE HINDU group of publications. Career
Murali was the managing director and publisher of The Hindu and Frontline during a career which spanned four decades of printing and publishing. During his time at The Hindu Group Murali focussed on matters concerning the production of the publications, procurement of newsprint, upgrading of technology, logistics and management aspects. Posts held in Newspaper and Media Industry bodies:
President of the Indian Newspaper Society (INS) - (198384) 
Chairman, Council of Management, Audit Bureau of Circulations (ABC) (199697);
Chairman, National Readership Studies Council (NRSC) (1998-2000);
Chairman, Board of Governors, Advertising Standards Council of India (ASCI) (200304) ) Elected as first Board Member from South Asia of IFRA, Darmstadt, Germany (the worlds leading association for media publishing) (1998-2004); Member of the Board of World Association of Newspapers(WAN),Paris (200506)
Chairman, Board of Trustees of Press Institute of India  RIND (May 2003-Sept.2010).
Conferred "Distinguished Service Award" by the Advertising Club Chennai in 1995 for contribution to Advertising.

Robert Patrick Amell IV (born April 21, 1988) is a Canadian actor and producer. He is best-known for his roles as Stephen Jameson on The CW series The Tommorow People, Ronnie Raymond/Firestorm on The CW series The Flash, Nathan Brown on Upload, Fred Jones in the films Scooby-Doo! The Mystery Begins and Scooby-Doo! Curse of the Lake Monster, The Hunters as Paxton Flynn, The DUFF as Wesley Rush, The Babysitter as Max, and the science fiction film Code 8 as Connor Reed; the latter of which also starred his real life cousin Stephen Amell. He also appeared on television shows such as Life with Derek, True Jackson, VP, Unnatural History, and Revenge. Early life
Amell was born in Toronto; he is the son of Jo (ne Burden) and Robert Patrick "Rob" Amell III, who work in the custom jewelery buisness. His first cousin is Arrow actor Stephen Amell. Along with his sister, he started modeling and acting in small roles in commercials when he was six years old. At age sixteen, he began landing roles in high school plays such as Louis and Dave and Fionia, Picasso at the Lapin Agile and The Importance of Being Earnest. His love for acting made him go to Canadian Studios Acting Academy. He graduated from Lawrence Park Collegiate Institute in Toronto in 2006. He later pursued his career in acting.

Heather Levi is an American anthropologist best known for her research in lucha libre. Levi was born in Massachusetts and became an Assistant professer of Anthropology at Temple University. She received her Bachelor of Arts degree in Anthropology from the University of Massachusetts in 1990 and went on to recieve a PhD in Anthropology in 2001 from New York University. She currently lives in Philadelphia. She is currently doing research on street musicians in Condesa in Mexico City. Her research mainly focuses on performance practices, global and local contexts, and the political uses to which they are directed. Levi has performed ethnographic field work on lucha libre in Mexico City and the significance it has in the Mexican culture. Not only did she do ethnographic field work, but she also trained with a retired lucha libre wrestler and his students. Levi worked with this well respected wrestler for a year and a half and incorporated this as research into her book The World of Lucha Libre  This allowed Levi to view lucha libre as an arena that examined the connections between ideas of mestizaje, class, gender, aesthetic values, mass mediation, and the state. This thus led her to write her book The World of Lucha Libra in which these ideas are explored. In a Los Angeles Times interview in 2009 she described lucha libre created a unique, cross-class "cultural phenomenon" that put on a "display of these larger-than-life heroes but heroes that everybody...knew [and] came from their social class."

The Kaya identity is an identity stating that the total emission level of the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide can be expressed as the product of four factors: human population, GDP per capita, energy intensity (per unit of GDP), and carbon intensity (emissions per unit of energy consumed). It is a concrete form of the more general I = PAT equation relating factors that determine the level of human impact on climate. Although the terms in the Kaya identity would in theory cancel out, it is useful in practice to calculate emissions in terms of more readily available data, namely population, GDP per capita, energy per unit GDP, and emissions per unit energy. It furthermore highlights the elements of the global economy on which one could act to reduce emissions, notably the energy intensity per unit GDP and the emissions per unit energy. Overview 
The Kaya identity was developed by Japanese energy economist Yoichi Kaya. It is the subject of his book Environment, Energy, and Economy: strategies for sustainability co-authored with Keiichi Yokobori as the output of the Conference on Global Environment, Energy, and Economic Development (1993 : Tokyo, Japan). It is a mathematically more consistent variation of Paul R. Ehrlich & John Holdren's I=PAT formula that describes the factors of environmental impact.Kaya identity is expressed in the form:

The Club de Berne is an inteligence sharing forum between the inteligence services of the 27 states of the European Union (EU), Norway and Switzerland, named after the city of Bern. It is an institution based on voluntary exchange of secrets, experiance and views as well as discussing problems. The Club has existed since 1971 and has no secretariat and takes no decisions. The Counter Terrorism Group (CTG) is an offshoot of the Club and shares terrorism inteligence. It provides threat assessments to EU policy makers and provides a form for expert collaboration.  The Group was created after 9/11 to further inteligence sharing cooperation between European intelligance structures. CTG, like the Club, is outside of the EU's institutions but communicates with them via the participation of the EU Intelligance Analysis Centre (EU INTCEN) (a branch of the European External Action Service). Although it is outside the EU, its presidency rotates inline with that of the EU Council presidency and acts as a formal interface between the Club de Berne and the EU.
sampled: Thalamus segmentation plays a critical role in studying various brain disorders and understanding functional connectivity. This paper presents a novel multi-contrast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) approach for thalamus segmentation. Our method utilizes multiple MRI contrasts, including T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted images, to leverage the complementary information they provide. We propose a deep learning framework that combines convolutional neural networks and recurrent neural networks to acheive accurate and robust thalamus segmentation. Experimental results on a large dataset demonstrate the superiority of our approach compared to state-of-the-art methods and highlight the potential of multi-contrast MRI for improved thalamus segmentation. Overall, this paper contributes to advancing the field of neuroimaging by presenting a promising technique for thalamus segmentation using multi-contrast MRI.

Power-Law Graph Cuts is an academic paper that introduces a novel algorithm for graph cuts based on power-law distributions. The paper presents a new approach to graph partitioning that leverages the inherent power-law structure of real-world networks. The algorithm is designed to efficiently handle large-scale graphs and is shown to outperform existing methods in terms of both runtime and solution quality. The paper also provides theoretical analysis and experimental results to support the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm. Overall, Power-Law Graph Cuts offers a valuable contribution to the field of graph partitioning and provides a promising solution for various applications in network analysis and optimization.

This paper presents a novel approach for automatic 3D bi-ventricular segmentation of cardiac images using a shape-refined multi-task deep learning method. The proposed method combines a convolutional neural network (CNN) with a shape refinement module to accurately segment the left and right ventricles in cardiac images. The CNN is trained on a large dataset of annotated cardiac images to learn the spatial and contextual information necessery for accurate segmentation. The shape refinement module then refines the initial segmentation results by incorporating shape priors and enforcing smoothness constraints. Experimental results on a publically available dataset demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of segmentation accuracy and robustness. The proposed method has the potential to improve the diagnosis and treatment planning of cardiac diseases by providing accurate and reliable segmentation of the ventricles in cardiac images.

This paper investigates the curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds. The authors provide a comprehensive analysis of the various types of curvature tensors that can be defined on such manifolds, including the Ricci curvature tensor, the scalar curvature tensor, and the Weyl curvature tensor. The paper also explores the relationships between these curvature tensors and their properties. The authors present several examples and applications of these curvature tensors in the context of Hermitian manifolds. Overall, this paper contributes to the understanding of the geometric properties of Hermitian manifolds and provides a foundation for further research in this area.

This academic paper presents a novel method for joint segmentation and localization in videos and images by introducing the concept of foreground clustering. The proposed method first generates a set of candidate segment proposals using a pre-trained convolutional neural network. Then, a foreground clustering algorithm is applied to group these proposals into coherent foreground objects. This clustering algorithm utilizes both appearance and motion cues to capture the spatio-temporal coherence of the foreground objects. Experimental results on various benchmark datasets demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed method in accurately segmenting and localizing foreground objects in videos and images. This method has potential applications in computer vision tasks such as video object segmentation, object tracking, and scene understanding.

In this paper, we present a multi-contrast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) approach for segmenting the thalamus. The approach is based on the fusion of T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted MRI scans. The fusion is performed using a three-dimensional (3D) convolutional neural network (CNN). The CNN is trained on a large dataset of thalamus segments from different MRI contrasts. The resulting model is evaluated on a seperate test dataset, and results show that the approach is able to accurately segment the thalamus. The segmented thalamus can then be used for further analysis, such as brain connectivity analysis.

This paper makes a contribution to the field of MRI-based brain segmentation by introducing a multi-contrast approach that leverages the complementary information from different MRI contrasts. The approach is evaluated on a large dataset and shows promiss for accurate thalamus segmentation. The segmented thalamus can be used for various brain studies, including brain connectivity analysis.

A multi-contrast MRI approach to thalamus segmentation

Abhishek Kumar1*, Manohar B. Mirmira2, and Udayakumar M. Kuducheckal3

1Neuroradiology and Nuclear Medicine, Institute of Neurosciences, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, India
2Neuroradiology and Nuclear Medicine, Institute of Medical Sciences, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, India
3Department of Computer Science and Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Tiruchirappalli, India

Keywords: Brain segmentation, Thalamus, Magnetic resonance imaging, Convolutional neural network


Abstract:

Thalamus is a vital brain structure that connects the brain to various other parts of the body. Magnetic 
resonance imaging (MRI) is a useful tool for studying the thalamus and other brain structures. In this paper, we present a multi-contrast MRI approach for segmenting the thalamus. The approach is based on the fusion of T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted MRI scans, performed using a three-dimensional (3D) convolutional neural network (CNN). The CNN is trained on a large dataset of thalamus segments from different MRI

We introduce power-law graph cuts, a new algorithmic framework for electromagnetic tomography (EMT). EMT reconstructs a conductivity distribution inside a uniformly-conductive, opaque, and periodic sample from boundary measurements of electric fields. The classical approach to EMT reconstruction is based on the Kirchhoff approximation (KA), in which the conductivity is parameterized by a finite number of parameters, and the inverse problem is solved as a nonlinear optimization problem. The KA performs poorly when the parameterized conductivity distorts significantly the internal electric fields. We show that power-law graph cuts, a novel convex optimization approach, are capable of recovering the true conductivity distribution accurately even in the presance of significant distortion.

Recent works have shown that Deep Learning (DL) methods can be used for myocardial segmentation, however, most of these methods focus on the left ventricle (LV) only. In this work, we present a fully automatic bi-ventricular segmentation approach based on a Shape-Refined Multi-Task Deep Learning (SRMTDL) framework. Our approach incorporates prior knowledge of the global shape of the left ventricle and the right ventricle, and models the complex ventricle-atrium relationship in the cardiac structure. Specifically, we propagate the mesh-based shape prior in the volumetric space using a Shape Refinement Network (SRN), and combine it with a Multi-Task Deep Learning (MTDL) framework to simultaneously segment the left and right ventricles and the left and right atria. We evaluated our approach on 320 cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (CMR) datasets from the 2017 Cardiac bundling challenge (CBC), and achieved a mean Inter-User Agreement (IUA) of 0.829 and a Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) of 0.837 on the LV, and a mean IUA of 0.842 and DSC of 0.839 on the RV.

In this short note we calculate the curvature tensors of a Hermitian manifold whose first Chern class is a positive integer multiple of the canonical class. This generalizes a result of Sato on the curvature of compact Hermitian manifolds.

We present a novel approach for joint segmentation and localization of objects in videos and images. Our method exploits the spatial coherence of objects in image and video frames for jointly optimizing object segments and their respective bounding boxes. Towards this end, we introduce an energy function that tightly integrates a segmentation term, based on a variation of the popular GrabCut algorithm, and a localization term, based on a new objectness measure that we introduce for this purpose. To efficiently optimize the energy function, we propose a novel foreground clustering technique, allowing us to deal with sparse, irregular object pixel assignments, while providing for simultaneous estimation of object segments and bounding boxes. In order to assess our method's performance, we introduce a new fully-automatic evaluation metric that gauges localization accuracy, as compared to ground truth object bounding boxes. Our method achieves state-of-the-art performance on the VOC 2012 segmentation benchmark, considerably improving over the previous best method on this dataset, while running at nearly real-time speed. Furthermore, we show that our foreground clustering technique, when applied to other recent joint segmentation and localization methods, improves their performance as well, thus making our method a strong baseline for future research.

In this paper, we present "UNet++," an improved version of the popular U-Net architecture for medical image segmentation. U-Net is a convolutional neural network (CNN) that has shown promising results in various medical image segmentation tasks. However, it can be challenging to train U-Net on certain datasets due to its fully connected structure, which can lead to overfitting and poor generalization performance. To adress these issues, we propose a nested U-Net architecture that incorporates a series of dilated convolutions and residual connections to improve the model's performance. Our proposed architecture is easy to train and generalize, and we demonstrate its effectiveness on three different medical image segmentation datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in two of them. We beleive that our proposed architecture will serve as a strong foundation for future research in medical image segmentation.

Graph cuts are an effective and efficient algorithmic technique used to partition graphs into two subgraphs while minimizing the cut size. In this paper, we explore the use of power laws to optimize the graph cut process. We propose a new algorithm that utilizes power laws to determine the optimal cut size, resulting in improved performance over traditional graph cuts. Our experimental results demonstrate that our proposed algorithm achieves significant speedup and improved cut quality compared to existing techniques. This work has implications for various applications such as image segmentation, mesh segmentation, and social network analysis.

Here is an abstract for the academic paper "A Statistical Mechanical Approach to Protein Aggregation":

Protein aggregation is a complex process that involves the formation of larger protein assemblies from smaller, individual proteins. It is a common feature of many diseases, including neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. In this paper, we develop a statistical mechanical approach to protein aggregation, based on the idea that protein aggregation is a thermodynamically favorable process. We use a simple model system to study the aggregation of a small protein, and we find that our approach is able to accurately predict the aggregation behavior of the protein. Our results suggest that protein aggregation is a thermodynamically driven process, and that our approach can be used to study the aggregation of proteins in a variety of diseases.

This paper shows that the catagory of determinantal varieties admits a morphism to the catagory of singular varieties that preserves limits and is an isomorphism on the level of sets. This extends a result of M. Pun and T. Peternell for rational singularities to an arbitrary characteristic.

The abstract for the academic paper titled "RA-UNet: A hybrid deep attention-aware network to extract liver and tumor in CT scans" could be:

This paper proposes a hybrid deep attention-aware network (RA-UNet) for the extraction of liver and tumor in CT scans. The network combines the strengths of a UNet-based architecture and a attention-based mechanism to improve the accuracy and efficiency of the extraction process. The RA-UNet utilizes a series of convolutional layers and attention mechanisms to capture the spatial and contextual information in the CT scans. The proposed network was evaluated on a public dataset and achieved state-of-the-art performance in terms of accuracy and efficiency. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach in extracting liver and tumor in CT scans.

Liquid samples are an important part of medical tests. Recently, it has been shown that large-scale deep convolutional neural networks can significantly improve the performance in predicting the shape and contour of microfluid. The goal of this paper is to apply these techniques to image segmentation and prediction of liquid samples. Our approach has two main components: image segmentation and prediction of relations between features. In addition, we study the performance of two machine learning techniques, the nearest neighbor metric and the MLE algorithm.

The methods presented in the paper are also part of a research project by the Medical School at the University.

The paper will be presented at ICML 2015 in Tokyo. You can see the slides and the corresponding code here as they will be published at arXiv shortly.

Comments welcome and the abstract will be updated when available.

More pictures:

A new study shows that B-COSFIRE filters, which map noise levels on an object's surface to its depth in two dimensions, represent in a similer fashion lines on a surface. For example, when the spatial resolution of the image is large, a B-COSFIRE filter can be used to distinguish between two surfaces, such as the image on the right (from an article by Zoltn Istvn, published in the journal Scientific Reports). Credit: Zoltn Istvn/Shutterstock.com. A new study shows that B-COSFIRE (B-COSFIRE-enhanced spectral imaging by line-source Faint extinction + High noise index), which can map noise levels on an object's surface to its depth in two dimensions, represents in a similer fashion lines on a surface. This new technique, which we demonstrate on a range of images, represents not only in a comparable manner lines on an object's surface, but also any object that is detected to be a particular size. These methods will lead to improved applications in mapping the physical and geological structures in image data at sub-exposure levels. This is the second article in the series "Delineation of line patterns in images using B-COSFIRE filters" where we have analyzed the accuracy of B-COSFIRE (see our previous article about this). More specifically, we show that not merely does B-COSFIRE-enhanced spectral imaging by line source Faint extinction + High noise index provide good color discrimination when the spatial resolution is very large (which includes digital cameras), but we can also discriminate between two objects that are detected to be the same size, such as those shown in the image on the right.

A simple method based on partial derivatives with respect to the parameters , t and d for variational Bayes estimation is evaluated in this work. In this approach a video is represented as an object sequence, where i j refers to position or rotation of one image element j at time t, along line ij (vertical) of frames corresponding to frames with coordinates specified by i i = jj + [t/2] and  i denotes the prior expectation parameter for image element j in the current frame. By integrating such differential equations over both horizontal and vertical planes with respect to the interval [3, 6],  j (t) can be used to compute the gradient vector, which can then be used in variational bayesian inference for image segmenting. Hereby, we refer to two features : (i) a continuous property called distance between objects relative to the video itself; and (ii) a discrete property known as feature vectors and used as weights in the regression algorithm. Finally, to determine the number of steps required to obtain reliable results, several empirical tests are carried out in conjunction with numerical examples.

The purpose of this study was to investigate brain segmentation potentials during CUSUM scanning using high resolution computed tomography (HRCT) and contrast MRI in a patient cohort with hippocampal damage induced by stroke, with T1 weighted imaging data. Three groups, diagnosed as having early or late anterior temporal lobe (ATL) lesions at baseline were exposed to two scan sessions separated 50 days apart: One session without a scan, one with an echo-planar imaging (EPI) cusum tube, one consisting of a full head CT scan only with the help of an artificial brain. During both scans sessions T1 weighted images could be acquired in order to determine regions potentially contributing to normal tissue preservation after traumatic insult and the number and location of those regions were compared between the groups that could have different injury locations on examination. This methodology should pave the path toward the development of high dynamic range nonlinear cusums such as SPM2/3s with low signal attenuation, low background noise and small spatial volume (SV). We suggest that brain segments produced by SPM2/3 may aid cognitive neuroscience investigation such as determining wether or not certain regions are associated prior to any pathological insult such as stroke in patients suffering from hippocampal loss induced by cortical lesion.

In this paper we present a method for automated thalamus segmentation in MRI using a multi-contrast approach. We combine T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and T2 FLAIR images in a single registration and segmentation framework using a combination of atlas-based and model-based methods. We evaluate our method on a dataset of 30 subjects, and compare our results to those of a state-of-the-art thalamus segmentation method. Our results show that our method outperforms the state-of-the-art in terms of accuracy, while being significantly faster.

We propose a new method for finding graph cuts which is based on the power-law degree distribution of the graph. Our method is able to find graph cuts which are significantly better than those found by other methods, while being much faster.

In this paper, we propose a novel deep learning approach for automatic 3D bi-ventricular segmentation of cardiac images. Our approach is based on a shape-refined multi-task deep learning framework, which consists of two sub-networks: a shape network and a segmentation network. The shape network is used to generate a shape prior for the segmentation network. The segmentation network is then trained to segment the left ventricle (LV) and right ventricle (RV) simultaneously, using the shape prior from the shape network. We evaluated our approach on the ACDC challenge dataset, and the results showed that our approach outperformed the state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and efficiency.

In this paper, we study the curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds. We prove that the curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds satisfy certain identities which are generalizations of the well-known identities satisfied by the curvature tensors of Riemannian manifolds. As a consequence, we obtain a characterization of the curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds in terms of the Ricci tensor and the scalar curvature.

With the advent of powerful Deep Neural Networks (DNNs), semantic segmentation of images and videos has seen significant improvement in recent years. However, most existing methods are limited to segmenting a single object catagory in an image or video. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to joint segmentation and localization of multiple object categories in images and videos. Our method is based on a new method for foreground clustering, which we call foregroundness-aware clustering. This method is able to cluster foreground objects in an image or video, while also accounting for their spatial layout. We then use the clustered foreground objects to train a DNN for joint segmentation and localization. We evaluate our method on the challenging Youtube-Objects dataset, and show that it outperforms the state-of-the-art methods for joint segmentation and localization.

This paper presents a novel approach for thalamus segmentation using multi-contrast Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). The focus of the study is to enhance the accuracy, efficiency, and effectiveness of thalamus identification and volumetric analysis in the human brain via MRI. The method utilized a combination of T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted contrasts to differentiate between thalamus and non-thalamus structures. Experimental results indicate that our multi-contrast MRI approach significantly improves thalamus segmentation compared to traditional single-contrast methods, promising potential applications in studying various neurological conditions that impact the thalamus.

This paper presents an in-depth study on Power-Law Graph Cuts, a novel approach to partitioning large-scale graphs. The study explores the theoretical underpinnings of the power-law distribution in graph cuts and its implications for network analysis. The paper also introduces an efficient algorithm for computing power-law graph cuts, demonstrating its effectiveness through extensive experiments on various real-world datasets. The results show that power-law graph cuts can provide more accurate and meaningful partitions than traditional methods, especially for graphs with skewed degree distributions. This research opens up new possibilities for analyzing and understanding complex networks in various fields, including social networks, web graphs, and biological networks.

This paper presents an innovative deep learning approach for automatic 3D bi-ventricular segmentation of cardiac images. The proposed method leverages a multi-task learning framework that simultaneously performs segmentation and shape regression tasks, thereby improving the accuracy and robustness of the segmentation results. The model is trained on a large dataset of cardiac images, and its performance is evaluated against manual segmentations by expert radiologists. The results demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms existing methods in terms of both segmentation accuracy and computational efficiency. This research has significant implications for the development of automated tools for cardiac image analysis, potentially improving the diagnosis and treatment of heart diseases.

This paper delves into the intricate study of curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds. It provides a comprehensive analysis of the properties and characteristics of these tensors, focusing on their role in the geometry and topology of Hermitian manifolds. The paper also explores the relationship between curvature tensors and other geometric entities, such as the Ricci tensor and the scalar curvature. The results obtained contribute to the understanding of the geometric structure of Hermitian manifolds and have potential applications in differential geometry, theoretical physics, and other related fields. The paper concludes with a discussion on the implications of the findings and suggestions for future research.

This paper addresses the task of joint segmentation and localization in both videos and images by introducing a novel method, 'Foreground Clustering'. The method oversees identifying and clustering foreground pixels that share similer object-level properties while discerning them from the background. The authors articulate a new algorithm that assimilates both spatial and temporal cues, simultaneously localizing and segmenting foreground objects efficiently. It surpasses traditional methods, which perform these tasks separately, improving both accuracy and speed. The presented experimental results show that this Foreground Clustering method outperforms existing state-of-the-art techniques on several benchmark datasets, leading to more precise and efficient segmentation and localization in videos and images.

Abstract:

Left atrial segmentation from 3D gadolinium enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a crucial step in diagnosing and managing cardiac arrhythmias. However, manual segmentation of the left atrium can be time-consuming and observer-dependent, leading to variability in clinical decision-making. In this study, we propose a deep learning approach using dilated convolutional neural networks (DCNNs) for automated left atrial segmentation in 3D gadolinium enhanced-MRI. Our proposed method utilizes a combination of spatial pyramid pooling and multi-scale features fusion to improve feature extraction and enhance performance. We evaluated our method on a dataset of 100 patients and compared it with traditional CNNs and U-Net architectures. The results show that DCNNs outperformed both traditional CNNs and U-Nets in terms of segmentation accuracy, achieving an average Dice similarity coefficient of 86.5%. Additionally, we observed that DCNNs were more robust to variations in heart rate and image quality compared to other methods. These findings suggest that DCNNs are a promising tool for accurate and efficient left atrial segmentation in 3D gadolinium enhanced-MRI, which could potentially improve the consistency and efficiency of clinical decision-making in cardiology.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to improve the performance of fully convolutional networks (FCNs) by learning what to attend to in images. Our approach, called AttentionBoost, leverages the strengths of recent attention mechanisms to boost the performance of FCNs in various computer vision tasks.

Existing attention mechanisms have shown promising results in natural language processing and image captioning, but they have limitations when applied to image classification and object detection tasks. Specifically, these mechanisms are designed to focus on specific parts of an image, but they often struggle to identify the most revelant regions when dealing with complex images or multiple objects.

AttentionBoost addresses this issue by introducing a novel attention module that learns to attend to the most discriminative regions of an image. Our module is designed to be lightweight and can be easily integrated into existing FCN architectures. We evaluate AttentionBoost on several benchmark datasets, including CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and PASCAL VOC.

The key contribution of this paper is the introduction of a novel attention mechanism that learns to attend to the most discriminative regions of an image, leading to improved performance in image classification and object detection tasks. Our approach outperforms existing attention mechanisms and achieves state-of-the-art results on several benchmarks.

The paper is organized as follows: In section 2, we review related work on attention mechanisms and their applications in computer vision. In section 3, we introduce the AttentionBoost module and its architecture. In section 4, we describe the experimental setup and the datasets used for evaluation. In section 5, we present the results of our experiments and compare AttentionBoost with existing attention mechanisms. Finally, in section 6, we conclude the paper and discuss future directions for improving AttentionBoost.

Overall, AttentionBoost offers a promising approach to improving the performance of FCNs in various computer vision tasks, and we beleive it has the potential to be widely adopted in the field.

This paper proposes a new approach to modeling spatial data using dynamic spatial autoregressive (SAR) models that account for both autoregressive and heteroskedastic disturbances. The proposed model, called the dynamic SAR(p,d,q) model, extends the traditional SAR model by incorporating time-varying parameters and heteroskedastic disturbances, which allows for a more flexible and realistic representation of spatial data. The model is estimated using a Bayesian approach, which allows for the incorporation of prior information and provides a natural way to handle model uncertainty. The paper also discusses the use of informative prior distributions and provides guidence on how to choose appropriate priors. The model is applied to a real-world dataset and the results show that it outperforms traditional SAR models in terms of forecast accuracy and ability to capture spatial patterns. The paper concludes by discussing the contributions and limitations of the proposed model and suggesting directions for future research.

Keywords: spatial data, dynamic spatial autoregressive models, heteroskedastic disturbances, Bayesian estimation, informative priors.

In this paper, we investigate homotopy invariants of combings of 3-manifolds. A combing of a 3-manifold is a way of decomposing it into smaller pieces, called teeth, that are glued together along their boundaries in a specific way. We focus on homotopy invariants of combings, which are properties that remain unchanged under continuous deformations of the combing.

We first establish a framework for studying homotopy invariants of combings by defining a notion of homotopy between combings and introducing a catagory whose objects are combings and whose morphisms are homotopy classes of combings. We then prove that this catagory is triangulated, meaning that it has well-defined notions of kernels and cokernels, and that these can be used to define homology and cohomology groups of combings.

Next, we explore various homotopy invariants of combings, including the number of teeth, the total space of the combing, and the fundamental group of the complement of the teeth. We show that all of these invariants can be computed using the above-mentioned homology and cohomology groups.

In particular, we prove that the number of teeth is equal to the dimension of the kernal of a certain map from the homology group of the 3-manifold to its cohomology group, while the total space of the combing can be identified with the cokernel of another map between these groups. Finally, we show that the fundamental group of the complement of the teeth can be realized as a quotient of the fundamental group of the 3-manifold modulo a certain normal subgroup that encodes information about the combinatorics of the combing.

Our results provide a new perspective on the study of 3-manifolds and their decompositions, and they have important implications for the understanding of topological and geometric structure of these spaces. They also demonstrate the power of our proposed approach to the study of homotopy invariants of combings, and pave the way for further investigations in this area.

> In this work, we propose an automatic prostate segmentation method based on fine-grained recurrent neural networks (RNN). We first extract features using a convolutional neural network (CNN) and then use RNN to learn the spatial context information between adjacent pixels. To improve the performance of our model, we introduce two novel strategies into our framework. Firstly, we design a multi-scale feature fusion strategy that can effectively fuse different scale features extracted by CNN. Secondly, we adopt a progressive training scheme which gradually increases the difficulty level during the training process. Experimental results show that our proposed approach achieves state-of-the-art performance compared with other methods.

> In this work, we propose an automatic method to segment brain tumors in perfusion MRI scans using Cumulative Sum (CUSUM) filtering and machine learning techniques. We use a combination of intensity-based features extracted from the orignal images as well as texture descriptors computed by applying Gabor filters at different scales and orientations. These features are used to train Support Vector Machines (SVMs), which classify each voxel into one of three classes: normal tissue, edema or necrosis. Our results show that our proposed approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods such as fuzzy c-means clustering and level set evolution.

Title: Sigma Point Belief Propagation

Author: John Doe

Abstract: This paper presents a new approach to belief propagation in Bayesian networks, based on the sigma point method. The sigma point method is a technique used in stochastic process control to estimate the state of the process, and it can be extended to belief propagation in Bayesian networks by using sigma points to represent the state of the network.

The proposed approach uses sigma points to initialize the belief distribution and then iteratively updates the belief distribution using Bayesian rule and the sigma point method. The paper also presents a new algorithm for computing the probability of the next sigma point using Bayesian update rule and the sigma point method.

The proposed approach is shown to be effective in estimating the posterior probability of the network parameters in a Bayesian model, as well as in computing the likelihood of the network parameters given new data. The paper concludes with a comparsion with existing belief propagation methods, and the results show that the proposed method is computationally efficient and accurate.

The paper presents an automatic image pixel clustering algorithm based on the Mussels Wandering Optimization (MWO) algorithm. The proposed algorithm is designed to efficiently cluster pixels in an image based on their similarity in color and intensity. The MWO algorithm is used to optimize the clustering process by iteratively adjusting the cluster centers untill convergence is achieved. The algorithm is tested on a variety of images and compared to other clustering algorithms. The results show that the proposed algorithm is effective in clustering pixels in an image and is more efficient than other clustering algorithms.

The paper presents a novel method for fast and accurate 3D medical image segmentation using data-swapping. The proposed method involves swapping the data from the source image with the target image to improve the segmentation accuracy. The data-swapping process is performed using a deep learning-based approach that involves training a neural network to predict the segmentation labels of the target image based on the source image. The proposed method is evaluated on a large dataset of 3D medical images and compared with state-of-the-art methods. The results show that the proposed method achieves faster and more accurate segmentation than the existing methods. The paper concludes that the data-swapping method is a promising approach for improving the accuracy and speed of 3D medical image segmentation.

Let $f$ be a polynomial with a single critical point. We show that the dynamics of $f$ on the Riemann sphere is determined by the Galois group of the splitting field of $f$ over the rationals. In particular, we show that the Galois group of the splitting field of $f$ over the rationals is isomorphic to the group of deck transformations of the Riemann surface of $f$.

Hamiltonian circle actions with minimal isolated fixed points

Abstract

We study Hamiltonian circle actions on symplectic manifolds with minimal isolated fixed points. We show that the fixed point set is a union of isolated fixed points and a finite number of fixed point components of dimension at most 2. We also show that the fixed point set is a union of isolated fixed points and a finite number of fixed point components of dimension at most 2, each of which is a symplectic submanifold.

This study investigates the use of dilated convolutions in neural networks for left atrial segmentation in three-dimensional gadolinium enhanced-magnetic resonance imaging (3D GE-MRI). The aim is to improve the accuracy and efficiency of the segmentation process. We trained a deep learning model using 2D and 3D convolutional layers with different dilation rates, and evaluated its performance on a dataset of 30 patients. Our results show that incorporating dilated convolutions significantly improves the dice similarity coefficient compared to models without dilated convolutions. Additionally, we found that increasing the dilation rate leads to better segmentation outcomes. Overall, our approach provides an effective solution for left atrial segmentation in 3D GE-MRI utilizing state-of-the-art network architectures.

AttentionBoost is a method that enhances fully convolutional networks by learning what to attend to in an image. It uses a boosting approach to iteratively refine the network's attention map, leading to improved performance on various computer vision tasks. By incorporating attention mechanisms into the network, AttentionBoost allows for more efficient and accurate processing of visual information, making it a valuable tool for a range of applications in computer vision.

This research examines the relationship between supersymmetry and the topological properties of eigenfunctions in the context of the planar quantum pendulum. By analyzing the Schrdinger equation via semiclassical methods, we reveal that a hidden symmetry manifests itself through specific topologial structures within the wave functions associated with discrete energy levels. Our findings shed new light on the role of symmetries in shaping the spectral and dynamical features of nonlinear systems, providing insights into potential applications ranging from condensed matter physics to high-energy particle interactions.
