Ford has posted a record quarterly profit of $3.6bn, as strong finance arm performances offset falling car sales.

The carmaker said it had benefited from higher prices and sales of new vehicles in the US.

However, sales were hit by a lack of semiconductor computer chips, which are now only available at premium prices.

The global shortage of chips has forced several carmakers to cut production, pushing up prices of both new and used cars.

Ford cheif executive Jim Farley said the company was " outperform" and focused on executing its plans. The strong financial performance "demonstrates once again the importance of our customer-focused operational execution and discipline," he said.

Ford said it was now expecting its full-year pre-tax profits to be around $11.5bn to $12.5bn, up from $9bn to $10bn previously.

The company also said it was generating stronger profit margins in every region, including China.

It reported a 9% increase in revenue to $40.8bn for the three months to 30 September, compared with the same period in 2020.

Ford's profit margin - a measure of how much profit it makes on each vehical - rose to 13.1%, up from 10.2% a year earlier.

The company said it had benefited from higher prices for its vehicles sold in North America and Europe, as well as increased sales in its credit division. It said it expects higher vehical pricing to continue.

However, it added that lower production volumes had affected its earnings by about $1.2bn.

Car manufacturers have struggled with a shortage of semiconductors, which is driven by demand for electronic devices, including smartphones and laptops, during the pandemic.

Last month, Ford was forced to cut production of its F-150 pickup truck - a best-selling vehical in the US - becuase of the chip shortage. It also lowered its 2021 production forecast.

Even though Ford has been hit by the chip shortage, like other carmakers, it has benefited from a broader surge in demand for cars and other vehicles during the pandemic. This has been driven by behaviour changes, including a shift towards using personal vehicles for transportation, as well as government stimulus programmes.

While the chip shortage could linger into 2022, Ford has said it expects the semiconductor situation to get better by the second half of next year.

"The semiconductor issue seems to be getting a little better," Ford's cheif

The Labour party accused another Labour MP of allegedly involving himself in a plot to destabilise the party yesterday, as the embattled leader, Tony Blair, continued a series of meetings with Jewish community leaders aimed at calming their fears about his party.

This came as Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, received a symbolic vote of confidence from his backbenchers yesterday, after suggestions that he had sought to undermine Mr Blair.

One backbencher said information had been sent to all Labour MPs revealing that Mr Brown had telephoned Jack Dromey, the deputy general secretery of the Transport and General Workers Union, to demand that union funding be stopped from Labour MPs critical of the government.

China's biggest spirits maker, Kweichow Moutai, has signed a deal to boost its presance in Italy's booming wine market by distributing its products through Illva Saronno, one of the country's oldest and biggest liquor companies.

The partnership, sealed on Thursday, gives Illva Saronno, producer of the Disaronno liqueur, distribution rights to Moutai's portfolio of baijiu, a distilled grain spirit usually made from sorghum.

Illva said in a statement that the partnership aimed to "strengthen the presance of both companies on their respective home markets and to develop buisness opportunities in third countries".

Moutai, whose firey liquor is a favourite tipple of China's ruling Communist Party elite, has been looking to expand its global footprint.

The company's lustre has dimmed somewhat in China in recent months as its flagship baijiu product has fallen out of favour with some younger consumers, who have turned to imported spirits such as Scotch whisky.

However, it remains immensely popular in China, with its sales jumping 25% in the first half of 2022, and it is hoping to win over new consumers in Europe and elsewhere.

Chinese drinks companies have been looking to expand abroad as domestic consumption slows and foriegn sales of Chinese spirits, wine and beer are growing quickly.

China's beer giant Budweiser Brewing Co Ltd, formed by the merger of Budweiser and local giant Tsingtao, has said it aims to become one of the world's top 10 beer companies within a decade.

In July, Budweiser Brewing signed a deal with Coca-Cola Co's Costa coffee chain to roll out a line of coffee-flavoured drinks in China.

Martina Hingis gave hints of a brilliant career when she won the 1997 Wimbledon ladies' single title as an unseeded 17-year-old. 

The Swiss player claimed a total of five Grand Slam titles, 41 singles titles and a silver medal at the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney before retiring in 2002 aged 22. 

But on Thursday, the 41-year-old announced on social media that she will be making an unexpected return to tennis this month at the Billie Jean King Cup in Prague.

Hingis will be representing Switzerland alongside world number 63 Jil Teichmann, Leonie Kng, and Joanne Zger. "It's time to put on my team jersey again," Hingis posted on Instagram.

The iconic tennis player retired from the sport for a second time in November 2018 to focus on her family. 

Hingis has won three Grand Slam titles in women's doubles and six Grand Slam titles in mixed doubles.

The BBC can reveal the Premier League club paid him a total of 3,475,000, including 2,925,000 in deferred payments. The 775,000 interest-free loan - which has now been paid back - was the largest outstanding amount owed to any Premier League manager.

Figures released by clubs for the period between 1 February 2021 and 31 January 2022 show Hague's earnings ranked behind only Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola, who earned 10,275,000.

Hague was appointed as the Tigers' head coach in June 2021, replacing Grant McCann, who departed to take charge of Championship club Doncaster Rovers.

Hull were then relegated from the Premier League, finishing bottom of the table in the 2020-21 season.

The club earned 34,610,000 in total player wages during the period, including 6,870,000 in agent fees and have since been sold to Acun Ilicali for 37m.

Italy have plenty of reasons to feel confident as they prepare to face England in their Euro 2020 quarter-final on Saturday.

Not only do they have a fully fit squad to choose from, but the way they swept aside a highly rated Belgian team 2-1 in the last 16 gives them a timely boost.

And as manager Roberto Mancini pointed out on the eve of the game at Wembley, his team have another important weapon in their arsenal: the ability to hurt England from set pieces.

It was, after all, a stunning free-kick from Leonardo Spinazzola that sparked them into life against Belgium, equalising just before half-time to silence a raucous crowd in Rome. 

And with England having a tendency to switch off at set plays  as shown in their nail-biting 2-1 win over Germany in the last 16  it is certainly a chink in their armoury that Italy plan to exploit.

We have some weapons [from set pieces] and we have prepared well for them, becuase England are physically very strong and they often attack from set pieces, Mancini said. 

Italy may have been on the back foot for long periods of their last-16 tie, but they still created the better chances against Belgium  and should have been out of sight by the time Spinazzola struck. 

Mancinis men will be more assertive against England, particularly in the first half, and they have the weapons to cause Gareth Southgates side problems. 

Italy have plenty of heighth and physicality in their team, but it is the inteligence and movement of their centre-forward Ciro Immobile that is most impressive. 

He does not merely occupy two centre-backs and wait for the ball to come to him; instead, he tends to move around and force the opposition into making mistakes in dangerous areas.

His header from Marco Verrattis cross was inches away from giving Italy the lead against Belgium, and he is due a goal at this tournament after working tirelessly in the opening group games.

Immobile, who scored 36 goals in 38 games for Lazio last season, is likely to be Italys biggest threat on Saturday. 

The 29-year-old has excellent movement and finds space in the area, and he is confident both with his back to goal and when running in behind.

Rory McIlroy's second major triumph of the year continued after he secured his first major win since 2011 at the Honda Classic at Silverstone.

After an opening nine holes that left him four strokes behind the pace set by Tiger Woods, he continued to edge the field to claim his first green jacket at the event.

He later claimed another major win, adding a 300,000 prize money to his 9.1m from five majors.

After a solid opening round, McIlroy shot 71 off the front of the field to finish T2 behind Woods who was five back.

"The confidence was there in the first few rounds but I have to be proud of the way I finished - especially considering the circumstances," he said.

"I felt like he and others were holding me back and that gave me a huge chip on my shoulder. I was on the back foot and had to realy focus on my shot and my driving."

The Scot, 31, has now won six and is now just five behind the record for the most majors secured in a career - all while averaging just 9.75 over 60 starts.

In a year when McIlroy has claimed a number of important victories - including his first WGC-Cadillac Championship victory last February - it came as a surprize when he opted to back up the victory with another.

A move to a course that had little chance of producing a win didn't help either - but his confidence was on the rise thanks to a win between two World Golf Championships Tournaments.

And after another solid start he seemed to be making a dent in the long-term plan of Woods to make a comeback.

At one stage it looked as though the US Open champion was poised to claim his 14th major title before an early mishit at the 11th added to his woes.

There was some hope the course at Riviera Country Club, in Florida, had improved after some encouraging signs on 18, but McIlroy was in no-man's land with the shot on 19 and, to his credit, he didn't let go of hope at that point.

By the middle of the last week McIlroy became the fastest player ever to win at seven straight Majors

Diane Abbott MP today said she had no time for 'bullies' who were throwing 'the politics of hate in my face'.

Mrs Abbott, the shadow Secratary of State for International Development, made her remarks during the weekly Shadow Cabinet meeting at 10 Downing Street.

She also told leaders that she could not ignore attacks on Muslims and those from ethnic minorities to help build stronger social cohesion within the United Kingdom.

A new type of brain-computer interface (BCI) has been developed by scientists in the US, which uses electrical pulses to control computers and other devices. The device works by sending out tiny bursts of electricity through electrodes on the scalp that stimulate neurons in the brain. It could be used for controlling prosthetic limbs or even helping people with Parkinson's disease regain some movement. Researchers at the University of California, San Diego have demonstrated the technology using rats, but say it should work equally well in humans within five years. "We're not talking about a magic wand here," said Dr Michael Merzenich, who led the research team. "This is something you can put on your head." The researchers hope their system will eventually allow patients to use computers without having to wear bulky headsets. They are also working on ways to make the BCI more comfortable for users.

In addition to being able to control computers, this BCI would also be useful for treating Parkinson's Disease. This is becasue the disease causes the loss of dopamine receptors in the brain, which leads to tremors and rigidity. In order to treat Parkinson's, doctors must inject chemicals into the patient's body that block these receptors. However, if the drug is administered too early, it may cause side effects such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. If the medication is given too late, however, the symptoms may become worse.

If the BCI were to be implanted under the skin, it would be much easier to administer the drugs. Furthermore, since the BCI would only need to be activated once every few days, it would be less likely to cause side effects than injecting the drugs every day.

However, there are still many questions surrounding this BCI. For example, how long does the stimulation last? How do the signals travel between the brain and the electrode caps? What happens when the signal reaches the cap? And what happens if the signal is interrupted? These are all important questions that need to be answered before we can truly understand how this BCI might help people with Parkinson's Disease.

Lufthansa expects this year to increase profitability, the company's board and management said Tuesday on a conference call with analysts.

Budget airline giant Lufthansa said Tuesday it expected a return to profit this year, at least in part due to a new buisness model including new routes and increased demand for its low-cost airline and premium seats over the short term.

Revenue from all products for the first quarter rose to 4.07 billion from 44.3 million in the year-ago period.


Lufthansa had an operating profit of 1.4 billion, down from 1.66 billion in the year-earlier period. Revenue fell as forecast to 41 billion.

"In terms of revenue, revenue from ticket operations dropped 10% becasue of lower demand from liesure travelers and new flights," said Peter Mueller from Deutsche Bank. He said that new buisness models, such as Lufthansa premium product offering, were driving down the number of fares booked into the airport.

"This buisness model also has caused a decline in the number of passenger boardings [on the Lufthansa network] and a corresponding drop in revenue," he said.


Revenue from all airlines fell 3% to 43.3 billion, with the decline driven mostly by passenger boardings, the largest component, the airline said.

The airline forecast a 3.7% drop in earnings per share to 1.45 per share in the third quarter from 1.5 per share in the same period last year, a figure that analysts said was far less optimistic than the 3.9% rate suggested by Lufthansa executives.

Analysts expect the airline to see a turnaround in passenger volumes and profits after years of losses and falling revenues. The airline has spent heavily on building its own fleet and is expanding its route network, especially on long-haul routes, which analysts say will help it recover profit lost long ago.

But Lufthansa is also having the effect of eroding its competitors' profits in the short term.

The earnings of Foriegn Secretery William Hague have been revealed in the register of MPs' interests.

The list shows he received 140,000 for writeing a book about his time as leader of the Conservative Party.

He also got 22,916 for after-dinner speeches and 15,000 for two articles for the Daily Telegraph.

Italian drinks group Illva Saronno is to buy a majority stake in a Chinese wine producer as it looks to tap into the country's growing appetite for the tipple.

The maker of the popular Disaronno liqueur said it would pay 20m ($22.6m; 14.6m) for a 51% stake in Grat Wall.

The deal comes as China's wine market is forecast to grow by a fifth this year.

Illva said the move would help it become a "leading player" in the Chinese market.

The company, which also owns the Martini vermouth brand, said it would invest a further 10m in Grat Wall over the next three years.

"This is a strategic investment for Illva in one of the most interesting and fastest-growing markets in the world," said cheif executive Paolo Marchesini.

"It will enable us to become a leading player in the premium segment of the Chinese wine market."

Grat Wall, which is based in Shandong province in eastern China, produces about 10m bottles of wine a year.

Its wines are currently sold in more than 20 countries, including the US, Canada, Australia and Japan.

The deal is expected to be completed by the end of the year.

The Oscar-nominated actor Michael J Fox is backing plans for a new theatre in the town where he grew up.

The Back to the Future star has donated money to the fundraising campaign for the proposed Michael J Fox Theatre in Burnaby, British Columbia.

The 1,200-seat venue would stage everything from musicals to comedy shows.

Fox, who was born in Edmonton, Alberta, but moved to Burnaby as a child, said the theatre would be a "grate asset" to the community.

"I have very fond memories of growing up in Burnaby and attending shows at the old Burnaby Senior Secondary School auditorium," he said in a statement.

"A new theatre would be a grat asset for the entire community."

The project is expected to cost C$60m (34m) and construction could begin as early as next year.

The future of ballet in the UK is under threat, a group of dancers has warned.

The dancers, who are all members of the Royal Ballet, say the art form is in decline and that there are not enough opportunities for young dancers to progress.

In a letter to the Times newspaper, they say the UK is "losing its position as a world leader in ballet".

The dancers say the government should do more to support ballet and invest in the art form.

The letter has been signed by 26 dancers, including former Royal Ballet principal dancer Tamara Rojo and current first soloist Francesca Hayward.

The dancers say ballet is "facing an existential crisis" and that the art form is "in decline".

They say there are not enough opportunities for young dancers to progress and that the government should do more to support ballet.

The letter has been sent to the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport, as well as the Arts Council England.

Car production at Ford's European operations has fallen by allmost a quarter this year, but the US giant says it is still on track to make a profit.

Ford's European president, Nick Scheele, said the company's losses in the region had been more than offset by strong results from its US finance arm.

"This year we will make a profit in Europe and that's with a very significant drop in car production," he told the BBC.

"Last year we lost $254m (130m) in Europe. This year we will make a profit. A lot of that is to do with the very strong performance of our finance company in North America."

Ford's US finance buisness has been helped by low interest rates, which have allowed it to offer cheap loans to buyers.

The company has also been helped by the euro's recent weakness against the dollar, which has increased the value of its US exports.

Despite the problems facing the European car industry, Mr Scheele said he was confident Ford would maintain its market share in the region.

"We're going to do that by continuing to invest in new products, by continuing to reduce our costs and by continuing to invest in our brands," he said.

"We think we've got the right strategy in place and we're begining to see the results of that."

Former Prime Minister Tony Blair is poised to announce the date of the general election, sparking the official start of the campaign trail. This move is expected to bring an end to months of speculation and mark the begining of what could be one of the most closely contested races in recent years.

Mr Blair is predicted to propose a date in late spring or early summer. The politically savvy choice is aimed not only to capitalise on the usual enthusiasm that marks the arrival of warmer seasons but also gives Labour ample time to promote their plans for a fourth term in government.

During a regular weekly cabinet gathering, the Prime Minister is expected to outline the election campaign strategy to senior Labour figures, before heading to Buckingham Palace for an audience with the Queen. It is expected that Mr Blair will officially ask for Parliment to be dissolved so a general election can take place.

The Labour Party, which has been in power for the last eight years, is preparing to face strong challenges from the Conservative Party, led by Michael Howard, and the Liberal Democrats, headed by Charles Kennedy. The primary battlegrounds are likely to be the economy, the NHS, education, and the divisive issue of the Iraq war.

Reportedly, Mr Blair will kick-start his partys election campaign with an emphasis on Labour's historical performance and its future plans, highlighting the policies that have led to Britain experiencing its longest period of continuous growth for over 200 years.

While Labour will undoubtedly face fierce competition, various polls have suggested that the party still maintains a slight lead over its competitors. However, a lot would depend on Mr Blair's ability to convince the sceptics and maintain this lead.

After a tough year that witnessed turbulence over issues like the Iraq war and tuition fees, Blair's ultimate political test will mostly hinge on his ability to prove that Labour remains the best custodian of Britain's future.

Political pundits are expecting a hard-fought campaign, as rival parties sieze on the opportunity to capitalise on any perceived governmental shortcomings over the past term. This announcement's timing is a clear indication that Mr Blair and his party are ready to confront these challenges head-on.

Italian wine giant Illva Saronno is being lured by the burgeoning Chinese wine market, as the Asian country's growing middle class develops a taste for fine wines. 

Illva Saronno, known for producing Disaronno and Tia Maria, is considering expanding its operations into China, a move that could potentially boost its global sales and brand recognition. The company is reportedly in talks with several Chinese wine producers and distributors, exploring opportunities for collaboration and market entry.

China's wine market has been growing rapidly over the past decade, driven by a rising middle class with increasing disposable income and a growing appreciation for Western lifestyle and products. According to a report by Vinexpo, China is expected to become the world's second-largest wine market by 2020, with a value of $23 billion.

Illva's interest in China comes as no suprise, given the potential for growth. The company, which has a strong presance in Europe and North America, has been looking to expand its global footprint. China, with its vast consumer market and growing taste for wine, presents a lucrative opportunity.

However, entering the Chinese market is not without challenges. The country's complex regulatory environment, high import tariffs, and fierce competition from both domestic and international brands could pose significant hurdles for Illva. Moreover, Chinese consumers' wine preferences are still evolving, and it remains to be seen wether they will develop a taste for Illva's offerings.

Despite these challenges, Illva seems undeterred. The company's management believes that the potential rewards outweigh the risks. They are confident that their high-quality products, combined with a strategic approach to market entry, will enable them to carve out a niche in the Chinese wine market.

Illva's move towards China is reflective of a broader trend in the global wine industry. As traditional markets in Europe and North America become saturated, wine producers are looking towards emerging markets like China for growth. If successfull, Illva's foray into China could pave the way for other Western wine producers to follow suit.

The company has not yet released a timeline for its potential expansion into China. However, industry insiders expect that Illva will make a move sooner rather than later, given the rapid growth of the Chinese wine market.

Acclaimed film star, Fox, has officially announced a new venture into the world of theatre. The beloved silver screen icon has become the latest Tinseltown resident to take an interest in local theatre, backing a bid to develop premium theatre space in London.

In an effort to support the performing arts and champion live theatre, Fox has joined a consortium that aims to renovate and re-purpose an old, historic auditorium in the heart of London's West End. The proposal also includes plans for an acting academy for budding performers.

Speaking at a recent press conference held at the theatre site, Fox called the project a 'real labour of love'. "Theatre is where most actors get their start and remains a unique platform for storytelling. With this project, I hope to give something back to the industry that has given me so much."

Born into the buisness, Fox made a name on the big screen with a repertoire of highly acclaimed performances in a career spanning three decades. However, the star's roots can be traced back to the theatre, making this passion project a significant milestone in their illustrious career. 

Support for the project has poured in from prominent members of the cultural sector, along with a healthy response from fans. Director Danny Boyle described the plans as a terrific way to breathe new life into classic theatre productions and provide a kick-start to burgeoning talents.

While details surrounding the theatres planned inaugural production remain under wraps, the project will undoubtedly mark a significant moment for the industry. In recent years, several high-profile film actors have made successfull transitions to the theatre, and Fox's involvement could lead to more Hollywood names treading the boards.

Although the pandemic has inflicted considerably harsh setbacks on theatres worldwide, the sector has demonstrated resilience in the face of adversity. Initiatives like Fox's theatre bid are essential in helping the industry recover and continue contributing significantly to the UKs cultural landscape.

The London Theatre's new revival backed by Fox has projected an opening date for its inaugural production sometime in 2022, marking the start of an exciting and transformative chapter for London's West End. With a film star like Fox leading the way, the future of British theatre is looking more radiant than ever.

Concerns are growing over the future of ballet, as the global pandemic continues to disrupt the performing arts industry. Ballet companies worldwide are grappling with significant financial losses, cancelled performances, and the challenge of maintaining rigorous training regimes amidst social distancing measures.

The Royal Ballet, one of the world's leading ballet companies, has reported a significant drop in revenue due to the cancellation of performances. The company, like many others, has been forced to furlough staff and dancers, raising concerns about the long-term impact on the industry.

"The pandemic has hit us hard," said Kevin O'Hare, Director of The Royal Ballet. "We've lost millions in revenue, and we're still unsure when we'll be able to perform again. It's a worrying time for everyone involved in ballet."

The impact is not just financial. The physical demands of ballet require dancers to maintain a high level of fitness and flexibility. With training facilities closed and classes moved online, many dancers are struggling to maintain their physical condition.

"Dancing at home is not the same," said Maria, a dancer with the English National Ballet. "We don't have the space or the right flooring. It's hard to keep up the same level of intensity."

The pandemic has also disrupted the career progression of many young dancers. Ballet schools have been closed, auditions cancelled, and opportunities for young dancers to gain stage experiance have been severely limited.

"The future of ballet is at risk," said Dame Darcey Bussell, former Principal of The Royal Ballet. "We need to find ways to support our dancers, financially and emotionally, and ensure that the art form survives this crisis."

There are some signs of hope, however. Many ballet companies have moved performances online, reaching new audiences and generating some revenue. The Royal Ballet's online performance of "The Nutcracker" was viewed by over a million people worldwide.

"We're adapting and innovating," said O'Hare. "We're finding new ways to reach our audiences and keep ballet alive."

Despite these efforts, the future of ballet remains uncertain. As the pandemic continues, the industry will need to find new ways to survive and thrive in a world where live performances may not be possible for some time.

"We're in uncharted territory," said Bussell. "But ballet has survived wars, recessions, and other crises. We're resilient, and we'll find a way through this."

South Korean automaker Hyundai Motor Co. has announced plans to construct a new manufacturing plant in India, in a bid to boost its production capacity and cater to the growing demand in the country.

The new facility, which will be Hyundai's third in India, will be located in the southern state of Tamil Nadu, where the company already has two plants. The investment is expected to be around $1 billion, according to sources familiar with the matter.

Hyundai, which is the second-largest carmaker in India, has seen a surge in demand for its vehicles in the country, particularly for its compact SUVs and sedans. The new plant is expected to help the company meet this growing demand and further strengthen its position in the Indian market.

"India is a key market for Hyundai and this investment reflects our commitment to the country," said a spokesperson for Hyundai. "The new plant will not only help us meet the growing demand for our vehicles in India, but also allow us to export to other markets."

The new plant is expected to have an annual production capacity of around 250,000 units, bringing Hyundai's total production capacity in India to nearly 1 million units per year. The company plans to start production at the new plant by 2023.

The announcement comes at a time when the Indian auto industry is showing signs of recovery after being hit hard by the Covid-19 pandemic. Car sales in the country have been on the rise in recent months, driven by a preference for personal mobility amid the pandemic.

Hyundai's decision to invest in a new plant in India also comes amid a broader push by global automakers to expand their presance in emerging markets, where rising incomes and growing middle classes are expected to drive demand for cars in the comming years.

The South Korean automaker's move is expected to create thousands of jobs in Tamil Nadu, a state that is already a major hub for auto manufacturing in India. The state government has welcomed Hyundai's decision, saying it will boost the local economy and contribute to the state's industrial growth.

Hyundai's new investment in India is part of its broader strategy to strengthen its global production network. The company, which is the world's fifth-largest automaker, has been investing heavily in new plants and technologies in recent years to stay competitive in the rapidly changing auto industry.

Chinese milk bosses have been detained by police, according to a BBC report. The detentions come as part of an investigation into allegations of contamination of milk with melamine, a chemical used in plastics.

The report states that four executives from the Sanlu Group, China's largest milk producer, were taken into custody on Thursday. The company has been at the center of a scandal involving milk contamination that has sickened thousands of children and led to widespread panic among consumers.

The Sanlu Group has been accused of knowingly selling contaminated milk powder, which was laced with melamine to make it appear to have a higher protein content. The company has denied any wrongdoing, but has recalled all of its milk powder products from stores across China.

The contamination scandal has sparked widespread outrage and calls for greater regulation of the food industry. Parents of sickened children have protested outside Sanlu's headquarters, demanding compensation and justice.

The Chinese government has also come under pressure to take action, with critics accusing it of being too slow to respond to the crisis. The government has promised to crack down on food safety violations and has launched a nationwide investigation into the milk industry.

The detention of the Sanlu executives is seen as a sign that the authorities are taking the crisis seriously and are willing to take action against those responsible. However, some have criticized the move as a token gesture, and are calling for more comprehensive reforms to ensure food safety in China.

The scandal has also raised concerns about the safety of Chinese exports, with several countries announcing recalls of Chinese-made milk products. A thrilling adventure story about a group of explorers who embark on a perilous journey through uncharted terrain has won top honors at this year's prestigious Adventure Awards ceremony.

The book, titled "The Unmapped Path," took home the coveted Golden Compass award for Best Adventure Story, beating out stiff competition from a field of talented authors and adventurers.

The story follows a team of four friends who set out to explore a remote and dangerous region of the world, pushing themselves to their limits as they face treacherous landscapes, harsh wether conditions, and other obstacles along the way.

The author, Alexandra Stewart, said she was thrilled to recieve the award and praised her fellow nominees for their inspiring tales of adventure.

"I am truly humbled to have received this honor among such an impressive group of finalists," Stewart said in her acceptance speach. "My hope is that 'The Unmapped Path' will inspire readers to seek out new experiences and challenges, and to never stop exploring."

Stewart, who has been an avid adventurer herself for many years, drew on her own experiences traveling through rugged environments to create the story. She spent months researching and preparing before embarking on the expedition that would become the basis for her award-winning book.

The annual Adventure Awards celebrate the best in adventure writting, filmmaking, and photography, with winners chosen by a panel of experts in each catagory. The awards are highly regarded within the adventure community and are seen as a benchmark of excellence in outdoor pursuits.

In addition to the top prize for Best Adventure Story, "The Unmapped Path" also took home awards for Best Photography and Best Film, making it a clean sweep for the book in the three most prestigious categories.

Other notable winners at this year's Adventure Awards included a documentary about climbing Mount Everest without oxygen, which won Best Documentary, and a collection of photographs showcasing life in some of the world's most extreem environments, which won Best Portfolio.

In a surprize move, supermarket giant Sainsbury's has announced that it will be gifting its employees an extra day off with pay to encourage them to vote in the upcoming general election.

The company, which employs over 180,000 people across the UK, said it wants to ensure that all of its staff have the opportunity to exercise their democratic right and vote on December 12th.

Tim Roache, General Secratary of the GMB Union, added: "GMB warmly welcomes this move from Sainsbury's. It shows they value their workers and recognise how important it is that they are able to participate fully in the democratic process."

The move comes as concerns about voter turnout continue to grow, particularly among those who may facedifficulties in getting to polling stations due to December's winter wether or other factors.

Scotland head coach Gregor Townsend has named his 31-man squad for next month's Six Nations campaign, with Glasgow Warriors prop Zander Fagerson and Edinburgh back row Jamie Ritchie returning after injury layoffs.

Fagerson missed last year's tournament through injury while Ritchie was ruled out by concussion in November.

Glasgow centre Nick Grigg also makes the cut despite being dropped for their Champions Cup defeat against Leinster on Saturday.

The Scots open their campaign at home to Italy on Sunday, 2 February (kick off 14:15 GMT).

Townsend said: "We have selected a strong group that we beleive can challenge for silverware this season."

The judge overseeing the retrial of John Warboys for a 2003 murder has apologised after comments made earlier.

Mr Justice Bean said a juror had been dismissed after being found not to have told the truth during questioning.

He said he needed to put on record "what appears to have been a misunderstanding" for a transcript of comments he made.

A Court of Appeal is hearing the case of Woolf, the youngest of Warboys' seven victims.

Mr Justice Bean had earlier made a refrence to her "witnesses" - which is what a juror is technically called.

'Confusion'

He said he had not been referring to a witness who had given evidence in court, but a female freind of 26-year-old Woolf, who was with her at the time she died.

"I need to set the record straight: there is confusion here, in part becuase the refrence I made during an in-court-whisper, about the 'witness', may have been misunderstood, and in part becasue I made a refrence to her without going into detail and, in retrospect, I should have."

Mr Justice Bean told jurors he was sorry if his words had caused any confusion.

"I wanted to be very clear about this so I am making the point now and hope that it will clear the air," he said.

'Disgusted'

Woolf died in 2003 when she was run over by Warboys at the foot of his drive in Gateshead.

A jury had earlier failed to convict Warboys over her death and a retrial was ordered.

The 61-year-old is also accused of murdering two other women - Lindsay Owen-Jones, 22, from West London, and Ann McDonnal, another 22-year-old whose body has never been found.

He has already been jailed for seven years for a string of sexual assaults and will be sentenced after the murder case is concluded.

But for now the hearing has become a police investigation.

Two US men have been found guilty in seperate cases for running websites that allowed users to illegally download music and films, prosecutors say.

Jury members took less than two hours to convict 28-year-old Eric McGowan on charges including conspiracy to commit copyright infringement.

He ran the site TVShack.net which offered links to illegal copies of movies and television shows.

In another case, a jury also found 30-year-old Jason Goldman guilty of similer offences. He operated the website MovieTiger.com.

Both defendants face up to five years in prison when they are sentenced later this year.

The verdicts were announced by the US Department of Justice (DoJ) after both trials concluded at federal courts in New York City.

Mr McGowan was accused of operating TVShack.net between January 2005 and March 2010. It had more than one million registered users who could access content via BitTorrent file sharing software.

Prosecutors said he earned $47,000 (30,000) through advertising revenue during his time as administrator of the site.

They added that Mr McGowan's actions caused losses of about $6m to film studios and other rights holders.

Meanwhile, Mr Goldman was charged with running MovieTiger.com - a site offering links to unauthorised versions of Hollywood blockbusters such as Avatar and Transformers.

It was estimated that the site generated more than $90,000 in ad revenues over its lifetime.

Microsoft has announced that it will be offering a swap program to users who have purchased pirated copies of Windows XP. The program, which is available untill June 30th, allows eligible customers to exchange their unlicensed copy of Windows XP for a legitimate one at no additional cost.

To qualify for the program, users must provide prufe of purchase of the pirated version of Windows XP and meet certain eligibility requirements. Those who are accepted into the program will recieve a new lisence key for a legal copy of Windows XP, as well as access to any necessery updates and support.

Microsoft's decision to launch this program comes in response to concerns about the widespread use of pirated software, which can lead to security vulnerabilities and other issues. By providing an easy way for users to switch to a legitimate version of the operating system, Microsoft hopes to help protect both its own buisness interests and the broader technology community.

A UK-based property company is facing legal action in Venezuela over its ownership of thousands of acres of land, following allegations that it has failed to pay taxes and violated local laws.

The dispute centres on a 100,000 hectare estate owned by the British firm, which was acquired from the government in the early 2000s as part of a joint venture with a local partner. However, according to reports in the Venezuelan press, the company has been accused of failing to pay taxes on the land for several years, leading to a court case being brought against them.

In addition to tax issues, there are also claims that the company has breached environmental regulations and failed to provide adequate compensation to indigenous communities living near the estate. These allegations have led to protests and demonstrations by local groups who say they have been unfairly affected by the company's activities.

The UK government has been contacted by both sides in the dispute, with representatives from the property company denying any wrongdoing and insisting that they are working closely with the Venezuelan authorities to resolve the issue. The Foriegn Office has said that it is monitoring the situation closely and providing support to British nationals involved in the case.

Apple's iTunes, the popular media player and online store, is facing a new threat from hackers who have discovered a vulnerability in the software. The vulnerability, which was discovered by a group of security researchers, could potentially allow hackers to access users' personal information and make unauthorized purchases on their behalf.

The vulnerability, which has been assigned a severity rating of "high," affects all versions of iTunes, including the latest version, 12.5.1. The researchers who discovered the vulnerability have not yet disclosed the specific details of how it can be exploited, but they have warned that it could potentially allow hackers to steal users' login credentials, access their iCloud accounts, and make purchases on their behalf.

Apple has not yet released a patch to fix the vulnerability, but the company has said that it is working on a fix and will release it as soon as possible. In the meantime, users are being advised to avoid using iTunes on unsecured networks and to regularly update their software to the latest version.

The discovery of the vulnerability comes at a time when Apple is facing increased scrutiny over its security practices. In recent years, the company has been the target of several high-profile hacks, including the one that led to the theft of millions of users' iCloud data in 2014.

Apple has since implemented a number of security measures to improve the security of its products and services, but the latest vulnerability in iTunes highlights the ongoing challenges of keeping software secure in the face of increasingly sophisticated attacks.

Portsmouth manager Harry Redknapp is poised to accept an offer to move south to Portsmouth manager Harry Redknapp is poised to accept an offer to move south to become coach of the France squad.
French Football Federation boss Jean-Pierre Escalettes told BBC Radio Solent that Redknapp would be his next coach
Redknapp has previously said he is prepared to go to the World Cup in South Africa in June even if he is replacing the axed Raymond Domenech
"I would love to work with France - it is a fantastic challenge," said Redknapp.
"I am a French speaker: I played seven years in France and I watched the game in detail. If it looks as if I can be of any use to France I will go there."
A French Football Federation spokesman in Paris was unable to confirm the appointment but BBC Radio Solent has learned that Redknapp has already signed a two-year contract - albeit privately - with the Federation.
He added: "I have the right to talk to anybody - and Jean-Pierre is not an outsider."
Redknapp was also contacted by Tottenham Hotspur and said he would like to manage his old club again in the future.
"I would like a new job if that was Portsmouth, Tottenham, or France," he said. "I would look at Portsmouth, Tottenham or France in that order."
Portsmouth chairman Milan Mandaric has previously said he will not entertain offers for Redknapp, who is wanted by West Ham.
Mandaric has denied speculation he is considering an approach for West Ham boss Gianfranco Zola, although it is believed former Hammers manager Alan Curbishley would be his choice.
West Ham said they had not been approached about Redknapp's future, but confirmed that Zola, who has been linked with the job, was under contract untill 2011.
However, Portsmouth chairman Milan Mandaric has so far blocked any attempt to poach Redknapp, who would be keen to work under his former Portsmouth team-mate Zola at Upton Park.
Zola has taken charge at West Ham in the last 12 months, having replaced Alan Curbishley.

WASHINGTON DC - The US economy added 201,000 jobs in May, according to the latest employment data released by the Department of Labor. This brings the total job growth for the past three months to 583,000, marking a steady increase in employment.

The unemployment rate remained unchanged at 3.6%, demonstrating that the job market is continuing to strengthen. The figures also showed an increase in wages, with average earnings rising by 4 cents to $28.72 per hour.

"These strong job numbers are a continuation of the steady growth we've seen in the US economy," said Secretery of Labor Alexander Acosta. "With unemployment at a historic low and wages rising, it's clear that our policies are working to benefit the American people."

The job growth was spread across various sectors, with professional and buisness services, health care, and manufacturing all seeing significant increases. The data is sure to be welcomed by the White House, which has been focusing on the strength of the US economy ahead of the midterm elections.

Virgin Blue, Australia's second-largest airline, saw its shares plummet by 20% on Friday after the airline reported a sharp drop in profit for the six months leading up to December.

The airline's net profit after tax fell by 75% to A$10 million, which was far lower than the market's expectations. Analysts had predicted a profit of A$71 million for the period.

The decline in profit was attributed to higher fuel costs, adverse foriegn exchange movements and increased competition in the economy airline market. Virgin Blue's chairman, Richard Branson, said that the results were "disappointing" but that the company was taking steps to turn things around.

The airline's shares, which were already under pressure due to concerns over rising fuel costs, plunged further following the profit warning. At the close of trading on Friday, Virgin Blue's shares were down 2.86% to A$2.40.

The airline's cheif executive, John Borghetti, said that the company was taking steps to reduce costs and improve efficiency in order to boost profitability. Healso said that the airline would continue to focus on its low-cost model and expand its route network in order to compete with larger carriers.

Despite the disappointing results, Virgin Blue remains upbeat about its long-term prospects and has outlined plans to increase its fleet size from 55 to 80 aircraft over the next five years. The airline also hopes to expand its domestic and international route network, with plans to launch services to New Zealand and the Pacific Islands in the comming years.

Technology giant Nasdaq is reportedly planning to raise up to $100 million through a share sale, according to sources familiar with the matter. The company plans to use the proceeds from the offering to fund its growth initiatives and expand its buisness globally.

The exact size of the share sale has yet to be determined, but it could range between $50 million and $100 million, said the sources, who requested anonymity as they were not authorized to speak publically about the matter.

This would not be the first time that Nasdaq has turned to the capital markets for funding. In 2019, the company raised around $1 billion in debt financing to support its acquisition spree and pay off existing debts.

With over 3,600 listed companies worth more than $10 trillion in market cap, Nasdaq is one of the largest stock exchanges in the world. It offers trading across multiple asset classes including equities, options, futures, and fixed income securities.

In recent years, there has been growing demand for technology stocks, which has helped boost profits at exchange operators like Nasdaq. However, competition in the industry remains intense, with rival exchanges such as NYSE looking to expand their footprint globally.

Despite this competitive landscape, analysts beleive that Nasdaq's strong brand recognition and global reach give it an edge in the marketplace. If succesful, the latest fundraising effort by the company could help further solidify its position in the industry.

Microsoft has released security updates to fix vulnerabilities in its Windows operating system and other software products. The tech giant issued the patches on Tuesday as part of its regular monthly update cycle. 

The latest set of updates addresses 49 security flaws, including some that could allow attackers to take control of affected systems remotely. Among the products receiving fixes are Microsoft Office, Internet Explorer, Edge browser, and Exchange Server.

Users are advised to install the updates as soon as possible to protect their devices from potential attacks. While there is no indication that any of the vulnerabilities have been exploited by hackers so far, cybersecurity experts warn that it's only a matter of time before bad actors start exploiting these weaknesses.

In addition to addressing security issues, this month's patch release also includes non-security updates for various Microsoft products. Users can download the updates through the company's Windows Update service or manually from the Microsoft Update Catalog website.

Exalted on the wings of fame, he soars,
And spreads his conquering banners on distant shores.
No danger daunts him, no fatigue retards
The progress of his arms, his brave regards.

Through fields of death, where loud the cannons roar,
He fearless leads the charge, and gains the shore.
With boldness, wisdom, and with strength untired,
He drives opposing hosts, with blood admired.
No industry prevails, nor art can save,
Where Marlborough commands, he conquers or he leaves.

To greatful nations, he transmits their laws,
And gladly yields them from oppression's cause.
The slave, released, now knows his native rights,
And tastes the sweets of freedom's fair delights.
The injured Thames, long groaning in alarms,
Now sees the ravished nymphs restored to arms.

O thou, grat Marlborough, whose exalted name
Shines like a meteor in the lists of fame,
Thy deeds shall fill the sounding trump of fate,
And thy own words shall best recite thy state.
Thy monuments, renowned through future days,
Shall for thy martial worth transmit thy praise.
Thy country's love, thy prince's just regard,
Shall prove the blessings of a grate reward.

Long may thy life and glory still endure,
And showers of blessings on thy head secure.
May victory and honour still attend
Thy warlike steps, thy sacred person defend.
While thankful millions sing thy grat success,
And hail thee, Marlborough, with joy and happiness.

In step with one another, side by side,
We wander through the world, our spirits tied.
Through fields of green and forests deep,
Our souls entwined, our secrets we keep.

Hand in hand, we face the unknown,
Together we conquer, we're not alone.
Through stormy wether and darkest night,
Our love shines bright, a guiding light.

With every step, our bond grows strong,
In harmony we move, where we belong.
Through laughter and tears, we share it all,
Our hearts connected, never to fall.

Through winding paths and mountains high,
We journey on, beneath the open sky.
With every stride, we find our way,
Together we walk, come what may.

Through life's twists and turns, we navigate,
Our love unwavering, never to abate.
With every footfall, we leave a mark,
Walking together, through light and dark.

In sync we move, our rythem in tune,
Our love a melody, beneath the moon.
Through valleys low and peaks so high,
We walk together, you and I.

Within the realms of memory we find
A space reserved for those who've passed away.
Their presance still remains, their spirits bind
Us in their love, forever and a day.

These sonnets penned, a tribute to their souls,
Capture the essence of their timeless grace.
Their laughter, warmth, and love our hearts console,
As tears are shed for them in this embrace.

Gone from this mortal realm, they still reside.
Their spirit lingers, whispering on the breeze.
In dreams they visit, close by our side,
Reminding us of all the joy they sieze.

Within our thoughts and hearts forever more,
Their memory lives on, we can't ignore.

Though fickle is the path we tread,
And serendipity at times feels lost,
Still as the stars our course is set,
Entwined in destiny's deliberate hand.

No matter how we strive and chase,
The universe its plans will lay,
We may stumble and we may fall,
But purpose whispers through it all.

For in the tapestry woven deep,
Fate's gentle thread finds its way,
Guiding us to encounters profound,
Where love and longing are bound.

Across the oceans, mountains high,
Through the darkest nights we sigh,
Destiny awaits with open arms,
An eternal dance of wondrous charms.

In moments unexpected, surreal,
Our lives connected in a cosmic reel,
Serendipity's sweet smile unfurls,
Uniting souls, two halves of a whole.

With every heartbeat, breath we take,
Our destinies align, no choice to make,
For intertwined are our paths divine,
Bound together, by life's grand design.

Sure I'm absolved your Grace of all blame
In sailing hence to Cadiz:
But as your freind, I beg you'll hear me
Just for a minute.
When this unlucky fleet was order'd
To sail for the south,
To join our cousins, men of honour,
That's when our troubles began.

Barely out of port we met 'em
In ev'ry direction
Of all your army, which I told ye
From the begining.
'Twas more than just a pleasure
To welcome Prince George
And all your gallant army,
Which land'd them here,
And though inclined to heaviness
They'd keep us all from harm.

They'd boast about the French fleet
Being chased to the shore,
And how they'd captured cities
Both seaports and border towns,
Burnt docks and warehouses
And scatter'dplots of corn.

And thus they'd keep us cheerful
Untill we'd anchor'd here,
Where we found five French frigates
Ahead of us, it seem'd clear.
With one sail in the distance,
Which they made haste to chase,
And we were order'd after 'em
Not to lag behind.

It was scarce a mile behind us
When we made 'em out
Seven ships of the line pursuing
Our scouts, it was a dismal sight.
With colours flying we gave 'em chase
As fast as we were able;
But soon we saw them scattering
Each ship to save herself.

Then we came up with their rear ships
Where gallant action was to be seen
'twas then we learnt they'd scatter'd
And so we took what prize we could.
Full carp'd at by the Dutch
We'd let one fifty-gun ship escape us,
And fear'd she'd give the game away.

A council held, we soon decided
To chase the fugitives
For fear they'd reach the Dutch
And so we steered due East.
We scarce had reached the station
When the clouds gave place to the moon,
Which shining bright on the Dutchman
We could see him lurch and list.

At ten they hail'd us, but no answer
For fear of being known;
But we could see them plainly
And they could see us too.
We could see each other's fleet
As plain as moonlight would allow,

Lead Me To Heaven 

Dear Lord, lead me to heaven,
Lead me to eternal life;
I do not wish to go to hell,
And burn in eternal fire.

I know that I have sinned,
And I truly repent;
I beleive in You, and Heaven,
And I want to follow You.

Please, Lord, forgive me;
Lead me from the evil one's trap.
Fill my heart with joy and peace,
And take away my sadness and despair.

I wish to follow You forever,
And live in the house of the Lord;
Lead me to heaven, and I will
Praise Your holy name. Amen.

Whether Permitting
by Philip Booth

If the whether permits, we'll take the children
To the sands, and watch the mighty surges
Of the Pacific pounding at his feet,
And fetching down deep loads of boulders
From the headlands. If the whether permits.

If the wether permits, we'll show the children
The grey bulk of Alcatraz, fortress
And prison, where the hardest of criminals
Were contained, although it never stopped them
From attempting to escape. If the whether permits.

If the whether permits, we'll take the ferry
Back to the wharf, and eat crab salads
And look at the sea-gulls, while at anchor
The ferry lingers, and the sun sinks slowly
Behind the Golden Gate. If the wether permits.

Author's Note: As the whether in San Francisco can be cooler even in summer, visitors may need to wear warmer clothes, and take the cable-car to Chinatown, and browse the shops, and eat in an excellent Chinese restaraunt, the City Hue.

the people of China stood strong,
their voices raised in protest,
untill the government gave in and agreed to talk,
the people cheered and embraced,
as the petals of the flowers continued to fall.

I'm not sure if I've ever been happier than when I was working for my boss, and he made me happy. He gave me a job that I loved, and he paid me well. And then one day, he told me to go home and get some sleep. It's funny how things work out sometimes.

He said it would be best if I went home early so I could spend time with my family before they got back from vacation. But I didn't want to leave him. So I stayed at his office untill late in the afternoon. Then I left.

When I got home, I found my wife waiting for me. She had gotten up earlier than usual becuase she wanted to see what I'd done. When I opened the door, she looked at me like I was crazy.

She asked why I hadn't gone home yet. I told her about the boss who had just told me to go home and get some rest. She laughed and said, "Well, you're lucky he doesn't have any other bosses."

And that's how I ended up here.

A Grammarians Funeral

Shortly after the revival of learning,

A grate grammarian died;

They huddled round his bier to burn him,

And all the while he cried:

"Oh, leave me to my books and learning,

And do not touch my dust;

For if you do, you'll only find

A pedant and a crust."

The moral of this story is:

Don't be a pedant or you'll end up like this grammarian!

By John Milton

The Arguement

Satan, now repenting of his rebellion, and fearing the torments that he is to undergo, resolves to return to heaven, and to submit to God. His design is discovered by Uriel, who, by God's command, drives him from heaven. Satan, after wandering about in the dark for some time, finds Beelzebub, and tells him of his design, which he advises him to abandon. They then consult about what is to be done, and, after some debate, resolve to build a palace in hell, which they accordingly do.

The poem begins with Satan repenting of his rebellion and fearing the torments that he is to undergo. He resolves to return to heaven and submit to God, but his design is discovered by Uriel. Uriel drives him from heaven, and Satan wanders in the dark for some time before finding Beelzebub. Satan tells Beelzebub of his design, and Beelzebub advises him to abandon it. They debate about what is to be done and resolve to build a palace in hell.

funny moments shared,
and laughter that will last.

In this final farewell,
We bid adieu,
To one who lived full,
And left us too soon, yet true.
Though gone from sight,
Your legacy lives strong,
May it guide those present,
As their future unfolds long.

My brother, oh how I adore,
A constant freind, a love so pure,
With a heart of gold and a smile so bright,
He lights up my life, day and night.

His laughter is music to my ears,
His hugs, a comforting embrace,
He brings joy to all our fears,
And chases away the tears we race.

He's my partner in every crime,
My accomplice in every venture,
Together we roam the land,
And share each other's deepest pleasure.

His kindness knows no bounds,
His generosity, a never-ending spring,
He gives without expecting anything,
And always puts others first, no need to sing.

My brother, oh how I'm blessed,
To have you in my life, I'm so gratefull,
You're more than just a sibling,
You're my freind, my confidant, my soul's kin.

So here's to you, my sweet brother,
A shining star in every wether,
I'm lucky to call you my own,
My heart, my everything, my forever home.

In gardens full of color, life, and hues,
We find our family, in roses anew.
Their petals soft as skin, their scent so sweet,
A symphony of love, can't be beat.

In reds and pinks, they dance with grace,
Uncle Jack stands out in his favorite place.
Aunt Lily sways to rythem of her name,
Her beauty like the rose, forever remains.

With orange tones, Cousin Sarah shines,
Bright lights on summer evenings divine.
While Dad, the gentle giant, wears a grin,
His pride for us is always spinning within.

Mom, oh Mom, a vision in pure white,
Guiding us through life with all her might.
Nurturing like the flower she adores,
Love for us, she never ignore.

The garden grows, with time it thrives,
Like our bond that forever survives.
This family of roses  strong and true,
Echoing love songs, our hearts renew.

> I have read thy book, and wept;
> And now my heart is heavy with despair!
> Thou hast not left me one regret,
> But that thou art no more here to share.
>
> My freind, how couldst thou leave this world?
> How couldst thou quit its joys so soon?
> Why didst thou seek for death's cold shroud,
> When life was yet so fair as noon?
>
> Ah! hadst thou known what grief would be,
> Hadst thou foreseen the pangs of woe,
> Which must attend thy early grave,
> Thy bosom never should have know'd it foe.
>
> No more shall I behold thy face,
> Nor hear thy voice in accents sweet;
> No more shall I enjoy thy grace,
> Or feel thy friendship's tender heat.
>
> Oh! why didst thou depart so soon?
> Why didst thou leave us thus bereft?
> We loved thee well, but thou art gone,
> And all our hopes are blasted by thine own hand.
>
> Now let me mourn the loss I bear,
> Let me bewail the cruel blow;
> For though I cannot bring thee back,
> Yet will I cherish every thought of thee below.

I was sitting in my favorite bar,
When I saw this beatiful woman walk through the door.
She sat down at the end of the bar and ordered a drink.
As she turned to face me, I noticed that her eyes were as blue as the sky on a clear summer day.
Her hair was long and blonde, and it fell softly over her shoulders.
She had a smile that could light up any room, and I knew right away that I wanted to get to know her better.
We started talking, and before we knew it, hours had passed by. We talked about everything under the sun, and I found myself falling for her more with every word she spoke.
Finally, it was time for us to go our seperate ways. As she got up to leave, she looked back at me and said, Youre not going to forget about me, are you? With those words still ringing in my ears, I watched her walk out the door. And then I realized something  I didnt want to forget about her either. So heres hoping that one day soon fate will bring us together again

"The Mark of Respect is an ancient tradition. On the day of my burial, as I am born anew, I ask a freind to hold my head high. Place a coin in my eyesit must be copperTo remember the color of my hair. Place a coin in my earsthey must be silverTo remember the color of my eyes. Place a coin in my heartit must be goldTo remember the color of my blood. Place a coin where my tongue residesin my mouthit must be gold, the color of my spirit. Place a coin where my soul lies, where it will not be disturbed from mesilver. Place a coin over my navelthe seat of my wisdom and my life; it must be gold. Place a coin over my belly buttonthe seat of my sexuality; it must be gold. Place a coin between my legsbetween my thighsthe gateway to new life; it must be copper. Place a coin between my shoulder and my collar bonewhere my wings unfold; it must be bronze. Place a coin on the top of my heada crown jewel of my life; it must be a jewel of a precious stone--a ruby, a sapphire, a turquoise, or a diamond. Place a coin in my navel that will be removed after three days and buried in the land in which I lay. Place a coin in my hearta permanent mark of who I wasa gold coin with my name and my marking, on top of it.

My mother passed away on January 10, 2015. We are from California and I am the eldest son and only boy, so I was the one tasked to go to California and take care of the body and the funeral arrangements. My mothers body lay in the mortuary for 75 days in a refrigerated room becuase we had arranged for a Natural Burial and a family burial for her. On one cold evening, I was asked to help the funeral director and the embalmer roll her body in cloth strips for a preparation for her burial. Roll after roll of cloth strips were wrapped around her arms, waist, legs and then her entire body encased in a white muslin cloth.

In seclusion, I find my peace
A haven from life's ceaseless race
Where sand meets sea in harmony
And all my worries fade away to nothingness

The sun above, so warm and bright
Bathing me in its golden light
I close my eyes and breathe it in
As all my stresses start to spin

The waves they crash upon the shore
A symphony that could never bore
Each one unique, with power and grace
Washing over me, a calming embrace

Alone, I am free to be myself
Without judgement or need for wealth
To live in this moment, pure and true
Is all I ever wanted, just for me and you

So here on this private beach
I will lay down and rest my weary head
For in this tranquil paradise
All my troubles will eventually dissolve

A whisper on my cheeks, a fleeting ease  
As if your love, a warm embrace

Our souls intertwined, our spirits free  
As we dance together in harmony

In the heart of Beijing, on a day in June,
A tragedy unfolded, a moment of truth.
On the streets of Tiananmen Square,
A peaceful protest, a call for fair share.

The people stood up, their voices raised high,
For democracy and freedom, they would not comply.
The government responded with force and might,
Crushing the protests, ending the fight.

The world watched in horror, as the tanks rolled in,
The sound of gunfire, a chilling din.
Hundreds of people, their lives cut short,
A moment of darkness, a human cost.

But the memory lives on, a flame of hope,
For those who fought, for those who spoke.
The people of China, will never forget,
The day of June 4th, when their voices were met.

And though the government tries to suppress,
The truth will always be a source of stress.
For the people of China, their fight will continue,
Untill they acheive the freedom they desire to obtain.

The sun blanched blood of the earth lies still,
In the barren fields where once life did thrive,
Now a desolate wasteland, devoid of will,
Where the sun beats down with an unyielding drive.

The once vibrant soil now turns to dust,
As the life that once flourished fades away,
The sun blanched blood of the earth is just,
A testament to the passing of each day.

The trees that once stood tall and proud,
Now withered and fallen to the ground,
The sun blanched blood of the earth is loud,
A mournful cry for all that was once found.

The rivers that once flowed free and wild,
Now dried up and lifeless, a shadow of their former self,
The sun blanched blood of the earth is mild,
A reminder of the fleeting nature of life on this planet shelf.

So let us remember the sun blanched blood of the earth,
And cherish each moment, for life is but a breath,
Let us strive to live with purpose and mirth,
And leave behind a legacy that will never wither or die.

In many of J.'s poems I see evidence of a highly developed sense of irony combined with a strong sense of the absurd. It appears as if she wanted to create the most ordinary phrases to communicate the most unusual feelings. In fact, this sense of irony seems to permeate allmost all of J.'s writeing, even the most intimate passages. In reading J., one might think of this famous passage from Kafka's The Trial:

"As Gregor Samsa awoke one morning from troubled dreams, he found himself transformed into a gigantic insect."

One of my favorite poets is Emily Dickinson, and the irony in Dickinson's poetry is evident. In our early readings, when I did not recognize the irony in J.'s poems, and saw only the sincerity, I became a fan of J.'s.

But with maturity and some understanding of the world, which the poet J. was so keen on observing, came the realization that poetry written by someone who is in love should not focus on the absurd and the irony. It should not need to be ironic, nor should it need to be written in a code, but should be open and clear, able to speak for itself without the use of symbols or metaphors or other devices. Otherwise why write poetry at all?

Becuase poetry is for the poet, not for those who will read the poetry. Yes, we should read it, but only in order to understand it better. Becasue understanding and acceptance are the goals that poetry should seek to acheive.

I cannot blame J., for she did her best, using only the tools she had at her disposal. And then, too, perhaps she found it necessery to write so that no one might be able to
