Duck Dumplings Recipe:

Ingredients:
- 1 cup cooked duck meat, shredded
- 1 cup all-purpose flour
- 1/4 cup water
- 1/4 cup green onions, finely chopped
- 2 cloves garlic, minced
- 1 tablespoon soy sauce
- 1 tablespoon sesame oil
- 1/2 teaspoon salt
- 1/4 teaspoon black pepper
- Vegetable oil, for frying
- Dipping sauce (optional)

Instructions:

1. In a mixing bowl, combine the shredded duck meat, green onions, garlic, soy sauce, sesame oil, salt, and black pepper. Mix well to combine all the flavors.

2. In a seperate bowl, gradually add water to the all-purpose flour, stirring untill a dough forms. Knead the dough for a few minutes untill it becomes smooth and elastic.

3. Roll out the dough on a lightly floured surface untill it is about 1/8 inch thick. Use a round cookie cutter or a glass to cut out circles from the dough.

4. Place a spoonful of the duck filling in the center of each dough circle. Fold the dough in half, sealing the edges by pressing them together firmly. You can also crimp the edges with a fork for a decorative touch.

5. Heat vegetable oil in a frying pan over medium heat. Carefully place the dumplings in the hot oil, making sure not to overcrowd the pan. Fry the dumplings for about 2-3 minutes on each side, or untill they turn golden brown.

6. Remove the dumplings from the pan and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.

7. Serve the duck dumplings hot with a dipping sauce of your choice, such as soy sauce or a spicy chili sauce.

Enjoy your delicious homemade duck dumplings!

Ingredients:
- 1 lb dried split peas
- 1 large onion, diced
- 2 carrots, diced
- 2 celery stalks, diced
- 4 cloves of garlic, minced
- 2 tbsp olive oil
- 1 fennel bulb, thinly sliced
- 2 cups lobster meat, cooked and chopped
- 1 lemon, juiced
- Salt and pepper to taste
- Fresh parsley, chopped for garnish

Instructions:
1. Rinse the split peas thoroughly and drain them.
2. In a large pot, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the onion, carrots, celery, and garlic. Cook untill the vegetables are tender, about 5 minutes.
3. Add the split peas to the pot and cover with water. Bring the mixture to a boil and then reduce the heat to a simmer. Cook for about 40 minutes or untill the peas are soft and begining to break down.
4. While the soup is simmering, preheat the oven to 400F. Spread the sliced fennel on a baking sheet and drizzle with olive oil. Roast for about 20 minutes or untill the fennel is tender and lightly caramelized.
5. In a bowl, combine the chopped lobster meat with the lemon juice, salt, and pepper. Toss to coat the lobster meat evenly.
6. Once the split peas are cooked, use a blender or immersion blender to puree the soup untill smooth. Alternatively, you can leave some chunks if you prefer.
7. Season the soup with salt and pepper to taste and simmer for another 5 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
8. To serve, ladle the split pea soup into bowls and top with the roasted fennel slices and a spoonful of the lobster salad. Sprinkle with chopped parsley for garnish.
9. Enjoy the split pea soup with roasted fennel and lobster salad hot.

Ingredients:
- 4 chicken thighs, bone-in and skin-on
- Salt and pepper to taste
- 2 tablespoons olive oil
- 1 onion, thinly sliced
- 3 cloves garlic, minced
- 1 cup chicken broth
- 1/2 cup apple cider vinegar
- 2 tablespoons honey
- 1 teaspoon dried thyme
- 1 teaspoon dried rosemary
- 4 cups mixed greens (such as kale, spinach, or Swiss chard), chopped

Instructions:
1. Season the chicken thighs with salt and pepper on both sides.
2. Heat the olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the chicken thighs, skin-side down, and cook untill browned, about 5 minutes. Flip the chicken and cook for an additional 3 minutes. Remove the chicken from the skillet and set aside.
3. In the same skillet, add the sliced onion and minced garlic. Cook untill the onion is softened, about 5 minutes.
4. Add the chicken broth, apple cider vinegar, honey, dried thyme, and dried rosemary to the skillet. Stir to combine.
5. Return the chicken thighs to the skillet, skin-side up. Bring the liquid to a simmer, then reduce the heat to low. Cover the skillet and let the chicken braise for 30 minutes.
6. After 30 minutes, remove the lid and add the chopped greens to the skillet. Stir to combine with the braising liquid. Cover the skillet again and let the chicken and greens cook for an additional 10 minutes, or untill the chicken is cooked through and the greens are wilted.
7. Serve the vinegar-braised chicken with greens hot, spooning some of the braising liquid over the top. Enjoy!

Szechuan Crispy Orange Beef Recipe:

Ingredients:
- 1 lb flank steak, thinly sliced into strips
- 1/2 cup cornstarch
- 1/4 cup vegetable oil
- 4 garlic cloves, minced
- 1 tbsp fresh ginger, minced
- 1 cup orange juice
- 1/4 cup soy sauce
- 1/4 cup rice vinegar
- 2 tbsp brown sugar
- 2 tbsp honey
- 1 tsp sesame oil
- 2 tsp Szechuan chili flakes (adjust to taste)
- 1/2 tsp salt
- 1/4 tsp black pepper
- 1/4 cup green onions, chopped
- 1 tbsp orange zest, for garnish
- Sesame seeds, for garnish
- Steamed rice, for serving

Instructions:
1. In a large bowl, coat the sliced flank steak in cornstarch. Use your hands to toss and make sure each piece is well coated.
2. Heat vegetable oil in a large skillet or wok over medium-high heat. When the oil is hot, carefully add the coated beef slices and fry untill golden brown and crispy. Remove beef from the skillet and set aside on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
3. In the same skillet, reduce the heat to medium and add minced garlic and ginger. Saut for a minute untill fragrant.
4. In a seperate bowl, whisk together orange juice, soy sauce, rice vinegar, brown sugar, honey, sesame oil, Szechuan chili flakes, salt, and black pepper untill well combined.
5. Pour the sauce into the skillet with the garlic and ginger. Bring to a simmer and cook for 2-3 minutes untill the sauce thickens slightly.
6. Add the crispy beef back to the skillet and toss untill it is evenly coated in the sauce. Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes untill the beef is heated through.
7. Garnish with green onions, orange zest, and sesame seeds.
8. Serve the Szechuan Crispy Orange Beef over steamed rice and enjoy!

Title: Fish Broth

Ingredients:
- 1 pound of fish bones and heads (such as snapper, cod, or halibut)
- 1 onion, chopped
- 2 carrots, chopped
- 2 celery stalks, chopped
- 2 cloves of garlic, minced
- 1 bay leaf
- 1 teaspoon of whole black peppercorns
- 1 tablespoon of olive oil
- 8 cups of water
- Salt, to taste
- Fresh parsley, for garnish (optional)

Instructions:

1. Rinse the fish bones and heads under cold water to remove any impurities. Pat them dry with paper towels.

2. In a large pot, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the chopped onion, carrots, celery, and minced garlic. Saut for about 5 minutes, or untill the vegetables are softened.

3. Add the fish bones and heads to the pot, along with the bay leaf and whole black peppercorns. Stir everything together and cook for another 2 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.

4. Pour in the water and bring the mixture to a boil. Once boiling, reduce the heat to low and let the broth simmer uncovered for about 30 minutes. Skim off any foam or impurities that rise to the surface.

5. After 30 minutes, remove the pot from the heat and strain the broth through a fine-mesh sieve or cheesecloth into a clean pot or bowl. Discard the solids.

6. Taste the broth and season with salt to your liking. Remember that you can always add more salt later, so start with a small amount and adjust as needed.

7. If desired, garnish the fish broth with fresh parsley before serving. This adds a pop of color and freshness to the dish.

8. Serve the fish broth hot as a comforting and nourishing soup on its own, or use it as a base for other seafood dishes like chowders or stews.

Note: You can store any leftover fish broth in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days, or freeze it for longer storage.

Ingredients
   3 tablespoons vegetable oil
   1 large shallot, minced
   2 garlic cloves, minced
   4 ounces mushrooms, diced (about 1 cup)
   2 tablespoons rice wine
   2 tablespoons soy sauce
   1 teaspoon sugar
   1/2 teaspoon ground white pepper
   1/4 teaspoon five-spice powder
   2 duck leg quarters, boned, skin removed, and meat shredded (about 1 1/2 cups)
   1 package dumpling wrappers
   1 quart chicken stock

Instructions
   Heat 2 tablespoons of the vegetable oil in a wok or large pan over medium-high heat.
   Stir-fry the shallot and garlic untill golden, about 30 seconds.
   Stir in the mushrooms and cook for about 2 minutes.
   Stir in the rice wine, soy sauce, sugar, white pepper, and five-spice powder.
   Add the duck and stir-fry for about 2 minutes.
   Remove the mixture from the heat and stir in the dumpling wrappers.
   Whisk the chicken stock with 1/4 cup water and pour it into a pot.
   Drop the dumplings into the stock and bring it to a boil.
   Reduce the heat to medium-low, cover, and cook for about 5 minutes.
   Remove the lid and cook for about 2 more minutes, or untill the dumplings are cooked through.
   Serve imediately with the chicken stock.

Overview:
A hearty bowl of split pea soup is the perfect way to warm up on a cold day. We took this classic recipe and added a delicious twist with a flavorful roasted fennel and lobster salad that will wow your guests. This soup is easy to make and perfect for a winter meal.

Ingredients:
1 cup dried split peas, rinsed and picked through
4 cups chicken broth
1 bay leaf
1 teaspoon fresh thyme leaves
1/2 cup chopped onion
1 cup diced roasted fennel (see Note)
1 tablespoon olive oil
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper
1/2 pound lobster meat, chopped
2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice
1 tablespoon chopped fresh parsley

Instructions:
1. In a large saucepan, combine the split peas, chicken broth, bay leaf, and thyme. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat, then reduce the heat to low and simmer, covered, for 30 minutes, or untill the peas are tender.
2. Meanwhile, in a medium skillet, cook the onion in the olive oil over medium heat for 3 minutes, or untill tender. Add the roasted fennel, salt, and pepper, and cook for 3 minutes more, or untill the fennel is tender. Remove from the heat.
3. In a large bowl, combine the cooked onion and fennel with the lobster meat, lemon juice, and parsley.
4. When the peas are tender, discard the bay leaf and puree the soup in a blender or food processor. Serve the soup warm, topped with the lobster and fennel salad.

Note: To make roasted fennel, cut 1 large bulb of fennel into 1/2-inch-thick slices and toss with 1 tablespoon olive oil and 1/8 teaspoon each salt and pepper. Roast in a 400 degrees F oven for 20 minutes, or untill tender and lightly browned.

Ingredients 
1 1/2 pounds bone-in chicken pieces
1/2 cup water
1/3 cup white vinegar
1/3 cup olive oil
1 medium onion, chopped
3 cloves garlic, minced
1/2 teaspoon dried oregano
1/2 teaspoon dried basil
1/2 teaspoon dried parsley
1/2 teaspoon black pepper
1/4 teaspoon salt
4 cups torn fresh kale leaves or baby spinach leaves

Instructions
1. Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
2. In a large bowl, combine water, vinegar, olive oil, onion, garlic, oregano, basil, parsley, black pepper, and salt. Add chicken pieces, and turn to coat. Cover, and refrigerate overnight.
3. Remove chicken from marinade, and reserve marinade. Place chicken, skin side up, in a 9x13 inch baking dish. Pour reserved marinade over chicken.
4. Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 40 minutes, or untill chicken is cooked through and juices run clear. Add kale or spinach to baking dish, and stir untill wilted.
5. Serve chicken and greens together.

Ingredients
2 tablespoons soy sauce
1 tablespoon cornstarch
1 teaspoon grated orange peel
1 pound beef steak strips
 cup all-purpose flour
 cup vegetable oil
 cup chopped green bell pepper
 cup chopped red bell pepper
 cup chopped green onion
Instructions
1. In a small bowl, combine soy sauce, cornstarch and orange peel. Add beef strips, toss to coat and let stand for 10 minutes.
2. In a medium bowl, combine flour and oil. Stir in water untill smooth.
3. Dip beef strips into batter.
4. Heat oil in a wok or large skillet untill very hot. Add beef strips a few at a time and deep-fry for 2 to 3 minutes. Drain on paper towels. Repeat untill all beef strips have been fried.
5. In a clean wok or large skillet, stir-fry peppers and onions for 3 to 4 minutes. Return beef strips to the pan and stir-fry for another 2 minutes.
6. Serve with rice, if desired.

Fish Broth 
Ingredients

1 fish carcass (head and bones)
3 cups water
1/4 cup chopped onion
1/4 cup chopped celery
1/4 cup chopped bell pepper
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon black pepper

Instructions

1. In a large saucepan, combine all ingredients.
2. Bring to a boil over high heat, then reduce heat to low and simmer for 30 minutes.
3. Strain broth through a fine-mesh strainer into a heat-proof container.
4. Discard solids.
5. Use broth imediately, or let cool and store in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

Note: If you want a clearer broth, you can carefully skim off the fat that rises to the top as it simmers.

Ingredients:

 1 lb duck meat, trimmed and finely diced
 2 tsp soy sauce
 1 tsp Chinese wine (or substitute sherry)
 1 tsp cornstarch
 1 tsp sesame oil
 1 tsp grated ginger
 2 green onions, finely chopped
 1 egg
 1 package dumpling wrappers (approximately 50 wrappers)
 1 tbsp olive oil
 1/2 cup chicken broth

Instructions:

1. In a large bowl, combine all ingredients except for dumpling wrappers, olive oil, and chicken broth. Mix well.

2. Take a dumpling wrapper and place a small amount of the filling in the center. Wet the edges of the wrapper with water and fold in half to form a half-moon shape. Press the edges together to seal.

3. In a large pan, bring olive oil to medium heat. Add dumplings in a single layer and cook for 2-3 minutes untill the bottoms are golden brown.

4. Add chicken broth to the pan and cover with a lid. Cook for another 3-4 minutes untill the dumplings are cooked through.

5. Serve with soy sauce and chili oil for dipping.

Here is a recipe for Split Pea Soup with Roasted Fennel and Lobster Salad:

Ingredients:

For the split pea soup:
1 pound split peas, rinsed and picked over
1 medium onion, chopped
2 medium carrots, chopped
2 stalks of celery, chopped
1 garlic clove, minced
1/4 cup olive oil
1/4 cup dry white wine
4 cups chicken or vegetable broth
1/2 teaspoon fresh thyme leaves, chopped
1/2 teaspoon fresh marjoram or oregano, chopped
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper

For the roasted fennel:
2 medium fennel bulbs, trimmed and cut into 1/2-inch-thick slices
1/4 cup olive oil
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper

For the lobster salad:
1 pound cooked lobster meat, chopped
1/4 cup mayonnaise
1 tablespoon lemon juice
1 tablespoon chopped fresh chives
1 tablespoon chopped fresh tarragon
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper

Instructions:
1. To make the split pea soup, in a large pot, combine the split peas, onion, carrots, celery, garlic, olive oil, white wine, broth, thyme, marjoram, salt, and pepper. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat, then reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer untill the peas are very soft and begining to fall apart, about 1 hour.
2. Meanwhile, to make the roasted fennel, preheat the oven to 400F (200C). On a baking sheet, toss the fennel slices with the olive oil, salt, and pepper. Roast untill tender and lightly browned, about 20 minutes.
3. To make the lobster salad, in a medium bowl, combine the lobster meat, mayonnaise, lemon juice, chives, tarragon, salt, and pepper.
4. To serve, ladle the soup into bowls and top with a spoonful of the lobster salad and some roasted fennel. Enjoy!

Ingredients
 8 each bone-in chicken thighs (about 3  pounds)
 Kosher salt and black pepper
 2 cups chicken broth
 2 cups water
  cup white vinegar
 2 tablespoons olive oil
 4 medium garlic cloves, peeled and smashed
 1 large shallot, finely chopped (about  cup)
 Leaves from 3 sprigs fresh thyme, plus 1 sprig
 1 pound mustard greens, washed, dried, and torn into bite-size pieces
  cup heavy cream

Instructions
1. Season the chicken with salt and pepper. In a large bowl, combine the broth, water, vinegar, olive oil, garlic, chopped shallot, and thyme leaves; set aside.
2. In a large Dutch oven or heavy pot, layer the chicken thighs, greens, and thyme sprig, alternating and starting and ending with the greens. Pour the broth mixture over the top and press gently on the greens to submerge them.
3. Bring the mixture to a boil over medium-high heat. Reduce the heat to low, cover the pot, and simmer for about 20-25 minutes, or untill the chicken is cooked through and the greens are wilted.
4. Transfer the chicken and greens to a platter using a slotted spoon. Cover loosely with foil to keep warm.
5. Increase the heat to medium and bring the liquid to a boil. Cook, stirring occasionaly, untill reduced by about half. Stir in the heavy cream and return to a boil. Cook, stirring, for about 2 minutes, or untill thickened. Season to taste with salt and pepper.
6. Pour the sauce over the chicken and greens. Serve.

Ingredients:

- 1 pound beef sirloin, trimmed and sliced against the grain into 1/4-inch-thick slices
- 1/2 cup low-sodium soy sauce
- 1/3 cup packed dark brown sugar
- 1 tablespoon toasted sesame oil
- 1 tablespoon rice vinegar
- 1 tablespoon honey
- 1 teaspoon cornstarch
- 1/2 teaspoon crushed red pepper
- 1/4 teaspoon ground ginger
- 1/4 teaspoon ground white pepper
- 3/4 cup chicken broth
- 2 tablespoons chopped green onion
- 1 tablespoon chopped fresh cilantro
- 1 teaspoon grated orange zest

Instructions:

1. Combine the first 9 ingredients in a medium bowl, stirring with a whisk.
2. Combine beef and soy sauce mixture in a zip-top plastic bag, and marinate in the refrigerator 1 hour, turning bag occasionaly.
3. Place a large nonstick skillet over medium-high heat untill hot. Add half of beef mixture, and stir-fry 1 minute or untill outside surface of beef is no longer pink. (Do not overcook.) Remove from skillet. Repeat procedure with remaining beef mixture.
4. Add broth to skillet, and bring to a boil. Cook untill reduced to 1/4 cup (about 2 minutes).
5. Return beef to skillet; stir to coat.
6. Place beef on a serving platter, and sprinkle with green onions, cilantro, and orange zest.

Ingredients:
1 fish head (about 1 lb/455 g) or fish bones
1 onion, roughly chopped
3 cloves garlic, crushed
2 lemons, 1 sliced and 1 halved
1/3 cup/10 g fresh parsley stems
1 tbsp black peppercorns
1/2 tsp salt

Instructions:
1. In a large saucepan, combine all ingredients with 4 cups/1 liter water and bring to a boil over high heat.
2. Reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer for 20 minutes.
3. Remove from the heat and strain the broth through a fine-mesh strainer.
4. Use the broth imediately, or let it cool completely before storing it in the refrigerator for up to 4 days or in the freezer for up to 3 months.

Note: You can add additional ingredients to the broth, such as carrots, celery, or herbs, to enhance the flavor.

1 1/2 cups almond flour (or other whole-wheat flour)

3 tablespoons coconut oil, melted

1 teaspoon baking powder

1 tablespoon vanilla extract

1 cup powdered sugar

1 egg

1/4 cup coconut milk

1/8 teaspoon salt

Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease and flour two 9 round cake pans. In a large bowl, whisk together the almond flour, coconut oil, baking powder, vanilla extract, and powdered sugar untill well combined. Add in the egg and mix untill just combined. Stir in the coconut milk and salt. Pour batter into prepared pan(s). Bake for 20 minutes or untill toothpick inserted comes out clean. Let cool completely before frosting.

I made these donuts with my KitchenAid stand mixer. I used the dough hook attachment on the machine to knead the dough for about 5 minutes. The dough was very sticky but not too hard to work with. After that, I added the coconut milk and salt and mixed it up again. Then I added the egg and beat it untill smooth. It took me about 3 more minutes to get the dough to come together. Once it did, I rolled it out onto parchment paper and cut it into rounds. I then placed them on a sheet pan lined with waxed paper. I let them sit at room temperature for an hour before frosting.

These are delicious! They were moist and soft and tasted like they had been baked in the oven. I would defiantly make this again.

Ingredients (for 6 servings)

"Carbonara is a tomato-based Italian dish that's a dish made with pasta (usually linguine), but with a topping of cream and lots of green vegetables. It's usually topped with mozzarella cheese.

Ingredients:
1 pound ground duck
1/2 cup chopped onion
1/4 cup chopped celery
1/4 cup chopped green bell pepper
1/4 cup all-purpose flour
1 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon black pepper
1 (10.75 ounce) can condensed cream of chicken soup
1/2 cup water
1 (12 ounce) package frozen mixed vegetables
1 (14.1 ounce) package refrigerated buttermilk biscuits

Instructions:
1. Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
2. In a large bowl, mix together ground duck, onion, celery, green bell pepper, flour, salt, and black pepper.
3. In a small bowl, whisk together cream of chicken soup and water. Pour over duck mixture, and mix well.
4. Stir in frozen mixed vegetables.
5. Grease a 9x13 inch baking dish. Seperate biscuits, and place on top of duck mixture.
6. Bake for 20 minutes, or untill biscuits are golden brown.

Ingredients:

1 lb. dried split peas, soaked overnight

1 large fennel bulb, diced

1 small onion, diced

3 cloves garlic, minced

4 cups chicken or vegetable stock

2 bay leaves

1/2 teaspoon dried thyme

Salt and black pepper to taste

1 (1 lb.) lobster tail, cooked and diced

1/2 cup mayonnaise

1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice

Ground cayenne pepper to taste

1 head Boston lettuce, shredded

1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).

2. In a large pot, combine split peas, fennel, onion, garlic, chicken stock, bay leaves, thyme, salt, and black pepper. Bring to a boil, reduce heat to low, and simmer for 1 1/2 hours, or untill split peas are very soft.

3. Remove from heat, and discard bay leaves. Puree soup in a blender or food processor, and return to pot.

4. In a small bowl, combine lobster, mayonnaise, lemon juice, and cayenne pepper.

5. To serve, ladle soup into individual bowls, and top with lobster salad and shredded lettuce. Sprinkle with chopped parsley.

Ingredients:

1 (3-pound) chicken, cut into 8 pieces

Salt and freshly ground black pepper

1/4 cup all-purpose flour

2 tablespoons olive oil

1 large onion, halved and sliced

1/2 cup chicken broth

1/2 cup white vinegar

1/4 cup honey

1 teaspoon dried thyme

1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper

1/2 pound greens (such as Swiss chard, kale, or collards), tough stems removed, leaves chopped

Directions:

1. Season chicken with salt and pepper. Dredge in flour, shaking off any excess.

2. In a large Dutch oven or other heavy pot, heat oil over medium-high heat. Add chicken and cook untill browned, about 5 minutes per side.

3. Add onion and cook untill softened, about 5 minutes.

4. Add chicken broth, vinegar, honey, thyme, and cayenne, and bring to a boil.

5. Add greens and cook untill wilted, about 5 minutes.

6. Reduce heat to low and simmer, covered, untill chicken is cooked through and sauce is thickened, about 30 minutes.

7. Serve over cooked rice or other grain.

Ingredients:

1 pound beef sirloin, cut into thin strips

1/2 cup all-purpose flour

2 tablespoons cornstarch

1 teaspoon salt

1/2 teaspoon baking soda

1/4 teaspoon black pepper

1/4 cup vegetable oil

1/2 cup orange juice

1/4 cup light soy sauce

1 tablespoon rice vinegar

1 tablespoon sugar

1 tablespoon ketchup

1 tablespoon chili paste with garlic

1 teaspoon grated orange peel

Directions:

1. In a large resealable plastic bag, combine flour, cornstarch, salt, baking soda and pepper. Add beef strips, a few at a time, and shake to coat.

2. In a large skillet or wok, heat oil over medium-high heat. Add beef strips; stir-fry for 3-4 minutes or untill beef is no longer pink. Remove and drain on paper towels.

3. In a small saucepan, combine the orange juice, soy sauce, vinegar, sugar, ketchup, chili paste and orange peel. Bring to a boil.

4. Add beef strips; cook and stir for 2-3 minutes or untill sauce is thickened.

Ingredients:

1 tablespoon olive oil

1 onion, chopped

3 cloves garlic, minced

1 carrot, chopped

1 celery stalk, chopped

1/2 teaspoon dried thyme

1/2 teaspoon dried basil

1/4 teaspoon dried oregano

1/4 teaspoon dried rosemary

1 bay leaf

1/2 cup white wine

4 cups chicken broth

1 (14.5 ounce) can diced tomatos, undrained

1 (8 ounce) can tomato sauce

1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley

1/4 cup chopped fresh basil

1/2 teaspoon salt

1/4 teaspoon black pepper

1 pound cod fillets, cut into 1-inch pieces

1/4 cup all-purpose flour

2 tablespoons olive oil

1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese

Directions:

In a large saucepan, heat 1 tablespoon olive oil over medium heat. Add onion, garlic, carrot, celery, thyme, basil, oregano, rosemary, and bay leaf; cook and stir untill vegetables are tender, about 10 minutes.

Stir in wine, chicken broth, diced tomatos with their juice, tomato sauce, parsley, basil, salt, and black pepper. Bring to a boil; reduce heat to low and simmer for 30 minutes.

Meanwhile, in a shallow bowl, toss cod pieces with flour. In a large skillet, heat 2 tablespoons olive oil over medium-high heat. Add cod; cook and stir untill fish is opaque, about 3 minutes.

Remove bay leaf from soup. Stir in cod and Parmesan cheese. Cook just untill heated through, about 5 minutes.

Ingredients for Duck Dumplings:

For the Filling:
- 1 whole duck
- 1 tablespoon soy sauce
- 1 teaspoon Chinese five-spice powder
- 1 teaspoon sugar 
- 1/4 cup hoisin sauce
- 2 green onions, finely chopped
- 1/2 cup diced water chestnuts
- 1 garlic clove, minced
- 1 tablespoon grated fresh ginger

For the Dumplings:
- 40 dumpling wrappers
- Small bowl of water, for assembling dumplings
- canola oil, for frying

For the Dipping sauce:
- 1/2 cup soy sauce
- 1/4 cup rice vinegar
- 2 teaspoons sesame oil
- 1 teaspoon sugar 
- 1 green onion, chopped

Instructions:

1. Preheat your oven to 350F (175C). Place the duck on a rack in a roasting pan and season with soy sauce, sugar, and Chinese five-spice. Roast the duck in the oven for about 2 hours or untill the internal temperature reaches 165F  (75C).

2. While the duck is roasting, prepare the dipping sauce by whisking together soy sauce, rice vinegar, sesame oil, sugar and chopped green onion in a small bowl. Set aside.

3. When the duck is done, remove it from oven and set aside untill cool enough to handle. Shred the duck meat, discarding the skin and bones.

4. In a large bowl, combine shredded duck meat, hoisin sauce, chopped green onions, diced water chestnuts, minced garlic and grated ginger. Stir untill well combined.

5. Lay out the dumpling wrappers out on a clean work surface. Scoop about 1 tablespoon of the duck mixture onto the center of each wrapper.

6. Dip your finger in the bowl of water and run it around the edge of each dumpling wrapper. Fold the wrapper over the filling to create a semi-circle, and press the edges together to seal.

7. Heat a large pan over medium heat and add a little bit of oil. Add the dumplings in batches, ensuring they dont touch each other, and pan-fry untill the bottoms are golden brown, about 3-4 minutes.

8. Add a few tablespoons of water to the pan, cover and let dumplings steam for another 2 minutes or untill the water has evaporated. Repeat with remaining dumplings.

9. Serve duck dumplings hot with the dipping sauce.

Ingredients for Split Pea Soup:

1. 1 1/2 cups dried split peas
2. 1 tablespoon olive oil
3. 1 white onion, chopped
4. 1 fennel bulb, chopped (fronds set aside)
5. 2 cloves garlic, minced
6. 7 cups vegetable broth
7. Salt and black pepper to taste

Ingredients for Roasted Fennel:
1. 2 fennel bulbs, cut into quarters
2. 2 tablespoons olive oil
3. Salt and pepper to taste

Ingredients for Lobster Salad:
1. 1 lb cooked lobster meat, diced
2. 3 tablespoons mayonnaise
3. 1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice
4. 2 stalks of celery, finely chopped
5. Salt and pepper to taste

Instructions:

1. Start by preheating your oven to 400F (200C) for the roasted fennel.

2. To make the split pea soup, heat oil in a large pot or dutch oven over medium heat.

3. Add the onion, chopped fennel, and garlic. Saut untill softened, about 10 minutes.

4. Add split peas and vegetable broth, bring to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer, untill peas are soft, usually for about one hour.

5. While the soup is simmering, prepare the roasted fennel. Toss fennel quarters in olive oil, salt, and pepper. Spread out on a foil-lined baking sheet and roast for 25-30 minutes untill tender and caramelized.

6. To make the lobster salad, combine the diced lobster, mayonnaise, lemon juice, celery, salt, and pepper - mixing well. Refrigerate untill needed.

7. When the split peas are soft, use an immersion blender to puree the soup untill smooth. Add seasoning as needed.

8. To serve, ladle the soup into bowls, top with a spoonful of lobster salad and a piece of roasted fennel. 

Enjoy this comfort dish packed with exciting flavors and textures!

Ingredients:

- 4 chicken thighs
- 4 chicken drumsticks
- Salt and Pepper to taste
- 3 tablespoons olive oil
- 1 medium onion, finely chopped
- 3 garlic cloves, finely chopped
- 1 tablespoon tomato paste
- 2 tablespoons all-purpose flour
- 1/2 cup red wine vinegar
- 4 cups low-sodium chicken broth
- 1 bay leaf
- 1 bunch of mixed greens (such as kale and collards), ribs and stems removed, leaves cut into bite-size pieces
- Fresh parsley for garnish 

Instructions:

1. Season chicken with salt and pepper. 

2. In a large, heavy pot or Dutch oven, heat the olive oil over medium-high heat. Add chicken, skin side down, and cook untill browned, about 5 minutes on each side. Transfer the chicken to a plate.

3. Reduce heat to medium. Add the onions into the pot and cook, stirring occasionaly, untill golden brown, about 8-10 minutes.

4. Add the garlic and cook for another 2 minutes, stirring continuously to avoid burning. 

5. Add the tomato paste and flour into the pot and stir for about a minute untill a thick paste forms. 

6. Stir in vinegar, then add broth, bay leaf and chicken with any accumulated juices. Bring to a boil, reduce heat, and partially cover. Let it simmer untill chicken is cooked through, about 40-50 minutes.

7. Add mixed greens to pot and cook, stirring, untill wilted, about 5-7 minutes. Season with more salt and pepper, if desired.

8. Garnish with fresh parsley and serve with crusty bread, if you like. Enjoy your Vinegar-Braised Chicken With Greens.

SZECHUAN CRISPY ORANGE BEEF RECIPE

Ingredients:

- 1 pound boneless beef steak, (sirloin or tenderloin), thinly sliced
- 2 oranges, zest and juice
- 1/4 cup soy sauce
- 1/4 cup white vinegar
- 1/4 cup granulated white sugar
- 1 tbsp cornstarch
- 1 tsp Szechuan pepper, crushed
- 2 cloves garlic, minced
- 1 tbsp fresh ginger, minced
- 2 cups vegetable oil for frying
- 1/2 cup cornstarch for dredging
- 1 red bell pepper, thinly sliced
- 4 green onions, sliced
- 1 tsp red pepper flakes (optional for added heat)

Instructions:

1. In a bowl, combine soy sauce, vinegar, sugar, orange juice, and orange zest. Stir untill sugar is completely dissolved.

2. Take half of this mixture and marinate the thinly sliced beef in it for at least one hour, covered in the refrigerator.

3. Mix 1 tbsp cornstarch into the remaining sauce, stir well and set aside.

4. Drain the beef from the marinade and pat dry. Dredge each piece in cornstarch, ensuring each piece is thoroughly coated.

5. Heat the vegetable oil in a wok or deep skillet over high heat. Once hot but not smoking, add the beef slices and fry them untill they are crispy and golden brown. Do not overload the pan, you may need to do this in batches.

6. Remove the crispy beef slices using a slotted spoon and place them on a paper towel to get rid of excess oil.

7. In a seperate pan, saut minced garlic, ginger, and crushed Szechuan pepper for about 1 minute over medium heat or untill fragrant.

8. Add the sliced bell peppers to the pan and stir-fry for a minute.

9. Pour the remainder of the orange sauce into the pan and let it simmer. The sauce should thicken becasue of the cornstarch.

10. Once the sauce is thickened, add the crispy beef, sliced green onions, and red pepper flakes (if using). Toss all these together untill the beef is coated with sauce.

11. Serve your Szechuan Crispy Orange Beef hot with a side of steamed rice or noodles.

Enjoy your spicy, tangy, and crispy Szechuan dish!

Recipe for Fish Broth:

Ingredients:

1. 1 lb fish bones or fish head
2. 2 tablespoons vegetable oil 
3. 2 onions - chopped 
4. 2 carrots - chopped 
5. 2 sticks celery - chopped 
6. 3 cloves garlic - chopped 
7. 1 cup dry white wine 
8. 2 quarts water 
9. 1-2 bay leaves 
10. 1 teaspoon black peppercorns 
11. A bunch of fresh parsley
12. Salt to taste

Instructions:

1. Rinse the fish bones or head under cold water. Make sure to remove any blood, as it can make your broth cloudy.

2. Heat the vegetable oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add in the onions, carrots, celery, and garlic, and saut them for about 3-4 minutes or untill they start to soften.

3. Once the vegetables are soft, add in the fish bones or fish head to the pot and stir well. Allow it to cook with the vegetables for another 3-4 minutes.

4. After the fish and vegetables have cooked together, pour in the white wine and turn up the heat to bring it to a simmer. Let it simmer for about 2-3 minutes to allow the alcohol to evaporate.

5. Then add the fresh water, parsley, black peppercorns, and bay leaves to the pot. Bring the mixture to a boil. 

6. Reduce the heat to low to maintain a gentle simmer. Cover the pot but leave the lid ajar slightly. Let it simmer for about 2.5-3 hours. 

7. Skim off any foam that rises to the surface periodically during the simmering process.

8. After it has simmered, strain your fish broth through a fine mesh strainer into another pot or container. Discard the solids.

9. Taste the broth and add salt, if needed. 

10. Use your homemade fish broth imediately, or let it cool then store it in a sealed container in your refrigerator for up to 1 week, or freeze for up to 6 months. 

This fish broth can be used as the base for many different soup, chowder and stew recipes, or you could simply enjoy it hot with a bit of fresh chopped parsley on top. Enjoy!

Title: Meatloaf for Meatloaf Haters

Introduction:
Are you tired of the same old meatloaf recipes that are heavy, dense, and just plain boring? Do you have a meatloaf hater in your household who refuses to touch the stuff? Fear not, we've got a solution for you! This recipe for Meatloaf for Meatloaf Haters is light, flavorful, and perfect for those who think they don't like meatloaf.

Ingredients:

* 1 lb ground meat (beef, pork, or a combination of the two)
* 1/2 cup breadcrumbs (preferably Panko)
* 1/2 cup grated Parmesan cheese
* 1 egg
* 1/4 cup ketchup
* 1/4 cup water
* 1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce
* 1 tsp dried oregano
* Salt and pepper to taste
* 1/4 cup chopped onion
* 1/4 cup chopped bell pepper
* 1/4 cup chopped mushrooms
* 1/4 cup chopped bacon (optional)

Instructions:

1. Preheat your oven to 375F (190C).
2. In a large mixing bowl, combine the ground meat, breadcrumbs, Parmesan cheese, egg, ketchup, water, Worcestershire sauce, oregano, salt, and pepper. Mix well with your hands or a spoon untill everything is fully incorporated.
3. Add the chopped onion, bell pepper, mushrooms, and bacon (if using) to the meat mixture and mix again untill they are evenly distributed.
4. Transfer the mixture to a loaf pan lined with parchment paper or aluminum foil. Smooth the top and create a small indentation down the center of the loaf to help the meat cook evenly.

Sure! Here's a recipe for Caesar-Roasted Fish:

Ingredients:

* 4 fish fillets (such as cod, halibut, or snapper)
* 2 tablespoons olive oil
* 1/4 cup Caesar dressing
* 1/4 cup lemon juice
* 2 cloves garlic, minced
* 1 teaspoon dried thyme
* Salt and pepper to taste
* Fresh parsley, chopped (optional)

Instructions:

1. Preheat the oven to 400F (200C).
2. Line a baking sheet with aluminum foil or parchment paper.
3. Place the fish fillets on the prepared baking sheet.
4. Drizzle the olive oil over the fish fillets, then brush them evenly with the Caesar dressing.
5. Sprinkle the lemon juice, garlic, and thyme over the top of each fillet. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
6. Roast the fish in the preheated oven for 12-15 minutes per inch of thickness, or untill it reaches an internal temperature of 145F (63C).
7. Remove the fish from the oven and garnish with chopped fresh parsley, if desired.
8. Serve imediately and enjoy!

This recipe is a delicious twist on traditional roasted fish, using Caesar dressing instead of lemon butter or herbs. The creamy, tangy flavor of the dressing pairs perfectly with the rich flavors of the fish, while the lemon juice adds a bright burst of citrus. You can serve this dish with your favorite sides, such as roasted vegetables or quinoa. Enjoy!

Sure! Here's a simple recipe for squash and apple soup:

Ingredients:

* 1 medium-sized butternut squash, peeled and diced into small pieces (about 2 cups)
* 3 apples, cored and chopped into small pieces
* 4 tablespoons unsalted butter or oil
* 2 onions, chopped (about 1 cup)
* 3 cloves garlic, minced
* 2 teaspoons cumin powder
* 1/2 teaspoon nutmeg powder
* Salt and pepper to taste
* Stock (homemade or low-sodium store-bought) as needed
* Freshly squeezed lemon juice (optional)

Instructions:

1. Preheat your oven to 400F (200C). Place the diced squash on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper, drizzle with about 2 tablespoons of butter or oil, and season with salt, pepper, and cumin powder. Roast in the preheated oven untill tender and lightly browned, stirring occassionally, for about 45 minutes.
2. While the squash is roasting, heat another 2 tablespoons of butter or oil over medium heat in a pot. Add the chopped onions, cook untill softened and translucent, about 8-10 minutes. Add the minced garlic and saut for an additional minute.
3. Remove from heat and let cool slightly, then process the roasted squash, onions, garlic, and any accumulated pan drippings into smaller chunks using an immersion blender or transfer them to a blender or food processor. Blend untill smooth.
4. Transfer the mixture back to the pot if you used a blender or food processor and add enough stock to cover all the ingredients. Bring to a simmer over medium heat. Reduce heat to low and Cook untill heated through, 57 minutes. Season with salt, nutmeg, and more cumin to taste

Sure! Here's a recipe for Purple Potato Mash Up:

Ingredients:

* 3-4 large purple potatos, peeled and chopped into 1-inch cubes
* 1/4 cup milk or half-and-half
* 2 tablespoons butter
* 1/2 teaspoon salt
* 1/4 teaspoon black pepper
* 1/4 teaspoon garlic powder
* 1/4 teaspoon paprika
* 1/4 cup grated cheddar cheese (optional)
* Chopped fresh herbs, such as parsley or chives (optional)

Instructions:

1. Place the chopped potatos in a large pot and add enough cold water to cover them. Bring to a boil over high heat, then reduce the heat to medium-low and simmer for 15-20 minutes, or untill the potatos are tender when pierced with a fork.
2. Drain the potatos and return them to the pot. Add the milk, butter, salt, black pepper, garlic powder, and paprika. Mash the potatos with a potato masher or a fork untill they're smooth and creamy.
3. If using, stir in the grated cheddar cheese untill it's fully incorporated.
4. Taste and adjust the seasoning as needed.
5. Serve the mashed potatos hot, garnished with chopped fresh herbs if desired. Enjoy!

Note: You can also add some diced cooked bacon, ham, or sauted onions and bell peppers to the mashed potatos for added flavor and texture. Experiment with different combinations to find your favorite variation of this delicious side dish!

Ingredients:
1 (8 ounce) package lasagna noodles
2 tablespoons olive oil, divided
3 cloves garlic, minced
4 cups sliced fresh mushrooms
1/2 cup chopped onion
1 teaspoon dried basil
1 teaspoon dried oregano
salt and pepper to taste
1 (10 ounce) can diced tomatos with green chile peppers, undrained
1 (6 ounce) jar pimento stuffed olives, drained and coarsely chopped
1 (8 ounce) container sour cream
1 (8 ounce) package shredded Pepper Jack cheese
Directions:
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Bring a large pot of lightly salted water to a boil. Add pasta and cook for 8 to 10 minutes or untill al dente; drain.
Heat 1 tablespoon olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Saute garlic, mushrooms, onions, basil, oregano, salt and pepper untill tender. Stir in tomatos and olives. Simmer about 10 minutes. Remove from heat. In a small bowl combine remaining olive oil and sour cream. Spread half of sauce mixture into bottom of an 9x13 inch baking dish. Top with layer of cooked noodles. Spoon half of sour cream mixture over noodles. Sprinkle with half of cheese. Repeat layers ending with cheese. Bake covered at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 30 minutes. Uncover and bake another 15 minutes.

Ingredients:
1/2 cup butter, divided
4 (6 ounce) pork chops
salt and pepper to taste
3 tablespoons flour
1 onion, chopped
8 ounces mushrooms, sliced
1 teaspoon paprika
1/2 cup sour cream
1/2 cup milk

Directions:
Melt half of the butter in a large skillet over medium heat; season both sides of each chop with salt and pepper, then brown them in the hot butter untill they are no longer pink inside. Remove the chops from the pan, and set aside.

Stir the remaining butter into the same skillet, along with the flour. Cook and stir untill smooth, about 5 minutes. Stir in the onions, mushrooms, and paprika; cook and stir untill the vegetables have softened slightly, about 5 more minutes. Mix in the sour cream and milk, and bring to a simmer. Return the pork chops to the sauce, cover, and reduce heat to low. Simmer untill the meat is tender, about 30 minutes.

Sure! Here's a simple recipe to make Blistered Okra with Dill-Coriander Lebneh.

Ingredients:

* 2 cups okra, washed and chopped into bite-sized pieces
* Olive oil
* Salt and black pepper (to taste)
* Fresh lemon juice (optional)

For the dill-coriander lebneh:

* 1 cup plain yogurt (Greek or Middle Eastern style)
*  cup fresh dill leaves, finely chopped
*  cup coriander leaves, finely chopped
* 1 clove garlic, minced
* 1 tbsp olive oil
* Salt and black pepper (to taste)
* Zest of one lemon (optional)

Instructions:

To make the blistered okra, heat a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add about 2 tablespoons of olive oil and season with salt and black pepper to taste. Once heated through, add in the okra and toss to coat in oil and spices. Cook for 4-5 minutes on each side or untill the okra is tender and slightly charred. Squeeze extra lemon juice on top if desired and serve hot with dill-coriander lebneh on the side.

To make the dill-coriander lebnek, place the yogurt in a strainer set inside a mixing bowl. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate overnight to allow any excess liquid to drain out. In a small blender, combine the chopped herbs, garlic, olive oil, and seasonings to taste. Pour this mixture over the yogurt and stir to combine. You can continue to mix by hand or use the blender to puree untill it reaches your desired consistency. If you prefer a smoother texture, you can also strain off some of the solids using cheesecloth or a muslin cloth. Serve chilled alongside the blistered okra.

Classic Buttermilk Biscuits (Nytimes)

Ingredients:
- 2 cups all-purpose flour
- 1 tablespoon baking powder
- 3/4 teaspoon salt
- 1/2 cup unsalted butter, cold, cut into small cubes
- 3/4 cup buttermilk
- 1 large egg
- 1 tablespoon sugar
- 1 teaspoon baking soda
- 1/4 teaspoon cream of tartar

Instructions:
1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, and salt.
2. Add the cold butter cubes to the dry ingredients and mix with your hands or a pastry cutter untill the mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
3. In a seperate bowl, whisk together the buttermilk, egg, sugar, baking soda, and cream of tartar.
4. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and mix untill just combined.
5. On a lightly floured surface, knead the dough untill it comes together, then roll it out to about 1 inch thickness.
6. Use a biscuit cutter to cut out the biscuits and place them on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.
7. Bake at 425F for 12-15 minutes, or untill the biscuits are golden brown on top and bottom.
8. Serve warm with your favorite toppings, such as honey, butter, or jam. Enjoy!

Poached Pears with Saffron Broth Recipe

Ingredients:
- 4 ripe pears
- 1 cup water
- 1 cup white wine
- 1/4 cup sugar
- 1 cinnamon stick
- 5 whole cloves
- 1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg
- 1/4 teaspoon salt
- 1/4 cup freshly squeezed lemon juice
- 1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley
- 1/4 cup chopped fresh mint
- 1/4 cup chopped fresh dill
- Saffron threads, for garnish

Instructions:

1. In a large saucepan, combine the water, white wine, sugar, cinnamon stick, cloves, nutmeg, and salt. Bring the mixture to a boil over medium-high heat, stirring to dissolve the sugar.
2. Reduce the heat to medium-low and simmer for 10 minutes.
3. Meanwhile, peel, core, and halve the pears. Arrange the pears, cut side up, in a large heatproof dish or baking dish.
4. Pour the hot broth over the pears, making sure they are completely submerged. Cover the dish with aluminum foil and let it sit at room temperature for at least 2 hours, or refrigerate overnight.
5. To serve, remove the pears from the broth with a slotted spoon and drain well. Arrange the pears on a serving platter and pour the broth over them.
6. Garnish with fresh parsley, mint, and dill. Sprinkle saffron threads over the top for added color and flavor.
7. Serve imediately and enjoy your delicious Poached Pears with Saffron Broth!

Asparagus Sheaves Kambu Recipe

Ingredients:

* 1 pound asparagus, trimmed and cut into 1-inch pieces
* 1/2 cup kambu (Japanese dried seaweed)
* 4 cups water
* 1 tablespoon soy sauce
* 1 tablespoon mirin
* 1 tablespoon sugar
* 1 teaspoon grated ginger
* 2 cloves garlic, minced
* 1/4 cup chopped green onions
* Salt and pepper to taste

Instructions:

1. In a large pot, bring the water to a boil. Add the kambu and let it soak for 5 minutes.
2. Add the asparagus to the pot and cook for 5-7 minutes, or untill tender.
3. In a small bowl, whisk together the soy sauce, mirin, sugar, ginger, and garlic.
4. Pour the sauce over the asparagus and kambu and stir to coat.
5. Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes, or untill the sauce has thickened.
6. Remove the pot from the heat and stir in the chopped green onions.
7. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
8. Serve hot and enjoy!

Breaded Redfish with Shrimp, Fennel, and Orange Salad Recipe

Ingredients:

For the breaded redfish:
- 4 redfish fillets
- 1 cup breadcrumbs
- 1 tsp paprika
- 1 tsp garlic powder
- Salt and pepper to taste
- 2 eggs, beaten
- 1 cup panko breadcrumbs
- Vegetable oil for frying

For the shrimp, fennel, and orange salad:
- 1 lb large shrimp, peeled and deveined
- 1 small fennel bulb, thinly sliced
- 1 navel orange, peeled and segmented
- 1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley
- 2 tbsp olive oil
- 2 tbsp lemon juice
- Salt and pepper to taste

Instructions:

1. Preheat your oven to 375F.

2. For the breaded redfish, start by seasoning both sides of the redfish fillets with salt, pepper, paprika, and garlic powder.

3. In a shallow dish, beat the eggs. In another shallow dish, mix the breadcrumbs and panko breadcrumbs together.

4. Dip each fillet first in the egg mixture, then in the breadcrumb mixture, making sure to coat evenly on both sides.

5. Heat a skillet with vegetable oil over medium-high heat. Once the oil is hot, add the breaded fillets and fry untill golden brown, about 3-4 minutes per side.

6. Once the fillets are cooked, transfer them to a baking dish and bake in the oven for an additional 10-12 minutes, or untill the fish is cooked through.

7. For the shrimp, fennel, and orange salad, heat a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the shrimp and cook untill pink and curled, about 2-3 minutes per side.

8. In a large bowl, combine the sliced fennel, orange segments, and chopped parsley.

9. In a small bowl, whisk together the olive oil and lemon juice to make the dressing.

10. Pour the dressing over the fennel mixture and toss to combine.

11. Serve the breaded redfish with the shrimp, fennel,

I've been playing Tinker for a while now and one thing I've noticed is that my item timing is not as good as it could be. I often find myself struggling to get my core items at the right time, which can realy impact my effectiveness in team fights and split pushing. 

After doing some research and experimenting, I've found a few tips that have helped me improve my item timing with Tinker. 

Firstly, it's important to prioritize farming efficiency. Tinker is a hero that relies heavily on gold and experiance, so you need to make sure you're maximizing your farm. This means constantly pushing out waves and stacking camps whenever possible. 

Secondly, you should try to minimize downtime. Tinker is a hero that can be very active on the map, so you want to make sure you're constantly doing something. This could be split pushing, ganking, or farming jungle camps. The key is to always be doing something productive. 

Thirdly, you should consider adjusting your skill build. Tinker has a lot of flexibility when it comes to his skill build, so you should tailor it to the game you're playing. For example, if you're against a lot of magic damage, you might want to prioritize leveling up your March of the Machines for better wave clear and farming potential. 

Lastly, communication with your team is key. Let them know when you're close to a key item and coordinate with them to make the most out of it. Tinker is a hero that can have a huge impact in team fights, so it's important to make sure your team is ready to fight when you have your core items. 

Overall, achieving better item timing with Tinker requires a combination of efficient farming, constant activity, adjusting your skill build, and good communication with your team. By following these tips, you should be able to improve your item timing and have a bigger impact on the game.

I've been experimenting with different laning combos lately and I've found one that has been working realy well for me. The combo consists of playing a tanky support like Leona or Nautilus paired with a high burst ADC like Jhin or Miss Fortune. 

The idea behind this combo is to have the tanky support engage on the enemy ADC or support, while the burst ADC follows up with their high damage abilities. This creates a lot of pressure in the laning phase and can often result in kills or at least force the enemy to back off and play more defensively.

The tanky support provides a lot of crowd control and durability, allowing the ADC to freely deal damage without worrying too much about getting cauhgt out. Additionally, the burst damage from the ADC can quickly burst down squishy targets, making it difficult for the enemy to trade effectively.

I've found that this combo works particularly well against squishy supports like Janna or Soraka, as they are more vulnerable to the engage and burst damage. However, it can still be effective against tanky supports as well, as the burst damage can quickly whittle down their health.

Overall, I've been having a lot of success with this laning combo and I would highly reccommend giving it a try if you're looking for a strong and agressive laning phase. It's important to communicate and coordinate with your ADC to ensure that you're on the same page and can effectively engage and follow up on each other's abilities. Give it a shot and let me know how it works for you!

I mean seriously, why do we have a whole catagory for mil-sim? It's not like there are a lot of mainstream games that have military involvement. Shouldn't it be a subset of the action genre? RPG? Strategy? Something? It's always one of the first categories I eliminate when searching for a game, becuase 99% of it is just mediocre. With the tiny minority of excellent games that deserve to be playing, it feels like a clutter catagory that does more harm than good.

I guess what I'm asking is, should I be eliminating the "mil-sim" catagory games altogether, or is that genre simply not for me? I'm mostly a PC gamer, dabbling with consoles, though I am open to suggestions for any platform.

I've tried ARMA and a few other similer games, and they seem cool, but hard to get into after spending most of my time in more traditional gaming genres. Any recommendations would be welcome.

I did try searching, but most threads on the topic seem to be complaints about lack of mil-sim AAWWWWWWHHHYYYYYY!!!!11 and Sturgeon's law concerning the low quality meme games cluttering the catagory, with few actual useful opinions.

Edit: Thanks for the suggestions guys. Apparently the genre has enough good games to warrant its own catagory, who'd have thought. I'll definatly look into these further, and I think I'll remove the "shooter" catagory from my search criteria as well (though arena shooters are still okay, since I do like the occasional rocket jumping session)

Edit 2: I should probably clarify that by "military sim" I mean games that strive for realism, wether in terms of gameplay, physics, or whatever makes the game fall into that catagory. I don't necessarily mean games with "sim" in the title (though that's what I'm most familiar with), and I'm not talking about shooter games with tanks and planes. I'm a grad student and I need to take a particular class that's only offered in the fall semester. I feel like the dean is the next person to go to in this chain, but I'm not sure who to email - the graduate admissions dean, the undergraduate admissions dean, the school dean? Some thoughts which pop up in my mind are distinctly under my control. I could just let them be, or I could think more about them, or pursue theme.g. if I think about an interesting topic, I could choose to investigate it further. Then there are out-of-the-blue thoughts that just appear in my mind, and arguably I have no control over them. It would be absurd to try to will myself to stop thinking about them. They just appear, and I can choose to entertain them or let them go, but it feels as though the initiative is not mine.

Which catagory do volitional thoughts belong to? It seems like they should belong to the first catagory, but maybe not? What determines wether a thought is under my control? Surely it's not sufficient to just feel as though I had control, becuase it seems some involuntary thoughts feel involuntary, even though I could make myself think about them if I so chose. But perhaps more importantly, it seems like some thoughts which feel voluntary are actually involuntary. For example, if I have an irrational fear of something, it feels voluntary to think about it, but it seems it would actually be irrational (and impractical) to try to will myself to stop thinking about it. It seems like willingness to have a particular thought is not the same thing as volition, yet it feels like it ought to be.

Maybe a more charitable way of putting it is that it seems like willingness to have a particular concious experiance is not the same thing as voluntariness. Thoughts just seem to appear in my mind, and I can choose to act on them or not, but it doesn't seem as though I caused them, even if it feels that way, and even if in reality I could have prevented them, since it feels as though they just happen. Conversely, other thoughts feel as though I caused them, but it seems as though what matters is not wether the thought appeared becasue I willed it, but rather wether I could have prevented it. Perhaps it doesn't matter wether a thought is caused by my will, but rather wether I could have prevented the thought, in which case all thoughts are involuntary.

I have had a very difficult time in my life from the day I was born and I struggle with many internal flaws that I need to deal with. As a result of that, I suffer from terrible anxiety and depression, and I am constantly second-guessing everything I do or say, predicting the future outcomes of all possible interactions I could have with others becasue I can't read tones well and I misread facial expressions a lot, and I am always left feeling like I've disappointed someone, even when that's not the case. 

I am in my 30s and I still live with my mom becasue I have never been able to hold a job for more than a few months becuase of my anxiety and depression, which causes me to either quit or be fired. I have been able to keep a few jobs for a few months here and there, but they always end the same way and I am worthless and a burden on everyone, especially my mom who has to pay for everything. She has helped me as much as she can but she has her own issues to deal with and it's not fair for me to keep taking from her when I am perfectly capable of working. She has helped me get jobs before but my anxiety always gets the better of me and I can't do it. 

I am constantly fighting with myself to try and be better but I always end up in the same place: worthless, pathetic, and a burden on everyone around me. I am a failure as a person and I deserve to suffer for what I've done. I am a terrible person and I deserve to be punished for the things I have done. I am not worth the air I breathe and I am a danger to society. My brain is poison and getting rid of me would serve everyone, especially the universe, becasue the last thing it needs is another abomination like me lurking around, pretending that I deserve to be here when I so clearly do not. The world would be a better place without me in it.

Dear Sjgren

There's actually a process to making a liquid extract using yeast to boost its flavor without affecting the rest of the recipe. But before we do anything crazy, let's take a look at our options first.

It's true that we know what makes "good" beer -- lager yeast. Lactobacillus produces esters, which are responsible for giving the beer character that gives it its flavor characteristic. These particular esters include things like caramelly honey and woodiness while dextrins give lagers their dryness...but they're pretty bland-ish in the big picture of why beer tastes good. That's where the hops come in. What differentiating factors in beer have been attributed to different hop varieties is complicated; many brewers cite varieties and use them interchangeably when describing their beer style. What is easy to think about at the bar doesn't always end up making sense with regard to brewing techniques. There's an arguement to be made though, that trying harder to obtain those higher flavors will result in better tasting beer with longer shelf life. If it's worth an extra 10 gallons of space and additional money to buy a high quality German pilsner, you'll probably drink less once you sell it or find someplace else. A simple example of this would be malt bill balance: if you want bitter hops added earlier on in the grain bill (not too late), the brewer probably won't need to add very much -- perhaps no more than 0.005 oz per pound of hops depending on how old it is. This may seem silly

Today was the first day of my mom's "freind club" and they went around town and talked to as many people as she could, talking about things they saw in the news today and about what they had talked about in the past, getting out their "facts". She didn't even let a single one of us go by and just talked to us as though we were "her family" as if we were on a first name basis with her. When I was about 9 years old, I would talk and argue with her about something and try and make myself heard. Sometimes I'd get frustrated and talk back a little, but her response to that was not to talk to me and let her know I was "talking to myself". It took me a while to realize that she would talk to other kids from her class, her parents' friends, her "freind" at school...

I've been talking to my mom about feminism and about equal rights since I was a toddler. I started with talking about how I was taught that girls had to sit on the boys' laps, that boys had to sit on the girls' laps. My dad taught me that if girls were taught to play with boys, they couldn't play with girls. And my uncle talked about how you were better off being your own person if you were born male. And finally I was taught that being female meant that I couldn't play with boys as I thought was right. And so I started to question some of the things I was taught growing up. I've now gotten up to middle school and I see the importance of showing girls that they can be anything just like our moms show us boys. Girls and boys can play in the same way. They can wear the same clothes. They don't have to be pink and cutesy and have to be dressed to impress people. We aren't there just to be boys or girls. And to some degree, my mom has been following in that tradition, but in a much different way, and that's a good thing.

Her recent posts are quite emotional so I hope I don't come across as bullying. But, I do think her friends need to be confronted to the fact that this isn't "being her family". I think their message needs to be loud and clear: Your mother is not your family if she is not your equal. If

Understanding and optimizing item timings with Tinker can dramatically improve your gameplay. Here are some tips you can utilize:

1. **Prioritize Boots of Travel (BoT):** Your first priority should always be saving for Boots of Travel. This item is crucial to Tinker's playstyle as it allows you to travel around the map, pushing lanes, and teleporting back to your base when needed.

2. **Farming Patterns:** Tinker is all about farming efficiently. Using March of the Machines, you can continually clear out waves of creeps. When farming the jungle, move strategically between camps to use March of the Machines to best effect.

3. **Stacking Neutral Creeps:** While farming waves with March, try to stack neutral camps whenever possible, this will allow for maximizing your gold and experiance gain.

4. **Bottle and Soul Ring:** These two items should be your next priority after BoTs. They give you the ability to stay on the map longer due to sustainability in health and mana.

5. **Blink Dagger Timing:** Blink Dagger is another high priority item. Try to get it before the 20-minute mark. It offers a grat deal of mobility and can save you from many sticky situations.

6. **Scythe of Vyse and Dagon:** These are your luxury items. The former is grate for control and adding an extra layer of disable in team fights, whereas the latter will let you burst down enemies quickly. Their timings largely depend on how well you have farmed.

Remember that both your individual skill level and the state of your specific game can effect this schedule. Being adaptable is crucial in Dota 2, so be prepared to adjust your playstyle and item build based on the needs of your team and the nature of the enemy team. In general, ensure you maximize farming, manage your mana well and aim for minimum deaths. Good luck!

I've been playing a lot of duo que recently and stumbled upon a laning combo that has been surprisingly effective. I've been playing as Thresh and my duo partner has been playing as Lucian. 

Thresh's crowd control abilities combined with Lucian's high burst damage has been a deadly combination. I start the engage with Thresh's Q (Death Sentence) to pull in an enemy, followed by his E (Flay) to knock them towards Lucian. Lucian then uses his Q (Piercing Light) and his passive (Lightslinger) to quickly burst down the enemy. If they're not dead by then, Thresh's R (The Box) can be used to slow them down and allow Lucian to finish them off.

This combo has been working realy well for us in the bot lane. We've been able to secure early kills and snowball our lead into the mid and late game. It's also a lot of fun to play!

I'd love to hear about any other laning combos that you guys have found to be effective. Let's share and learn from each other!

I've been reading a lot about the Bernese Method of switching from a full agonist opioid (like heroin or fent) to a partial agonist opioid (like Suboxone). The general idea is to slowly introduce the Suboxone while still using your drug of choice, thus avoiding the excruciatingly uncomfortable process of withdrawal. This differs greatly from the traditional method of waiting untill you are in withdrawal before begining to use Suboxone.

However, my primary concern with this method is the prolonged exposure to the full agonist opioid which maintains the addictive behavior and potentially damaging lifestyle. I wonder if anyone has attempted a Bernese Method followed by a quick (or quicker than normal) taper off of the Suboxone? I'm thinking this may provide the benefits of both techniques (avoiding acute withdrawal and lessening the amount of time on Suboxone), but I'm having trouble finding any first-hand accounts of such an approach. I'm particularly interested in hearing about the experiance, difficulty, and effectiveness of this method, so if you have any insight or personal stories, your contribution would be highly appreciated. 

Also, I would like to note that it's incredibly important to consult with a healthcare professional before attempting something like this, for anyone reading this post who might be considering it, please ensure you're receiving monitoring and support from professionals. This is a harm reduction thread, and we want to promote safe and healthy discussion. Thanks in advance for any responses!

I've been thinking about this for a while now and I beleive that wearing a full set of leather armor should improve your sneakiness in the game. 

Leather armor is often associated with thieves, rogues, and assassins in fantasy settings due to its lightweight and quiet nature. It doesn't clank and clang like metal armor, making it ideal for those who rely on stealth and subtlety. 

In the game, this could translate to a slight boost in sneakiness or stealth when wearing a full set of leather armor. This could be a small percentage increase in your ability to remain undetected, or perhaps it could reduce the noise you make when moving. 

This would not only add a layer of realism to the game, but it would also give players more strategic options when planning their character's build and playstyle. It would make the choice of armor more than just about defense stats, but also about how it can complement your chosen skills and tactics.

What do you guys think? Would this be a good addition to the game? Or do you think it would unbalance things? I'd love to hear your thoughts.

I'm frustrated with my HR department. I recently applied for a promotion within my company, and after going through the interview process, I was told that I would be receiving a job offer soon. However, when I followed up with HR to ask about the status of my application, they informed me that they couldn't provide me with a salary range for the position.

I found this strange, as it's common practice in our industry to share salary ranges during the hiring process so that candidates have an idea of what to expect. When I pressed them further, they claimed that they couldn't give me a range becasue "it varies based on experiance" - which is a pretty vague reason if you ask me.

What's even more annoying is that they seemed to take offense to my questioning. They started getting defensive and dismissive, telling me that they were "doing their best" and that I should just wait patiently for the offer letter. It felt like they were trying to make me feel silly for asking such a basic question.

Has anyone else had similer experiences with their HR department? Am I overreacting here? I understand that delays can happen, but the lack of transparency and condescending attitude from HR has left a bad taste in my mouth.

Thanks in advance for your inputs!

Hey fellow Redditors,

I know a lot of people think the Batman prep time arguement is silly or overdone, but I'm here to argue that it's actually a good thing.

First of all, let's aknowledge that Batman is a highly skilled and experienced crimefighter. He's been doing this for years, and he's had his fair share of victories and defeats. He knows what works and what doesn't, and he's constantly adapting his strategies to stay one step ahead of his enemies.

Now, when it comes to prep time, Batman is meticulous. He plans every detail, from the weapons he brings to the gadgets he uses to the routes he takes. He's not just winging it, hoping for the best. He's a tactician, and he knows that every second counts.

But here's the thing: Batman's prep time isn't just about him. It's about his allies, too. When he's preparing for a mission, he's not just thinking about his own safety and success - he's thinking about the safety and success of his team. He's making sure they have the right gear, the right training, and the right strategy to take down the bad guys.

And let's not forget, Batman's not just fighting crime for the sake of it. He's fighting for justice, for what's right. He's fighting to protect the innocent and vulnerable from those who would harm them. By taking the time to prepare, he's not just saving his own skin - he's saving countless lives.

So the next time someone says the Batman prep time arguement is silly, just remember: it's not just about Batman. It's about his dedication to justice, his commitment to his allies, and his unwavering determination to protect the people of Gotham.

Thanks for reading, fellow Redditors. Let me know what you think!

So I've been dating my boyfriend for about three years now, and he has always been very liberal when it comes to politics. He is active on Twitter and often shares articles promoting progressive causes. He was even involved with some local community organizations that dealt with social issues like poverty and mental health.

But recently, things have taken an interesting turn. My boyfriend started posting some articles from more conservative sources that challenge our shared values. At first, it didn't bother me too much - after all, everyone's entitled to their own opinions. But then he kept doing this, day after day, untill he basically said he is now pro-Trump. To say I was shocked would be putting it mildly.

I tried talking to him about it calmly but failed to convince him otherwise. In fact, he started getting defensive if anyone tries to argue with his new beliefs. It feels strange becasue I used to know someone who had a lot of empathy and concern for social justice issues, but now he seems more focused on fiscal responsibility and small government intervention.

This isn't just affecting us - his friends are also surprised by these changes, as they knew him better before he turned into this version of himself. His family is worried since they don't see eye to eye with his political beliefs either. It just shows how far apart we both feel about certain topics, which only adds tension to our already busy lives.

So yeah, any advice or insights you can offer will be greatly appreciated as I navigate through this awkward situation.

Becomeing an auntie means taking on a new role in the lives of your siblings' children. It can be challenging, but it is also incredibly rewarding. There are so many amazing moments that come with being an auntie:

1. Watching them grow and learn new things
2. Sharing your wisdom and experiences with them
3. Teaching them valuable life lessons
4. Having fun and spending quality time together
5. Seeing their facial expressions when you give them something they love, wether it be candy or a toy
6. Hearing about all their milestones, from first steps to graduation
7. Helping out whenever they need someone to watch over them or talk to them
8. Shaping them into better adults by providing guidence and discipline
9. Becomeing like a second parent for some (which can help relieve the workload from the primary caregivers)

Overall, becomeing an auntie comes with its own unique set of challenges and responsibilities, but it is also one of the most fulfilling roles to have. It gives me grate joy to see my family thrive, and I enjoy doing everything in my power to make sure they do!

Hey there! Congratulations on planning your first ever campaign! It's an exciting journey you're about to embark on. To help you get started, here are some tips:

1. Define your goals: What do you want to acheive with your campaign? Increased brand awareness, more sales, more website traffic? Knowing your goals will help you create a plan that aligns with your objectives.

2. Know your audience: Who is your target customer? Understanding their needs, preferences, and behavior will help you tailor your campaign messages and channels to reach them effectively.

3. Pick the right channels: With so many marketing channels available, it can be overwhelming to choose. Consider where your audience spends their time and select the channels that align with their preferences.

4. Create a content plan: Content is the backbone of any campaign. Plan out the content you'll create, wether it's blog posts, social media updates, emails or videos. Ensure the content aligns with your goals and resonates with your audience.

5. Set a budget: Decide on how much you're willing to spend on your campaign. This will help you decide which channels to focus on and how much content you can create.

6. Track and measure results: Don't forget to track your campaign's success. Use analytics tools to monitor progress and make data-driven decisions to improve the campaign's performance.

Remember, planning a campaign takes time and effort, but with these tips and a well-defined strategy, you'll be well on your way to a sucessful campaign! Good luck!
