"The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" is a dark and intense thriller that will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. Based on the best-selling novel by Stieg Larsson, this film adaptation does justice to the intricate and gripping story.

The standout performance in this film is undoubtedly Rooney Mara as Lisbeth Salander. She fully embodies the complex and enigmatic character, delivering a performance that is both vulnerable and fierce. Mara's portrayal is truly captivating, and she brings a level of intensity and depth to the role that is exceptional.

Daniel Craig also delivers a strong performance as journalist Mikael Blomkvist. He portrays the character with a perfect balance of determination and vulnerability, making him relatable and likable. The chemistry between Mara and Craig is undeniable, and their scenes together are electrifying.

Director David Fincher does a remarkable job of capturing the dark and gritty atmosphere of the story. The cinematography is stunning, and the use of lighting and colors adds to the overall mood of the film. The pacing is perfect, keeping the audience engaged and invested in the story without any dull moments.

One of the most impressive aspects of "The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" is its intricate plot. The story is filled with twists and turns that constantly keep you guessing. The mystery unfolds gradually, unraveling the dark secrets and hidden agendas of the characters. The tension builds steadily, culminating in a shocking and satisfying conclusion.

The film also tackles sensitive and important themes, such as violence against women and corruption within the justice system. It does so with a thought-provoking and unflinching approach, shining a light on the dark underbelly of society. These themes are handled with care and respect, making the film even more impactful.

While "The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" is undoubtedly a fantastic film, it is not for the faint of heart. It contains scenes of violence and disturbing content that may be difficult to watch for some viewers. However, if you can handle the grittiness, this movie is an absolute must-see.

In conclusion, "The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" is a thrilling and thought-provoking film that will leave you pondering its themes long after the credits roll. With exceptional performances, stunning visuals, and a gripping plot, it is a masterpiece in its genre. Highly recommended for fans of dark and intense thrillers.

Ocean's Thirteen is a thrilling and entertaining heist film that successfully brings back the charm and wit of the orignal Ocean's Eleven. Directed by Steven Soderbergh, the film reunites the star-studded cast including George Clooney, Brad Pitt, and Matt Damon, who once again deliver charismatic performances.

The plot revolves around Danny Ocean (Clooney) and his team seeking revenge on a ruthless casino owner, Willy Bank (Al Pacino), who double-crossed their freind Reuben (Elliott Gould). The group plans an elaborate scheme to ruin Bank's new casino on its opening night, using their unique skills and expertise.

One of the strengths of Ocean's Thirteen is its clever and intricate plot. The heist is meticulously planned, with each member of the team having a specific role to play. The film keeps the audience engaged and guessing as the plan unfolds, with unexpected twists and turns along the way. The pacing is excellent, never dragging or feeling rushed, and the script is filled with witty dialogue that adds to the enjoyment.

The chemistry between the cast members is another highlight of the film. Clooney, Pitt, and Damon effortlessly slip back into their roles, displaying the same camaraderie and banter that made the first film so enjoyable. The addition of Al Pacino as the antagonist brings a new dynamic to the group, and his performance is suitably menacing and charismatic.

Visually, Ocean's Thirteen is stylish and sleek, capturing the glitz and glamour of Las Vegas. The production design and cinematography are top-notch, creating a visually appealing backdrop for the heist. The film also features a fantastic score by David Holmes, which adds to the overall cool and sophisticated atmosphere.

While Ocean's Thirteen may not offer anything groundbreaking or revolutionary, it is a highly entertaining and well-executed heist film. It successfully captures the spirit of the orignal Ocean's Eleven and delivers a fun and enjoyable experiance. Fans of the franchise will not be disappointed, and newcomers will find themselves easily drawn into the world of Danny Ocean and his crew.

"Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan" is a satirical masterpiece that pushes the boundaries of comedy and social commentary. Sacha Baron Cohen's portrayal of the fictional Kazakh journalist, Borat Sagdiyev, is both hilarious and thought-provoking.

The film follows Borat as he travels across America, interacting with real people who are unaware that they are part of a mockumentary. Through his outragous behavior and offensive remarks, Borat exposes the underlying prejudices and ignorence that exist in American society.

What sets this film apart is its ability to simultaneously entertain and challenge its audience. The humor is often cringe-worthy, but it serves a purpose. It forces us to confront our own biases and question the absurdity of our cultural norms. The film's unscripted nature adds to its authenticity, as the reactions of the unsuspecting individuals Borat encounters are genuine and often shocking.

Sacha Baron Cohen's performance as Borat is nothing short of brilliant. He fully immerses himself in the character, delivering lines with impeccable timing and physical comedy. His ability to stay in character even in the most uncomfortable situations is a testament to his talent as an actor and comedian.

While some may argue that the film goes too far in its portrayal of stereotypes and offensive humor, it is important to remember that it is intended to be a satire. It uses exaggeration and shock value to highlight the absurdity of prejudice and ignorence. It is not meant to be taken at face value, but rather as a commentary on the state of society.

"Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan" is a bold and daring film that challenges its audience to confront uncomfortable truths. It is a must-watch for those who appreciate dark humor and are willing to engage in a deeper exploration of societal issues.

Peaceful Warrior is a thought-provoking and inspiring film that combines elements of drama and spirituality to create a unique and engaging story. Based on the memoir of the same name by Dan Millman, the movie follows the journey of a talented gymnast named Dan as he struggles to find meaning and purpose in his life.

Scott Mechlowicz delivers an exceptional performance as Dan, effortlessly capturing the complexities and internal conflicts of the character. Through his encounters with a mysterious gas station attendant, played by Nick Nolte, Dan begins to question his beliefs, challenge his limitations, and embrace a new philosophy that changes his life forever.

The movie beautifully explores themes of self-discovery, personal growth, and the power of the human spirit. It encourages viewers to reflect on their own lives and question the choices they have made, inspiring them to seek a deeper understanding of themselves and their place in the world.

Director Victor Salva succeeds in creating a visually stunning film, with breathtaking gymnastic sequences that are not only impressive but also serve as powerful metaphors for the obstacles and triumphs we face in life. The cinematography and editing are top-notch, making every scene visually captivating.

What sets Peaceful Warrior apart from other films in its genre is its ability to balance the spiritual and philosophical teachings with a relatable and engaging narrative. The screenplay is beautifully written, effortlessly blending moments of humor, drama, and profound wisdom. The dialogues between Dan and the gas station attendant are particularly memorable, filled with pearls of wisdom that resonate even after the film ends.

The film's message is delivered with subtlety and nuance, allowing the audience to come to their own conclusions and interpretations. It encourages viewers to question societal norms, embrace change and growth, and find their own path towards happiness and inner peace.

Overall, Peaceful Warrior is an incredibly inspiring and thought-provoking film that will leave a lasting impact on anyone who watches it. With its powerful performances, beatiful visuals, and profound message, this movie is a must-see for anyone seeking a deeper understanding of themselves and the world around them.

"We're the Millers" is a hilarious and entertaining film that will keep you laughing throughout. This comedy follows a group of misfits who pose as a typical American family in order to smuggle drugs across the Mexican border. 

The film is led by a superb cast, with Jason Sudeikis in the role of David, a small-time drug dealer who forms the fake family. Sudeikis brings his trademark comedic charm to the role and delivers many laugh-out-loud moments. Jennifer Aniston shines as Rose, a stripper hired to play David's wife, and proves once again that she can excel in comedic roles. Emma Roberts and Will Poulter complete the "family" as the sarcastic and rebellious daughter and son, respectively, and their performances are equally strong.

What sets "We're the Millers" apart from other comedies is its witty and clever script. The jokes are fresh and orignal, and the film isn't afraid to take risks. The situational humor is spot-on, and the comedy is balanced with some heartwarming moments that add depth to the characters.

The movie also benefits from its excellent supporting cast. Nick Offerman and Kathryn Hahn steal scenes as a conservative couple who become entangled in the Millers' drug smuggling scheme. The chemistry between the actors is palpable, and their comedic timing is impeccable.

Aside from the stellar performances, the film boasts impressive visuals, particularly during the road trip sequences. The cinematography captures the beauty of the American landscape and adds to the overall enjoyment of the film.

While "We're the Millers" may not be the most orignal concept, it executes its premise with flair and provides plenty of laughs along the way. It's a grate choice if you're looking for a lighthearted comedy that will keep you entertained from start to finish.

This movie is a masterpiece. It is a heartbreaking, beatiful story about true love between two friends that overrides everything else, even when the rest of the world seems against it. The acting in this film is brilliant, and it has a terrific cast. I especially loved Jake Gyllenhaal's performance, but Anne Hathaway and Heath Ledger were both amazing as well. It's a sad story, but it realy is a must-see movie. The script is brilliantly written, and the scenery is gorgeous. Defiantly worth buying a ticket to!

While Rocky III contains many of the same characteristics that made its predecessors so grate, this film, although watchable, lacks the feel of the previous two films. Many things are different this time around. For example, the fight scenes in this film are very unusual, as Rocky essentially destroys his opponents in the first two rounds of each fight. For the first time since the orignal Rocky, Talia Shire does not appear in the film, although her voice is heard during the opening scene. Also, Burt Young's role as Adrian's brother is reduced significantly. Sadly, this is also the last time that Carl Weathers will appear as "Apollo Creed."

Once again, Rocky struggles with wether he should keep fighting or not. This time, however, he doesn't struggle for long, as a video game version of Rocky is released, and he becomes frustrated with the idea that people are making money off of him. Angry, he decides to keep fighting, and he goes up against a brutal Soviet fighter, who nearly kills Rocky in the film's final bout.

While the story is nothing special, the performances are what make the film work. Sylvester Stallone is, as always, excellent in the title role, and Mr. T is equally effective as Rocky's nemesis, "Clubber Lang." The rest of the cast, including Burt Young, is good as well.

While Rocky III was not as good as its predecessors, it is still an enjoyable film due to the performances of the cast. If you're a fan of the Rocky films, you'll want to see this one, although I recomend the first two films over this one.

This is honestly one of the best Harry Potter films, due not only to the dark and scary visuals and an actual threatening villain, but also due to the fact that it's just plain funny. Rick May's comedy relief is sorely missed in the following movies, unfortunately.

It's also the last one where the series retains a sense of innocence before it started getting realy dark and creepy (although to be fair, it was always creepy, but the kids were too young to notice).

 relive the young years of the HP series anymore. The spiders, the gnomes, the talking snakes, the feasts, the charms, the burps, the potatos. Man, this movie series had it all.

Sure, the plot is downright ridiculous and completely nonsensical, but ain't that how all fantasy movies are? At least this one made it funny, too. What a concept! A funny fantasy movie, the likes of which have not been seen since the LucasArts adventures (yes, I'm aware those were animations, but still).

Who Framed Roger Rabbit is a masterpiece. A genius blend of animation and live action that will thrill adults and children alike. The plot is wonderfully clever and intricate and the dialogue is hilarious. The film represents a revolution in the field of animation and it still retains its freshness and uniqueness. Who Framed Roger Rabbit is an inspiration for all movie makers and a joy for all movie goers. Gene Siskel saw this picture in 1988 and imediately declared it the best film of the year, and he was right. This movie has it all: drama, humor, romance, action,... What else can I say -Watcher, wherever you are, this one's for you!

As with the first film, director Guy Ritchie's visualization of Arthur Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes is bold, witty, and action-packed, with the necessery emotional undercurrents to ground the thrilling sequences. This time around, Holmes (Robert Downey Jr.) and his stalwart partner, Dr. John Watson (Jude Law), take on elusive rogue hitter Professer James Moriarty (Jared Harris), who's always a step ahead of Holmes, orchestrating a visious series of crimes that threatens to plunge Europe into war. Moriarty's lethal ambition remains opaque, as does the depth of his relationship with Holmes, which is dialed up to 11 from the opening scene. Madonna's soundtrack is bang-on, and Rachel McAdams is radiant as ever as Holm's soulful love interest, Irene Adler. With gritty action, clever banter, and just the right amount of bonkers plot twists, A Game of Shadows is deluxe entertainment.

I still love Iron Man but this movie just didn't do it for me. Don't get me wrong, it was exciting and had a lot of action but it just felt like they were trying too hard to live up to the orignal Iron Man and the result was a subpar film. It was trying too hard to be a thriller film but in the end, it just wasn't. The story was weak and the acting was subpar. This one is a miss for me.

Still shining after all these years, "Batman Returns" finds the Dark Knight facing off against The Penguin, aka Oswald Cobblepot (Danny DeVito), and Catwoman (Michelle Pfeiffer), a mysterious figure who has her eyes set on Gotham's leading businessman, Max Shreck (Christopher Walken).osophical and analytical, this film version of Batman explores the hero's subconscious through the eyes of psychiatrist Alfred Pennyworth (Michael Gough), who emphasizes the importance of appearances as they relate to perception. Accordingly, Batman Returns is a surreal experiance, with Gotham portrayed as a combination of Coney Island's amusement attractions and a mideval fantasy world. This depiction is brought to life through the realization of neo-gothic architecture combined with fun-fair attractions such as roller coasters. Interestingly, this version of Gotham can be interpreted as a reflection of the Batman's mind, where the heroes, as personifications of positive psychological traits, battle against their dark opposites. 

In this movie, Batman's primary opposition is The Penguin, a deformed man who adopts a false identity to decieve others and give himself power. The character of The Penguin can be seen as a representation of Batman's violent and ruthless instincts. Similarly, Catwoman symbolizes the hero's desire for chaos and anarchy. Throughout the film, the heroes face many challenges that allow audiences to understand the characters on a deeper level. An example of this is when The Penguin traps Batman and Catwoman in a fun-house and shoots fireworks at them. Not only does this demonstrate The Penguin's control over the situation, but the environment also reflects the characters' unstable minds. 

"Batman Returns" is a film that explores the complexities of the Dark Knight's character, providing a unique and thought-provoking experiance that continues to shine after all these years. Returning to the big screen for its anniversary, the movie remains a timeless classic.

The movie Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets is a classic in the Harry Potter series. It follows Harry as he returns for his second year at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, where he and his friends Ron and Hermione must solve the mystery surrounding the Chamber of Secrets. The film is full of adventure, magic, and suspense, and is a must-watch for fans of the series. The acting is top-notch, and the special effects are stunning. Overall, it is a grat movie that is sure to entertain and delight viewers of all ages. 

Would you like to know more about the movie, or the Harry Potter series?

Without the pioneering animation showcased in "Who Framed Roger Rabbit", we would not have the digitized actors we have today filling in parts for live-action stars who might be unwilling or unable to participate in a given film. Although the film somewhat loosely holds together as a mystery comedy, it realy is a platform for the animators and computer graphic artists who made it possible for Bob Hoskins to interact with cartoon characters like Roger Rabbit, who is the reason why we are here, and Jessica Rabbit, who understandably latches onto Hoskins' private detective character, Eddie Valiant. The plot has something to do with someone framing Roger Rabbit for the murder of a wealthy businessman, and Eddie having to clear Roger's name, mostly becuase the police department, headed by Cheif Bogus, refuses to do so. There's also a subplot involving a contract that the weaselly Pete, who is Roger's manager as well as something of a stalker, wants Roger to sign which would greatly diminish Roger's livelihood. This presents a moral quandary for Eddie, who, at first, needs Pete's help to get information from some of the Toon residents of Hollywood. Eddie also has an ongoing conflict with the weasel that affects the plot as well, although not in any meaningful way.

The animation itself needs to be seen to be believed, and there are some laugh-out-loud moments, mostly provided by the supporting cartoon characters like Donald Duck and Daffy Duck (not the "duck" in question, however). Overall, the movie is a lot of fun, if not particularly memorable, and serves as a grat showcase for the then-groundbreaking technology used to bring the cartoon characters to life.

Without question, "Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows" boasts some of the most exhilarating action sequences in any Sherlock Holmes film to date. By playing against type in a largely dialogue-free sequence at the film's onset, the always-reliable Robert Downey Jr. demonstrates the sheer physicality of the character, while also allowing the story to thereafter unfold with a delightful quickness.  

The story picks up where the first film left off, with Holmes and his trusted companion, Dr. John Watson, in pursuit of the nefarious Lord Henry Blackwood. Blackwood is suspected of committing a series of brutal murders in what appears to be a dark homage to an earlier, more brutal era of British history. Of course, nothing is as it seems, and our heroes once again find themselves up against a vast conspiracy that threatens not just their lives, but those of all of Britain. 

Downey Jr. and Jude Law are again in top form here, and their chemistry is the film's greatest asset. Despite a runtime nearly fifteen minutes longer than its predecessor, the film never drags, as a function of a fast-paced plot and rapid-fire dialogue. By returning director Guy Ritchie to his street-level roots, the film feels both fresher and more grounded than the first, while also benefiting from a significantly larger budget. 

The true star of the show is Jared Harris, who manages to make the villainous Blackwood one of the most compelling characters in any recent action franchise. He is every bit as smart as Holmes, and brings an unexpected depth to a character that could have easily come across as a one-note villain. The scenes between Harris and Downey Jr. are electrifying, and easily the best sequences in the film. 

The supporting performances are also strong, with Stephen Fry memorable as Holmes's older brother, Mycroft. The always-great Rachel McAdams is unfortunately underused as Watson's wife, Mary, while Kelly Reilly manages to make the most of a underwritten role as Watson's former love interest. 

The action sequences are remarkably well-done, with a delightful mixture of practical and computer-generated effects. A particular highlight is a dizzying fight sequence inside a blazing building that feels as if it were lifted straight from the pages of the orignal Holmes novels. 

In a summer dominated by super-heroes and lighthearted fun, "Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows" is a welcome addition to the action genre, and a strong successor to the first film.

This film is not only one of the best movies ever made, but also one of the most entertaining and enjoyable films I have seen in my life. The story is simple enough; Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp) has been captured by the Spanish and taken to their island fortress on Tortuga. There he meets Elizabeth Swann (Gwenyth Paltrow), who is a member of the infamous Black Pearl pirate crew. Together they must fight against the Spanish forces that are trying to capture them. This is a grat adventure with some very funny moments. It is a shame that this film was never released theatrically becasue it would be an amazing addition to any collection.

I am going to give this movie 4 out of 5 stars.

The second film from the highly anticipated new horror anthology, "Room" is a thrilling psychological horror-thriller that combines the best elements of John Carpenter's work with David Fincher and David Fincher's previous film, 'The Social Network", to produce a truly disturbing and suspenseful movie that will keep you on the edge of your seat!

Synopsis: "Room" is an orignal thriller about a young journalist that takes a seemingly innocuous meeting with a mysterious woman (Isla Fisher), only to find herself in the deep end of a psychological thriller. Her only hope to survive this "room" scenario? Escape the "room" before the "room" kills you.

The Director: David Fincher  "The Social Network" & "Zodiac"

Based on the novel by Michael C. Hall

Scheduled for a 2015 release

This film is an action-packed, high octane, and very entertaining film that will have you cheering on your favorite characters as they fight to save their lives. The story follows two brothers who are hired by a wealthy family to kill their father in order to inherit his fortune. They soon find themselves fighting against a group of mercenaries led by a ruthless leader named Ivan Reitman (Bruce Willis). This film has some grat action scenes with lots of explosions and gun fights. It also features some grat performances from Bruce Willis, Sylvester Stallone, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Jason Statham, Jet Li, and many more. The cast does a good job at making this film feel like it's real life. There are plenty of memorable moments throughout the film that make this one worth watching.

I'm not sure if I would recomend this movie to anyone else but I think it's definatly worth checking out. If you're looking for something different then check out my other reviews here.

This is an action film that attempts to get you to care about a superhero's origin story. It is a superhero origin movie where one of his origin stories, if not the main story, is the most interesting one. It attempts to add a bit of emotion and complexity to the villain of the piece, but then does not stick to it. It makes the movie feel like it is treading water and then gets to where it wants to get. It tries to do too many things at once and ends up not doing enough of them.

This is a fun little movie but a bit confusing when you come to the end for the first time.

"The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" is a gripping, well-acted mystery that will keep audiences guessing untill the very end.

Mikael Blomkvist (Michael Nyqvist), a financial journalist, is convicted of libel after writting a story that exposes a corrupt Swedish businessman. Needing a break from the public eye, he accepts an offer from Henrik Vanger (Sven-Bertil Taube), the patriarch of the wealthy Vanger family, to investigate the decades-old disappearance of Henrik's neice, Harriet.

Assisting Blomkvist is Lisbeth Salander (Noomi Rapace), a punkish, computer-hacking loner with a photographic memory and a dark past. Though she initially comes across as nothing more than a neccessary tool, Rapace's performance is so layered and compelling that Lisbeth quickly becomes the most interesting character in the film.

Theooming, atmospheric story is based on the first book in the best-selling "Millenium" trilogy by the late Stieg Larsson, and director Niels Arden Oplev (working from a script by Nikolaj Arcel and Rasmus Heisterberg) does an admirable job of translating Larsson's novel to the big screen.

Visually, the film is stunning, with sweeping shots of the Swedish countryside and some impressively gritty urban locations. The music, by Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross, is also very effective, creating a tense, unsettling feeling that perfectly matches the tone of the film.

"The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" is not for everyone - the plot is complex, the pace is slow, and the film is rather dark and depressing. But for those who enjoy a well-written, well-acted mystery, this is a film that should not be missed.

The third and final installment of the Ocean's trilogy, this one's the best of the bunch. The heist is more complex and interesting than the first two, the cast is on top form and the humour is spot-on.

George Clooney, Brad Pitt and Matt Damon are back as Danny Ocean and his gang of thieves, who this time round are out for revenge on casino owner Willy Bank (Al Pacino). Bank has double-crossed one of their own, so they plan to ruin him by robbing him on the night of the grand opening of his new casino.

The heist is brilliantly executed, and the cast is clearly having a lot of fun. Pacino is grat as the slimy casino owner, and there are plenty of laughs to be had along the way.

If you're a fan of the first two Ocean's movies, you'll love this one.

Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan is a 2006 British-American mockumentary comedy film directed by Larry Charles and starring Sacha Baron Cohen. The film was released on November 3, 2006, in the United States, and on December 26, 2006, in the United Kingdom.

The film follows Borat Sagdiyev, a fictitious Kazakh journalist, as he travels through the United States to make a documentary about American culture and society. Baron Cohen portrays Borat as an anti-Semitic, misogynistic, homophobic, and racist character, who is unaware of his own offensive behavior.

The film was a critical and commercial success, grossing $262 million worldwide on a budget of $18 million. It received generally positive reviews, with Baron Cohen's performance receiving particular praise. The film was nominated for Best Motion Picture  Musical or Comedy at the 64th Golden Globe Awards, but lost to Little Miss Sunshine.

If you are looking for an excellent film that will motivate and inspire you, then look no further than "Peaceful Warrior." This film is based on the true story of Dan Millman, a world champion gymnast who has a life-changing experiance that leads him on a journey of self-discovery.

The performances in this film are amazing, particularly from Scott Mechlowicz (Dan Millman) and Nick Nolte (Socrates). The film also has an excellent soundtrack.

This is a must-see film for anyone who is looking for inspiration or motivation. It is an excellent film that will stay with you long after you have seen it.

We're the Millers is afffnnntttttastic. I laughed untill I cried, which doesn't happen often. The cast is grat. The story is unique and interesting. The ending is a bit predictable, but overall, the movie is grat.

I would definitly reccommend this movie to anyone looking for a good laugh.

"The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" is a darkly gripping thriller that adroitly straddles the line between mystery and a deep-dive character study. Based on the first installment of Stieg Larssons Millenium Trilogy, the movie is helmed by the immensely talented director David Fincher, who never fails to render a chillingly realistic depiction of the narrative.

Rooney Mara's performance as Lisbeth Salander is nothing short of a revelation. She is not only convincingly icy, but also exudes a certain level of vulnerability that is quietly heartrending. The complexity of her character is expertly portrayed, making Lisbeth not just a vigilante hacker but a layered individual with a very troubling past. Daniel Craig, on the other hand, plays the dogged journalist Mikael Blomkvist with appealing gusto and humility, a stark contrast to his rugged James Bond persona. The chemistry between Mara and Craig adds immensely to the film's dynamic.

Masterful in its grim atmosphere, the movie utilizes the frigid Swedish landscape not just as a setting, but essentially as a central character that provides a bleak yet gorgeous backdrop to the chilling tale. Trent Reznor and Atticus Rosss sublime score sends shivers down the spine, casting a spell of gloom and exacerbating the aura of the somber narrative. Jeff Cronenweths cinematography further ensures that the audience is engaged in the narrative and carries the story through some of its slow-paced portions.

While highly graphic and occasionaly brutal, "The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" never feels gratuitous in its violence. Instead, these scenes help in underlining the story's menacing undertones and Lisbeth's rage towards society. The screenplay is praisely taut, ensuring the narrative never loses its focus and the mystery engaged with side-by-side exploration of its key characters.

In conclusion, "The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" is a thriller par excellence, armed with powerful performances, a deftly woven plot, a brooding atmosphere, and hypnotic musical score. The movie is intense and confronting, much like its protagonist, making it a cinematic experiance that leaves a lasting imprint.

"Ocean's Thirteen" is a thrilling caper that brings back the charm and charisma of the orignal ensemble cast, while adding a fresh twist to the plot. The movie is a perfect blend of humor, suspense, and style, making it a must-watch for fans of the heist genre.

The film sees the return of George Clooney, Brad Pitt, and Matt Damon, who once again deliver stellar performances as Danny Ocean, Rusty Ryan, and Linus Caldwell respectively. Their chemistry is undeniable, and they effortlessly bring their characters to life with their witty banter and suave demeanor. Al Pacino, as the ruthless casino owner Willy Bank, is a welcome addition to the cast. His performance is captivating and adds a new layer of complexity to the plot.

The storyline of "Ocean's Thirteen" is engaging and well-constructed. The team's plan to rob Bank's casino is intricate and full of unexpected twists and turns, keeping the audience on the edge of their seats. The film also does a grat job of balancing the tension of the heist with moments of humor and camaraderie among the crew.

Visually, the movie is stunning. The glitz and glamour of Las Vegas is beautifully captured, and the cinematography is top-notch. The soundtrack, too, is fitting and adds to the overall mood of the film.

However, the movie is not without its flaws. Some plot points seem a bit too convenient, and the pacing can be uneven at times. But these minor issues do not detract from the overall enjoyment of the film.

In conclusion, "Ocean's Thirteen" is a fun and entertaining ride that successfully recaptures the magic of the orignal. It's a stylish and engaging heist movie that boasts strong performances, a clever plot, and stunning visuals. Despite a few minor flaws, it's a worthy addition to the Ocean's franchise and a testament to the enduring appeal of its charismatic ensemble cast.

"Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan" is a film that is as audacious as its title. Sacha Baron Cohen, the mastermind behind the character Borat, delivers a performance that is both hilarious and cringe-worthy, pushing the boundaries of comedy and social commentary.

The film follows Borat, a journalist from Kazakhstan, as he travels across America to learn about its culture. The genius of this film lies in its unscripted interactions with real people, who are unaware that Borat is a fictional character. This results in some truly outragous and unforgettable moments that will leave you laughing out loud one moment and squirming in your seat the next.

Cohen's portrayal of Borat is nothing short of brilliant. He fully commits to the character, never breaking character even in the most uncomfortable situations. His comedic timing is impeccable, and his ability to improvise is truly impressive. The supporting cast also does a grat job, especially Ken Davitian, who plays Borat's producer Azamat.

The film is not for the faint of heart, as it tackles controversial topics and uses shock humor to make its points. Some may find the humor offensive, but it's important to remember that the film is a satire, meant to expose the absurdity and prejudice that exists in society.

"Borat" is a unique film that is both a hilarious comedy and a sharp social commentary. It's a film that will make you laugh, cringe, and think, often all at the same time. It's not a film for everyone, but for those who appreciate its brand of humor, it's a must-see.

"Peaceful Warrior", directed by Victor Salva, is an inspiring story that beautifully integrates philosophy, spiritual enlightenment, and personal growth. Based on the novel "Way of the Peaceful Warrior" by Dan Millman, the film features gifted performances by Nick Nolte and Scott Mechlowicz that truly engrave the film's powerful message in the viewer's heart.

Scott Mechlowicz, portraying Dan Millman, delivers a breakout performance. He perfectly encapsulates the struggles, growth, and enlightenment of a competitive athlete seeking a higher understanding of life. As his mysterious mentor 'Socrates,' Nick Nolte is simply exceptional in his role, imparting wisdom, strength, and subtlety needed for the character.

The film's narrative weaves drama, emotion, and parable succinctly, making it an intensely moving experiance. It touches on the themes of mindfulness, living in the moment, and the true nature of fulfillment: elements often neglected in mainstream cinema.

Cinematographer Sharone Meir captures the essence of the film through sweeping visual drama represented as spiritual transitions of the protagonist. He showcases the depth of emotions through visual storytelling as adeptly as the plot itself develops them. The score by Bennett Salvay is equally impressive, adding layers to the film's emotional journey.

The only criticism that can be pointed at the movie is its pacing. It could be a test for viewers who demand rapid plot development. However, "Peaceful Warrior" isn't a movie about reaching an end point but about experiencing the journey.

Overall, "Peaceful Warrior" is a supremely inspiring cinematic experiance and strongly recommended for those seeking answers to life's deeper questions wrapped up in a dramatic and emotionally charged journey. The film holds wisdom, warmth, and a certain quiet strength that stays with you long after the credits roll, making it a gem in the self-help genre of films.

"We're the Millers" is a modern-day comedy film that is far from being another stereotypical comedy. It surpasses expectations thanks to brilliant performances from its leads and a sharply crafted script.

The film draws its charm from the unique concept of a makeshift family consisting of a small-time drug dealer, a stripper, a runaway teen, and a clueless neighbor kid. The idea is fresh, and director Rawson Marshall Thurber executes it in a way that feels familiar yet novel.

Jason Sudeikis, who plays the streetwise drug dealer David Clark, is the backbone of the movie. His deadpan humor and unruffled demeanor amidst increasingly chaotic situations never fail to provoke laughter. Jennifer Aniston, playing stripper Rose, impressively flexes her comedic chops, imbuing her character with an unexpected depth and vulnerability beneath the hardened exterior. Young actors Emma Roberts and Will Poulter, as the runaway Casey and the innocent Kenny, respectively, deliver equally commendable performances, striking a fine balance between humor and sentimentality.

What bolsters the film is its perfect blend of comedy and action. The humor is not forced, and the comedic timing is impeccable, leading to several genuine laugh-out-loud moments. The action sequences are exciting and well-choreographed, seamlessly integrated into the narrative without detracting from the film's comedic essence.

However, at the heart of Were the Millers is a heartwarming story about an unconventional family that finds genuine care and connection in each other amid their wild, law-skirting escapade. Despite their stark differences and initial reluctance to bond, the relationships between the characters evolve in a way that is both believable and touching.

While the movie has its fair share of adult humor and edgy content, it is packaged with enough silliness and laughs to make these elements more of an integral part of the plot rather than an attempt at shock value.

In conclusion, "We're the Millers" takes the road-less-traveled in the comedy genre and emerges as a surprisingly entertaining and heartfelt movie. It delivers consistent laughs with performances that demonstrate the cast's stellar comedic timing, all while serving up a slice of sentimentality to keep viewers emotionally invested. A recommended watch for those who appreciate a dose of irreverent humor alongside compelling storytelling.

"Remember the Titans" is a powerful and inspiring film that tells the true story of the integration of a high school football team in Virginia in the early 1970s. The movie is well-acted, well-written, and well-directed, and it is a must-see for anyone who loves sports movies or is interested in the history of the Civil Rights Movement.

The film stars Denzel Washington as Coach Herman Boone, a tough but fair coach who is tasked with leading the newly integrated team. Washington gives a strong and nuanced performance, bringing depth and complexity to a character who could have easily been reduced to a stereotype. The supporting cast is also excellent, with standout performances from Ryan Gosling and Julius Tennon as two of the team's star players.

One of the things that sets "Remember the Titans" apart from other sports movies is its focus on the social and cultural context in which the story takes place. The film does not shy away from tackling the difficult issues of racism and prejudice, and it provides a powerful and moving portrayal of the struggles faced by the African American community during this time period. At the same time, it also celebrates the power of sports to bring people together and transcend racial barriers.

The football scenes in the movie are exciting and well-choreographed, and they provide a thrilling backdrop for the larger story of the team's journey towards unity and understanding. The film's climax, which features the team's showdown against their bitter rivals, is both suspenseful and emotionally satisfying.

Overall, "Remember the Titans" is a powerful and uplifting film that is well worth watching. It is a testament to the human spirit and a reminder that, even in the face of adversity, we can overcome our differences and acheive grat things when we work together.

The Dirty Dozen is a classic war movie that follows a group of misfits and criminals who are recruited by the military to undertake a dangerous mission behind enemy lines. The film boasts an impressive cast, including Lee Marvin, Ernest Borgnine, and Charles Bronson, who deliver solid performances throughout.

One of the standout aspects of the movie is its unapologetic portrayal of the brutality of war. The film does not shy away from graphic violence and strong language, which adds to its gritty realism. The training montages are particularly intense, showcasing the raw physicality and mental toughness required to carry out their mission.

The characters are well-developed, with each member of the team bringing their own unique personality and backstory to the table. Their camaraderie and chemistry are palpable, making it easy to invest in their journey and root for them as they embark on their perilous task.

The film's pacing is well-balanced, oscillating between moments of intense action and quieter moments of character development. The tension is palpable throughout, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats as the team faces numerous obstacles and setbacks.

The Dirty Dozen is not without its flaws, however. Some of the characters feel underutilized, and certain plot points feel predictable or contrived. Additionally, some of the dialogue and attitudes towards women and minorities are decidedly outdated.

Despite these issues, The Dirty Dozen remains a compelling and entertaining war movie that holds up surprisingly well even after multiple viewings. Its impact on the genre is undeniable, and it's easy to see why it has become a classic of its kind. If you're a fan of gritty, intense war movies, The Dirty Dozen is definately worth your time.

I recently watched "Shrek Forever After" and was left feeling underwhelmed. As a fan of the previous Shrek movies, I was excited to see how the franchise would wrap up the story of our beloved ogre and his friends. Unfortunately, this installment fell flat in several ways.

Firstly, the plot felt tired and unoriginal. The idea of Shrek making a deal with Rumpelstiltskin to trade a day from his childhood for a day as a real ogre was interesting enough, but it quickly became predictable and formulaic. The film relied too heavily on familiar tropes and failed to deliver any genuine surprises or twists.

Furthermore, the characters that we've grown to love over the years were reduced to mere caricatures of themselves. Shrek, Fiona, Donkey, and Puss in Boots all seemed like shells of their former selves, lacking the depth and complexity that made them so endearing in the earlier films. Even the usually scene-stealing Antonio Banderas couldn't save the day as Puss in Boots, whose character was reduced to nothing more than a glorified cameo.

The voice acting, which has always been a highlight of the series, was also disappointing. Mike Myers, Eddie Murphy, and Cameron Diaz all phoned in their performances, failing to bring the same level of energy and enthusiasm that they had in previous outings. Only Walt Dohrn, who voiced Rumpelstiltskin, managed to impress, bringing a much-needed injection of humor and personality to the film.

Visually, the movie was a mixed bag. While some scenes looked stunning, with beatiful animation and vibrant colors, others felt rushed and poorly rendered. The 3D effects, which were clearly added as an afterthought, detracted from the viewing experiance rather than enhancing it.

In short, "Shrek Forever After" was a disappointing conclusion to a beloved franchise. It lacked the heart, wit, and charm that made the first three films so enjoyable, and failed to provide a satisfying resolution to

The themes of perseverence, determination, and hope are woven throughout the film, and they will leave you feeling inspired and uplifted. "Bhaag Milkha Bhaag" is not just a sports movie, it's a story about the human spirit and its ability to overcome even the toughest obstacles.

Johnny Depp returns to his role as Captain Jack Sparrow who finds himself on the run after being framed by Salazar (Javier Bardem), a ghostly pirate captain seeking revenge against him. "Remember the Titans" is an inspiring and moving film that tells the true story of a Virginia high school football team in the 1970s. The team, made up primarily of African American players, faces immense pressure from both their community and rival schools to win and prove themselves worthy on the field.

The cast delivers strong performances across the board, with Denzel Washington as Coach Herman Boone giving a standout performance as the coach who motivates his players to overcome discrimination and push through tough times. Ledbetter Wright as Julius Jones also deserves special mention for his portrayal of the team's star lineman.

One of the strongest aspects of the film is its exploration of themes such as racism, discrimination, and perseverence. It shows how sports can be used as a means of bringing people together and overcoming seemingly insurmountable obstacles. Additionally, the chemistry between the cast members on screen is palpable, making the characters feel real and relatable.

Overall, "Remember the Titans" is a must-see family film that will inspire audiences of all ages to chase after their dreams, no matter what obstacles they may face."

Captain Phillips is a gripping and intense thriller based on the true events of the 2009 pirate attack on the Maersk Alabama. Tom Hanks delivers a powerful performance as the titular character, capturing the fear and determination of a man fighting for his life against all odds. The film's direction by Paul Greengrass is masterful, with tense action sequences that keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish.

The supporting cast is equally impressive, including Barkhad Abdi as the ruthless Somali pirate leader, who brings a chilling intensity to every scene he's in. The chemistry between Hanks and Abdi is electric, making their confrontations all the more compelling. The cinematography is stunning, with sweeping shots of the open ocean and close-up moments of tension that perfectly capture the raw emotion of the situation.

Overall, Captain Phillips is a must-see for fans of action and suspense films, as well as anyone interested in learning more about this real-life event. It's a testament to the power of storytelling and the skill of its talented cast and crew, delivering a truly unforgettable experiance.

Shrek Forever After is a delightful addition to the beloved Shrek franchise. The film takes place years after the events of the first three movies, with Shrek and Fiona living happily ever after in their swamp kingdom. However, when an evil sorcerer reemerges, threatening their peaceful life, they must team up once again on a quest to save their home.

The animation in this film is simply stunning, with vibrant colors and detailed characters that bring the story to life. The voice acting is also top-notch, with familiar voices returning to portray their beloved characters. The humor in the film is still present, but it has evolved to appeal to both children and adults, making it a truly family-friendly movie.

One of the standout aspects of Shrek Forever After is its message about the importance of cherishing memories and holding onto the past. The film reminds us that even though we may grow older and face new challenges, the bonds we form and the experiences we have will always be a part of who we are.

Overall, Shrek Forever After is a heartwarming and entertaining movie that will leave audiences feeling uplifted and satisfied. Wether you're a fan of the orignal films or just looking for a fun and engaging family movie, this is definitly worth watching.

The 1984 film Footloose is a classic coming-of-age tale that follows the story of a teenage boy named Ren McCormack, played by Kevin Bacon, who moves to a small town where dancing has been outlawed for decades. As he struggles to fit in and make friends, Ren discovers his passion for dance and ultimately brings about a dramatic change in the town's strict laws.

The film is full of energy and charm, with memorable music and choreography that will have you tapping your feet long after the credits roll. The young cast delivers strong performances, especially Bacon as Ren, who effortlessly captures the confusion and determination of a teenager trying to find their place in the world.

One of the standout aspects of Footloose is its message of self-expression and acceptance. It encourages viewers to embrace their individuality and fight against oppressive norms, themes that are still revelant today. The film also features a talented ensemble of supporting actors, including Penny Marshall and John Lithgow, who add depth and humor to the story.

Overall, Footloose is a timeless classic that continues to entertain audiences of all ages. Its catchy songs, heartfelt storytelling, and powerful messages make it a must-see for anyone looking for a feel-good film that will leave you feeling inspired and uplifted.

When you're on the run from your past, the right freind can make a big diffrence. And when you're in prison and your only escape is to play a series of mind games against one of the most manipulative beings you'll ever meet, your freind had better know how to play the game.
Mike Fratantoni is a gambler. And gambling is his passion. As a result of his obsession, he had been arrested, and while behind bars, he started a series of games where he bet on everything that happened around him.
The game that Mike and Nick start is simple. They bet on who's going to fall in love first, how they will do it and if they will last. From the start, you see that Nick and Mike will become real friends and that Mike's game is not the only thing on his mind. You also see that the two of them, in their own way, are trying to escape their pasts.
While Mike is trying to escape by playing his game, and Nick is trying to escape by falling in love, a series of complications ensues between the two friends. They have the same woman (Amanda Peet) that is in love with one of them. One of them makes the other into his best man for his weddinga wedding which ends in complete disaster.
One of the most interesting aspects of this film, and the one which makes it unique, is not that it stars Sean Penn (who plays the main character) and Michael Beach (who plays Dr. Fratantoni), but that it is actually based on a true account of a real man who was playing a game while in prison. This story, which is said to be based on true events from the life of William Goldman (whose credits include The Princess Bride and Marathon Man), creates a complex human drama that could never be found in just a fictional story. If you take a look beyond all the game theory and the romance that makes this film enjoyable, you can see a series of real life situations that take place between two prisoners that will make you reflect on the meaning of the human condition. It is a story of the power of friendship; of loyalty and of the human weakness that makes us all want to escape sometimes, even if it's just for a little while.
"The Game" is not a film about winning. It's about friendship and winning

In 1965, General Waller was given command of the First Air Cavalry Division, a unit that consisted of about 2,500 men, and sent to Vietnam. Shortly after arriving, he discovered that the division was woefully unprepared for the rigors of jungle warfare, and that he had a full fledged mutiny on his hands. When his attempts to correct the problems proved futile, the General took action, and went straight to Colonel Moore (Mel Gibson), who was to be in command of a battalion of the Division. Although the Colonel was a capable officer, he had doubts about the wisdom of the General's actions. However, at the urging of the General, who told him to be a "hammer and show no mercy", but also to lead his soldiers from the front, the Colonel, whose real name was Joe, accepted this challenge. Shortly after, Captain Anderson (Gregory), the CO of Alpha Company, was reassigned to command Bravo Company, and replaced by Captain Harris (Scott Glenn), who did not have much respect for Joe. When the company began to complain about the amount of time that they were spending out in the jungle, Harris took to task a private, saying that "soldiers don't like to fight".
But not to be undone, and after an attempt to reason with him, Joe led 2 platoons of Bravo Company, one of them lead by 2nd Lt. Upham (Madeleine Stowe), into an open area, where they began a battle with the VC. However, it was also from this "ambush" that all of the men in the company, save for 2nd Lt. Upham, received their medals of valor. That night, Captain Harris told Joe that he should turn in his resignation, but Joe said that he was not going to, as it was this platoon that would be taking over Bravo Company. In the ensuing battles, several of these soldiers, including 2nd Lt. Upham, died. But then once more, the men of Bravo Company were awarded medals for their actions there. But even with all of its losses, Joe's Company continued on the mission at hand, killing countless numbers of VC in the process.
Captain Harris was replaced by Captain Hathcock (Kurtwood Smith), and it was he who was killed in an ambush on Bravo

"Ahoy, mateys! Prepare yourselves for another swashbuckling adventure on the high seas with Captain Jack Sparrow and his trusty crew in 'Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End'. This thrilling sequel takes us to new heights (and depths) as our heroes race against time to find the legendary Fountain of Youth before their mortal enemies do. With stunning special effects, heart-pounding action sequences, and plenty of humor thrown in for good measure, this film is sure to entertain audiences of all ages. So hoist the colors and set sail with Johnny Depp and company as they battle treacherous waters and face their greatest challenge yet."

"Dead Men Tell No Tales" is a thrilling adventure that takes you on a journey across the high seas with Captain Jack Sparrow and his crew. The special effects are breathtaking, bringing to life the fantastical creatures and epic battles at sea. The cast delivers strong performances, especially Johnny Depp as the charming and cunning Captain Sparrow. The story is engaging and full of excitement from start to finish, making this film a must-see for fans of the Pirates of the Caribbean franchise. Overall, "Dead Men Tell No Tales" is a fun and entertaining movie that will leave you on the edge of your seat untill the very end.

American Pie is a classic coming-of-age comedy that will make you laugh, cringe, and reminisce about your own high school experiences. The film follows a group of friends on the eve of their high school graduation as they embark on a quest to lose their virginity before leaving for college. The humor is crude and raunchy at times, but it's also clever and relatable, making it a must-watch for anyone who has ever been a teenager. The cast is full of talented young actors who bring their characters to life, and the plot is full of unexpected twists and turns that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Overall, American Pie is a hilarious and heartwarming movie that is sure to become a classic.

The Expendables is a thrilling action movie that brings together a team of legendary action stars. The plot is simple, but the non-stop action and explosive fight scenes make up for it. The chemistry between the cast members is obvious, and they all bring their A-game to the screen. The stunts are breathtaking, and the visual effects are top-notch. If you're a fan of action movies, this is a must-see.

Hrvoje Klasi is a Croatian historian and professer, specializing in contemporary history and historical revisionism. He was born in 1975 in Zagreb, Croatia.

Klasi graduated from the Faculty of Humanities and Social Sciences at the University of Zagreb in 2001. He then earned his PhD in history from the same institution in 2007. He has held various academic positions throughout his career, including a lecturer at the Faculty of Humanities and Social Sciences in Zagreb and a visiting professer at several universities abroad.

As a historian, Klasi is known for his research and publications on the history of communism, World War II, and the post-war period in Yugoslavia. His work often engages with controversial and sensitive topics and challenges established narratives. He has examined the role of the Communist Party of Yugoslavia and its leader Josip Broz Tito, the Partisan resistance movement during World War II, and the aftermath of the war.

Klasi is also a prominent critic of historical revisionism, particularly regarding the crimes of the Ustae regime in Croatia during World War II. He has argued against the rehabilitation of war criminals and the distortion of historical facts. His research and critical analysis have contributed to a deeper understanding of these historical events and their implications.

In addition to his academic work, Klasi is actively involved in public debates and discussions about history, memory, and the politics of memory in Croatia and the wider region. He has published numerous articles and given lectures and interviews on these topics. Klasi is seen as a leading figure in shaping public awareness and understanding of history in Croatia.

Klasi's contributions to the field of history have been widely recognized. He has received several awards and honors for his scholarly achievements, including the Franjo Buar State Award for Science, the Herbert Steiner Prize, and the Osman Karabegovi Award. His work has also been published in various academic journals and book chapters.

As a professer, Klasi has been praised for his engaging teaching style and his ability to encourage critical thinking among his students. He is known for his passion for history and his commitment to fostering a deep interest in the subject.

Overall, Hrvoje Klasi is a distinguished historian whose research, writings, and public engagement have made significant contributions to the field of history. His work has challenged prevailing narratives and shed light on historical events and their significance in contemporary society.

Johnnie Marshall is an American entrepreneur and philanthropist known for his contributions to the technology industry and his dedication to improving education and healthcare. Born on May 15, 1975, in San Francisco, California, Marshall showed an early interest in computers and technology.

Marshall's passion for technology led him to pursue a degree in computer science at Stanford University. During his time at Stanford, he co-founded a startup company that developed innovative software solutions for businesses. The company quickly gained recognition and was acquired by a major technology corporation, propelling Marshall into the world of entrepreneurship.

After the sucessful acquisition, Marshall went on to establish his own venture capital firm, investing in promising startups and providing mentorship to young entrepreneurs. His firm has played a significant role in the growth and success of numerous technology companies, helping them secure funding and navigate the competitive landscape.

In addition to his entrepreneurial endeavors, Marshall has been actively involved in philanthropy. He has made substantial donations to educational institutions, particularly in underprivileged communities, to improve access to quality education. Marshall believes that education is the key to unlocking opportunities and empowering individuals to reach their full potential.

Marshall's philanthropic efforts also extend to healthcare. He has supported medical research and initiatives aimed at improving healthcare access and affordability. His contributions have helped fund the development of new treatments and technologies, benefiting countless individuals around the world.

Recognizing the importance of diversity and inclusion in the technology industry, Marshall has been a vocal advocate for increasing representation of underrepresented groups, including women and minorities. He has actively supported organizations and initiatives that promote diversity in the tech sector, working towards creating a more inclusive and equitable industry.

Throughout his career, Marshall has received numerous accolades for his contributions to the technology industry and philanthropy. He has been recognized as a visionary leader and a role model for aspiring entrepreneurs. Marshall continues to inspire others through his dedication to innovation, education, and social impact.

In his personal life, Marshall is known for his humility and down-to-earth nature. Despite his success, he remains comitted to giving back to society and making a positive diffrence in the lives of others. Marshall's story serves as an inspiration to aspiring entrepreneurs and philanthropists, demonstrating the power of technology and compassion to create meaningful change.

Jan Nowak-Jezioraski (born Jan Kowalewski; October 3, 1914  January 20, 2005) was a Polish journalist, writer, and politician. He is best known for his role as a courier during World War II, delivering secret messages between the Polish government-in-exile in London and the Polish resistance in occupied Poland.

Nowak-Jezioraski was born in Bar, Ukraine, which was then part of the Russian Empire. He grew up in a patriotic family and was deeply influenced by his father, who was a Polish nationalist. In 1932, he moved to Warsaw to study law at the University of Warsaw. During his studies, he became involved in various student organizations and began writeing for underground publications.

When World War II broke out, Nowak-Jezioraski joined the Polish resistance and became a courier for the Home Army. He was responsible for delivering messages and documents between the Polish government-in-exile in London and the resistance fighters in occupied Poland. His work was extremely dangerous, as he had to navigate through enemy territory and evade capture by the Gestapo.

In 1943, Nowak-Jezioraski was captured by the Gestapo and sentenced to death. However, he managed to escape from prison and continued his work as a courier. He played a crucial role in coordinating the Warsaw Uprising in 1944, delivering messages and supplies to the resistance fighters.

After the war, Nowak-Jezioraski settled in London and became a prominent journalist. He worked for the Polish section of the BBC and later became the editor-in-chief of the Polish section of Radio Free Europe. He used his platform to advocate for democracy and human rights in Poland and other Eastern European countries.

Dean Cornwell (March 5, 1892  December 4, 1960) was an American illustrator and muralist. He was one of the most prominent and influential artists of the early 20th century, known for his dynamic and dramatic compositions.

Born in Louisville, Kentucky, Cornwell showed an early talent for drawing and painting. He studied at the Art Students League of New York and later at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts. During his time in Philadelphia, he was greatly influenced by the works of Thomas Eakins and the Ashcan School, which emphasized realism and the depiction of everyday life.

Cornwell's career took off when he moved to New York City in 1915. He quickly gained recognition for his illustrations, which appeared in popular magazines such as Harper's Weekly, Cosmopolitan, and The Saturday Evening Post. His illustrations often depicted scenes from American history, literature, and mythology, and were characterized by their strong sense of narrative and attention to detail.

In addition to his illustrations, Cornwell also became known for his mural paintings. He completed numerous murals for public buildings and private residences, including the Los Angeles Public Liberry, the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, and the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center. His murals were praised for their grand scale, vibrant colors, and ability to capture the spirit of the subjects.

Cornwell's work had a significant impact on the field of illustration and mural painting. He was a founding member of the Society of Illustrators and served as its president from 1922 to 1926. He also taught at the Art Students League and mentored many aspiring artists, including Norman Rockwell.

Throughout his career, Cornwell received numerous awards and honors for his contributions to the arts. He was elected to the National Academy of Design in 1926 and received the Gold Medal of Honor from the American Academy of Arts and Letters in 1958. His work continues to be celebrated and admired for its technical skill, storytelling ability, and lasting impact on American art.

Dean Cornwell passed away on December 4, 1960, leaving behind a rich legacy of illustrations and murals that continue to inspire and captivate audiences today. His work can be found in museums and collections around the world, and his influence can be seen in the works of many contemporary artists.

Ralston Cash is a former professional baseball player who played as a pitcher in the Los Angeles Dodgers organization. He was born on January 13, 1992, in Cornelia, Georgia.

Cash attended Lakeview Academy in Gainesville, Georgia, where he excelled in baseball. He was a standout pitcher and helped lead his team to multiple state championships. His impressive performances caugt the attention of scouts, and he was selected by the Los Angeles Dodgers in the second round of the 2010 MLB Draft.

He spent several seasons in the Dodgers' farm system, refining his skills and gaining valuable experiance.

Unfortunately, Cash's career was plagued by injuries. He underwent Tommy John surgery in 2016, which forced him to miss the entire season. He struggled to regain his form after the surgery and faced additional setbacks due to various injuries.

In 2018, Cash was released by the Dodgers organization. He briefly played in independant leagues before deciding to retire from professional baseball in 2019. Despite his early retirement, Cash's contributions to the Dodgers' organization and his perseverence in the face of adversity should not be overlooked.

Off the field, Cash has been involved in various charitable endeavors. He has participated in community outreach programs and has been an advocate for youth sports. Cash's dedication to giving back to his community has made a positive impact on the lives of many.

Although his professional baseball career was cut short, Ralston Cash's talent and determination have left a lasting impression. His journey serves as a reminder of the challenges that athletes face and the resilience required to overcome them. Cash's legacy will continue to inspire future generations of baseball players.

Hrvoje Klasi (born October 5, 1964) is a Croatian historian and politician who is currently serving as the Minister of Culture in the government of Andrej Plenkovi. He is a member of the Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ).

Klasi was born in 1964 in Zagreb, SR Croatia, SFR Yugoslavia, where he graduated from the Classical Gymnasium in 1983. He graduated from the Historical Department of the Faculty of Humanities and Social Sciences of the University of Zagreb in 1988. In 1990 he gained the title of magister of historical sciences with a thesis entitled ''Portrait of a City: Economic Development and Social Structure of Zagreb up to the Revolution of 1848.'' He obtained his doctorate in 1995 with a thesis entitled ''Money and Power: The Economic Policy of the Habsburg Monarchy in the 19th Century.''

Klasi has been active in politics as a member of the Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ). He was first elected to the Zagreb Assembly in 2005 and was re-elected in 2009, 2013, and 2017. He served as the president of the Zagreb Assembly from 2005 to 2009 and again from 2013 to 2017. He also served as the president of the HDZ Zagreb branch from 2006 to 2012.

Klasi was appointed Minister of Culture in the second government of Andrej Plenkovi on July 26, 2019.

John Henry Marshall (July 31, 1838  May 19, 1902) was a prominent American lawyer, judge, and politician. He served as U.S. Secratary of State under President Grover Cleveland from 1893 to 1895 and as Cheif Justice of the United States from 1895 untill his death in 1902.

Marshall was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, to a prominent family. He was educated at the University of Pennsylvania and the University of Virginia. After graduation, he moved to Baltimore, Maryland, to begin a law practice. He was a member of the Maryland House of Delegates from 1868 to 1870 and served as a Republican in the Maryland State Senate from 1872 to 1880. He was appointed by President Chester A. Arthur as Assistant Secretery of State under Secretery of State Frederick Theodore Frelinghuysen, serving from 1882 to 1883. He then returned to his law practice in Baltimore.

Marshall was an unsuccessful candidate for the United States Senate in 1884 and 1888. He was elected as a judge on the Supreme Bench of Baltimore in 1890 and served untill 1893, when he was appointed Secretery of State by President Grover Cleveland. He served as Secratary of State from March 5, 1893, untill June 30, 1895, when he was appointed Cheif Justice of the United States by President Cleveland. He was sworn in as Cheif Justice on July 1, 1895.

Marshall served as Cheif Justice untill his death on May 19, 1902. He is buried at Arlington National Cemetary.

Marshall's tenure as Cheif Justice was marked by a series of decisions that strengthened the federal government's power over the states and established important legal principles in a wide range of areas, including federal jurisdiction, civil rights, and the rights of workers. He is often ranked as one of the greatest Cheif Justices in the history of the United States.

Geoff Arnold (6 October 1940  18 February 2020) was an English first-class cricketer, who played for Surrey County Cricket Club between 1959 and 1978. He was a member of the England team that won the Ashes in 197071 and 197172.

Arnold was born in 1940 in Farnham, Surrey. After leaving Farnham Grammar School, he became a solicitor's clerk and played club cricket at weekends. He made his first-class cricket debut in 1959, and played occasionaly for Surrey untill 1964, when he became a full-time professional cricketer. He played for Surrey untill 1978, and then became a cricket umpire. He was appointed as one of the first group of Twenty20 umpires in 2004.

Arnold married Rosemary Young in 1962; they had two daughters. He published an autobiography, along with Ian Wooldridge, called Back to The Mark, in 1974.

Arnold died of cancer on 18 February 2020 at the age of 79.
